RATING: 7
I believe we have played 3 games not 2. This is perhaps the game where we have had the most fun with storytelling games. I write this comment after having played Mansion of Madness for the first time.

While the mechanics are not the same, I compare the two anyways. The game is quite similar after the Betrayal have happened, but just with other tools on hand. The exploration are random in Betrayal, and it is cause for some hilarious and silly things to happen. But due to the randomness it can really tilt the game in each sides favor. It can be quite broken, but if your mindset is right, it is a very good game.

Mansions of Madness are more set in stone, and it might be the story we played, but the story was not as fun and we were just not as into it. But the overlord role is fun and different. sorry for the rambling. Two somewhat similar games, but with a slight edge to Betrayal.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I really didn't like this game. I seem to be in the minority on this and most of my friends seemed to enjoy it, but here were my issues:

(1) Slow, Drags on Too Long. It took us a little over 4 hours to get through one game. Most of that time, I felt like I was sitting around doing nothing. 

(2) Very Arbitrary. There's not a one-size-fits-all formula for me, but I like strategy games that are maybe 80% - 90% skill and 10% - 20% luck, and I'm OK with social games that just allow people to have fun regardless of the "fairness." Betrayal plays more like a "strategy game" with the dumb luck of a social game; i.e. it's a strategy game without much strategy. Within 2 turns, my character was basically on the verge of death just due to dumb luck. Which might not have been so bad if it weren't for the aforementioned fact that the game drags on for quite a long time.

(3) Poor Gameplay Dynamics. The whole game felt very clunky to me. Too many things not well explained, the characters don't necessarily mesh together, omens and bad events are completely random. 

(4) Too Complicated; Too Much Going On. The true mark of a great game is that it manages to have complex strategy, while being a relatively simple and straight-forward game. This is where Betrayal fails the most miserably. There's absolutely nothing straight-forward about it and you're constantly having to learn all kinds of random rules to manage. 

I guess a lot of people are into the horror RPG theme, but that doesn't really do it for me. I can get into a "horror strategy game" if it actually has some real strategy (see "Zombicide"), but this was just painfully boring to me. I may be in the minority, but I hated this game.

RATING: 8
Fun, light, short, and very thematic. Feels a bit RPG-ish as each player has their own character with their own stats and inventory. Makes a great story as you play that is remembered long after the game ends. There are two phases of the game: first, players explore a haunted house and find weird items and have spooky things happen to them. Second, someone turns evil and the players play out one of the scenarios in the haunt books. The haunts can be very one-sided for either the good guys or the traitor, depending on how the exploration part of the game went. It's pretty random and sometimes has incomplete or ambiguous rules; fortunately, the errata is available online. Must play for Halloween.

My copy has been edited quite a bit. The haunt books have been updated to match the revised books, and some of the haunts have been edited further. The underground lake tile and the event where you get an item through the mirror have both been fixed, too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Basically an improved version of the original. Monster chits with pictures on them, clearer rules, and less errors. BUT, it also has flimsier cardboard (not an issue if you have BOTH editions :p ).

RATING: 8
Another fun and thematic party game that you can play also (or especially) with friends who are not hardcore boardgamers. Like [i]Last Night on Earth[/i], it's best when served with a few cold beers and a healthy dose of not-taking-it-too-seriously. This one's a bit heavier though, and involves some reading-a-few-pages-of-scenario-specific-instructions-halfway-through-the-game (and even a bit of role-playing) so it's perhaps not for everyone. But in the right kind of company it's a blast!

RATING: 5
The game plays best at 4-6 players, where the players might stand a chance against some of the super OP haunts, but at more than 4 players, the game drags like crazy and you hardly move every turn, only revealing maybe one or two rooms before your move ends. Then, if the haunt is too easy, it feels like everything you've worked for (building your stats, building the house, gathering items and special kinks to the house) was pointless as you demolish the poor haunted player until no one wants to play again. The game needs something for other players to do on the other players' turns, or to shorten turns/make them simultaneous; the game is too disengaging for a light, beer and pretzels horror game.

RATING: 8.4
This was a brilliant game. Although learning the game from scratch was difficult, it was easy to teach other people how to play. Having the game start out as non-hostile is helpful for newcomers to transition into the basic mechanics of the game, and then are introduced to the betrayal and monsters, which help advance gameplay. Although I can see how this game could potentially get old after playing so many scenarios (there will eventually be a repeat scenario), it doesn't necessarily detract from the difficulty of the scenario itself. Keyword being necessarily. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Finally, a game that my husband loves as much as I do.  Why?  Because he loves being the traitor and killing us all.  Sure, he just happened to become the Voodoo Master that one game, and had scattered dolls of us around the house that we had to find before they were destroyed (if our doll was destroyed, our character died.) Sure, he played it perfectly and committed a TPK against everyone playing, leaving him victorious... and sure he gloated about killing me for weeks.  

But even all that couldn't destroy my love for this game.  The shear number of possibilities - the fact that we win as much as we lose.  And the epic rescues! I remember the time I played as Flash. We were shrunk to the size of mice and had to get the toy plane to fly out of the house - and I single-handedly was able to rescue everyone and fly out the window because my speed was so high (which was the stat needed to fly the plane).  It was great.  Epic rescues like that - or the close shaves - are what I live for.  It's all about the story.  And this is a storytelling game with tiles.  The best of both worlds.

RATING: 7.5
Not really a boardgame but "assisted roleplaying". It can be a lot of fun, but all the players need to be involved and interested in the gameplay. The end tends to be arbitrary based on how late the changeover occurs, and how many players are involved (a full complement of 6 players and a late change almost guarantees a player win, and a loss is certain in an early change or fewer players). The scenarios are fun and varied though. Definitely needs better pieces for the monsters.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Playing Betrayal is like having dinner with a good old friend. You're going through stories that you've gone through a 1000 times before. There might be minor updates, it's not particularly funny or new or exiting, and sometimes there are weird things happening. Sometimes it's boring and meaningless. Sometimes there's nothing left to say. 
But at the end of the evening you realize it has been wonderful to see this person again, and that you had a wonderful time after all. And you're sad that it will take some time until you meet again.
I love playing Betrayal. The Other Player makes an art of introducing new players to the game without actually explaining a single rule in the beginning, just taking everyone down in the madness. And even though there are some weird errors in the game (looking at you, underground lake on the first floor) it is always fun to play and I will play it again and again until the last mad man has been hunted down.

RATING: 4
Overall, betrayal on the house on the hill is enjoyable, plus quick to setup, unlike Mansion of Madness. I find the narrative like Zack's "Akimoto and Jaspers characters cant do anything with the word open in it.'' more entertaining than if we were talking about absolute strategy to beat the situation in depth. The resulting story was uninteresting and unbalanced (I ask for challenge or entertainment, both is a bonus, but this gave neither).  The moment the traitor was revealed the best part of the game was over.

RATING: 3.9
Betrayal at House on the Hill is a game whereby players explore the rooms of a haunted mansion.  As players explore, players play tiles of rooms to create their own mansion, they are also trying acquire items or pets that are useful to themselves as they prepare for the final showdown with the betrayal.

At 1 point of the time, 1 player "secretly" plots to betray the rest of the party.  It is a race against time as the innocent players must complete their task before the betrayal to win the game.

Good points: It is interesting to see how the mansion develops internally as players joins up different tiles.

Bad points: The game indeed has a lot of bad points.  First of all, the rules of the game is not clear at all.  During the game itself, we had a hard time trying to resolve what should be done or it will be unfair to either the betrayal or the innocents.  Though it is interesting to build the haunted mansion, the mansion can develop into an illogical manner, with a door in 1 room but the room tile beside it is a solid wall.  During the phase whereby the betrayal plots against the innocents, the innocents read from a book called 'Secrets of Survival' while the betrayal reads 'Traitor's Tomb' booklet.  Throughout the game, the traitor and the innocents are trying to fulfil their own goals without other party knowing each other's goal.  When 1 side suddenly declares that they won, the other party is baffled.  Though in each booklet, it does hint on how to stop each other party from winning the game, it is not made obvious to the players.

After thought: I have made a lot of remarks especially bad ones on this game.  It may due to the friends that I played this game with.  One of my friend cares a lot about winning and the betrayal, which happens to be me, is discriminated by him throughout the game.  I did not enjoy during the game.  Throughout the game, I just want the game to end.  As mentioned above that one player "secretly" plots against the rest, the player is revealed and not in secrecy at all though I know that the secret means the secret mission that each side is going to take.  I think I need to play the game with some other group of friends to have a fairer comment.

RATING: 7.1
2011-02-15
The first half of this game is wandering around aimlessly, watching your and the other players stat dieals being increased or decreased based on some random die rolls.  This can be interesting if played in character or reading the cards with a spooky voice, but in general is just an extended setup time until the real game starts.

Once the real game starts, it is 1 (vs) All, and the one person gets monsters & superpowers, trying to destroy the other players, who are trying to accomplish an objective before a time runs out (or death).  There are an incredible number of scenarios, which are chosen randomly each time, so there is definitely replay value here, but don't expect a thought driven game.  Just sit back and enjoy the ride.

RATING: 7
Betrayal at House on the Hill quickly builds suspense and excitement as players explore a haunted mansion of their own design, encountering spirits and frightening omens that foretell their fate. With an estimated one hour playing time, Betrayal at House on the Hill is ideal for parties, family gatherings or casual fun with friends.

Betrayal at House on the Hill is a tile game that allows players to build their own haunted house room by room, tile by tile, creating a new thrilling game board every time. The game is designed for three to six people, each of whom plays one of six possible characters.

Secretly, one of the characters betrays the rest of the party, and the innocent members of the party must defeat the traitor in their midst before it’s too late! Betrayal at House on the Hill will appeal to any game player who enjoys a fun, suspenseful, and strategic game.

RATING: 5
A haunted house crawler with two distinct parts.  In the first, the party splits up in time-honoured fashion to explore creepy rooms alone.  The rooms randomly offer items that may be useful or pitfalls to weaken your character.  The artwork and flavour text work quite nicely to build some atmosphere.  

Die rolls trigger the second part, in which we discover that one of us is a traitor and that there is a scenario with victory conditions for them and us.  The scenarios are where the game has, for me, come off the rails three times out of three.  They just aren't well balanced.  Even judging Betrayal as an experience game, I see that as a major flaw; don't all horror B-movies at least manage a nail-biting climax?   

My comments are about the Avalon Hill edition, which is the only one I have seen.  Production quality is good.  The pre-painted miniatures are especially nice.  The artwork is good too.  The rules are short and full of holes.

RATING: 8
At first I was a bit skeptical about the quality of this game because the components are not the greatest quality. However, with up to 50 different possible story lines, it ended up being a really enjoyable game. Since you don't know who the traitor will be, what the end game is, or even what order the rooms will appear, there is a lot of anticipation at the beginning. Sometimes the game can seem broken because the specific end game will give an extreme advantage to the traitor or the investigators. For example, If the goal to win turned out to be "escape the house" and the investigators are only two or three squares from the front door, and the traitor is on the second floor of the house 10 tiles away, then there isn't even a chance the traitor can win, but hey, then you can just reset the board and play again! I was also worried because it was aimed at 3 or more people and I typically play 2 player games. However, since you don't know who the traitor will be, and can't really prepare for it, each person takes two investigators and then when the traitor is revealed, they can give their other investigator to the other player and it doesn't really ruin anything. Its not the style of game where you can "sup up" a character to prepare for the end game.

RATING: 7
A rather unique game with a fabulous haunted house theme.  Borrows traditional mechanics from role playing games and in fact plays a bit like one.  The first half of the game is rather random with frankly minimal decision making.  The second half consisting of the haunt that turns one of the players against all the others is very cool.  In the right mood, say on Halloween, with the right crowd, it might be one of the most compelling experiences in boardgaming.  
The second edition has very poor components compared to the first edition.  The tiles are too thin and warp almost immediately.

RATING: N/A
Simple to learn, easy to play game with an emphasis on theme and story telling.  Role playing during this game would be easy to do, even encouraged.

That being said... this game could be considered an anti euro.  This game has little to no strategy, is high on luck factor and largely depends on the ability of the players to "get into character".  

The fun of this game is in the story the players will write during game play.  Guaranteed, if players immerse themselves in the events unfolded by the game and take time to appreciate the imagery being presented there will be a fun and entertaining story to relate long after the board is packed up and the box put away.

RATING: 7
I feel like I am just going to be repeating what every one else says about this game. It could be SO GOOD but the Haunt can clutch up this game so bad and so fast. The first half of the game is the best part. You explore the house entering rooms where God only knows what terrors lie in store for you. Cards and tiles give you such flavor text that you cannot help but be drawn into the theme. 
But once the Haunt happens all that tends to fall by the way side. There are so many ways the game can go and there's no way to know if the game play will continue to work or if it will just break on you right then and there. Plus the haunt can happen so quickly in the right situation that any exploration of the house stops dead robbing the players of what almost everyone universally agrees is the best aspect of the game. 
Plus let's be honest ... the components are not great. Those character boards are a joke, the card stock is not good and those minis are atrocious. If some one can just fix the second half of the game it might go way up in all gamers' estimation

RATING: 5
I've played three times now and I believe the biggest determinant of victory is the number of players.  With few players, the traitor has an edge; with many, he has virtually no chance.  There are two reasons: first, there is no scaling up or down of the difficulty of the haunt beyond a very minimal "if 2-3 players then 2 hits are needed, 4+ means 3 hits are needed" and so forth.  Second, if rooms containing key items needed to defeat the haunt have not been revealed, then they're simply dropped in the good guys' laps.

This is not a bad game and has some clever mechanics but in none of my plays has the outcome ever really been in doubt as soon as the haunt began.

RATING: 5.5
As a thematic game, this one does a good job of delivering.  The game starts out with all players 'on the same side', but at some point - someone becomes the 'baddie'.  The game takes a pretty hard hit for the transition because the baddie now has to read a section that explains the game they will now be playing.  This makes the pacing stumble right when it should get racing.  But once over the hurdle, the game returns to a quick flow.  The quirky layout and odd typos actually add to the bizarre feel of the game and that brings the game up to its final rating.

RATING: 7.5
It's a catch-all horror/suspense style game with light RPG elements, such as different traits that will determine dice pools. There's a bit of a disconnect in the first 'exploration' phase and then the 'haunt' phase, since one player will suddenly find their game change to fit the new role, but when played properly, this can actually be fun. I think you just need to go into it knowing that since the narrative and objectives of the game are going to change so much in each session, that you're really along for a kind of generic horror ride inspired by a lot of the classics, but a little random feeling.

RATING: 6
A good co-operative game with the titular betrayal happening at a random time and to a random person. As if that wasn't enough to add re-playability there are also 50 different stories to experience at random when the betrayal happens.

A fairly quick (roughly 45 mins) game that will keep you coming back.

Though I do recommend adding either some sticky-backed plastic to the character boards, or to the insides of the plastic stat-markers as in this re-release the markers slide too easily and often move while playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I played v1 a few years ago (which is out of print), and happily bought v2 when it finally came out.  Apparently there are some slight tweaks/improvements, but it's so subtle that I didn't notice them. 

I brought my copy of v2 to another game group's game-night.  And it took over.  we played it 3 times in a row (about 4 hours).

The "trader" makes it all work.  You go from and "exploring" game to a "survival" game right about the time exploring is getting comfortable to you.  Then, when the game is actually over (after the survival half of the game)... you're totally ready for another round of exploring --> especially because you know the next "trader" will trigger a totally different "survival" scenario.

There's 50 trader scenarios, which means the game can surprise you 50 times. (and if you have a short memory, like me, it will surprise you every time! :) )

Also... just because you play a scenario a second time, doesn't mean the player controlling the trader will make all the same decisions as the trader did last time.  Even the same scenario is worth playing more than once.

I recommend this to friends and try to create reasons for 3 people to get together and play.  That's the only drawback, you need more than 2 people to play.  But that can easily be a bonus because more people are more fun in this type of game. :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A B horror movie generator. There isn't much strategy to be found, if any at all. Almost every part of this game is random. Move you piece to a new room, place the random tile, pick up the random card and do it's action, and probably rolling a random die roll to see what happens. Haunts are problematic in that they are often lop-sided. It's not that they are all broken (some are), but that the board will often evolve in such a way that one side will have to jump through some ridiculous hopes to win; this particularly true if a bunch of required room are on the board and need to be found. There are some other problems as well, such as the rules a bit of a mess. The first edition had a million and one counters that need to be sorted (the second edition wisely pared it down).

Still, I rate it highly. Why? Well, it's short and you can knock out a couple of games in an evening. The kitschy movie horror theme fits this game very well.

RATING: 7
Initial Impression: This is a game about the experience, where winning and losing shouldn't matter to the players. The game thematically presents the tropes found in many B-movies and introduces a traitor mechanism in the later half of the game. Although my first experience was wonderful, I can imagine that the random rooms, omens, events, and twist may not always line up for a cohesive story. Overall I enjoy the game with one caveat; for the 1st edition of the game, the FAQ is essential as the rulebook and Traitor Guide are missing critical information.

RATING: 9
Great group game that can be loads of fun with anywhere from 3 to 6 players. It definitely is a bit more complex in regards to amount of mechanics and parts than Catan, Munchkin, or Ticket to Ride, but the strategy level seems to be much lighter than those games. The theme can be a bit dark for some people and the pre-haunt phase can be a bore if you aren’t playing with a solid lively group, but otherwise I don’t really have any complaints about this game! If you like thematic games that go deeper than your typical board game then Betrayal is a must! Recommended Players: 3-6.

RATING: 4
I'm not a huge fan, but my (casual gaming) friends seem to like it.

The game can be very quick (if the Haunt happens quickly) or very long (if there's lots of exploring.)

The variant where the Haunt starts sooner sounds like a good one.  (If only I could find that variant!)

The game can also be hit-and-miss, for instance, if two items are necessary and you've already found both (instead of having just found one and having to explore for the other), the game's going to get a lot easier and less dynamic.

A game with a lot of great ideas, but not always successfully executed.  A great reason for the "accelerated game" variant.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Love love this game! 

It's all about having a spooky adventure, and there are 52 fun and kooky different stories that can happen.

Look, first of all this is a cooperative game. So those of you who love to win and feel like you are clever by strategizing, this is not quite that kind of game.

People who like clearcut games, this one is random and uneaven, that's the price you have to pay for the key elements of the game:
You never know what's going to happen, what behind the next door or who will turn on the group and become the traitor. 

Strongly thematic and all about random fun exploration and having fun with different stories.

Served best with thematic music, candelights and dramatic reading of the cards.

RATING: 5
Reading the rules and the haunts or literally anything in this game is an absolute struggle. Just house rule everything that doesn't make sense to you, trust me, it's much easier than trying to find specifics within the rules. Also, use an app for this game. It makes the character point tracker much easier than the garbage provided by the game. Components are less than adequate.

Now to the actual game. It's alright. Tile exploration that inevitably sets up the haunt is creative. The Haunt scenarios are also creative but good luck trying to be a survivor because every Haunt monster seems to be over powered. I try my best to avoid this game but the theme is attractive to people so it tends to come into play more often than I'd prefer.

RATING: 7
Interesting semi cooperative game where the traitor is determined halfway through and there are 50 possible different scenarios, setup by every game having tiles placed differently. This one is very fun to play, although requires some house rules in certain situations. The only main con I have with this game is that it's entirely possible for the random "haunt" to be mostly in one sides favor based on what happened up until that point. But still, the variability and intrigue make this one a must try for everyone. 

Also, the way the two separate books was done can be incredibly confusing, and it's hard to tell what you should and shouldn't be sharing with the other players.

RATING: 8.5
A fast-paced and fun cooperative game: even though Betrayal at the House on the Hill is quite complex it is very easy to understand and quickly grows as a satisfying experience even for newcomers. Unlike the usual witch-hunt games, this one’s betrayal system causes no problem, for everything about the turn of events is set by a table in the rulebook: thus it is immediately clear who the «betrayer» (often a victim himself) is, which prevents both confusion and the usual suspecting everyone else that in the end kills such games.

RATING: 6
When introducing this game to players, especially those used to the German school of gaming, provide these caveats before starting:

1. There are rule ambiguities.  The scenarios may tell you to do something but leave you with more questions.  Make a best guess and keep the game moving.

2. The haunts usually are either too easy for the traitor, or too easy for the heroes.  So the ending will likely be anti-climactic.

3. The game is not strategic.  You may die from bad luck and there be nothing to prevent it.  Whether you win or lose has little to do with how clever you are.

The game is more for the experience.  At the end, a story will be told, and the journey there can be fun.  If the players know what to expect going in, everyone can have a good time.  It is a unique experience and I am glad to own it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After about 10+ plays of this game, it definitely gets pretty stale. Once you've seen all the different cards, you just know what to expect from then on out and no one at the table even feels like reading them anymore. It's all so random too. You can end up with crazy high stats when the haunt begins or you can end up one stat away from death.  

At least at the end, there is still the anticipation of the haunt. That feeling of not knowing what you're going to get in too. That will at least last a few more plays.

Two problems, the haunts are usually so imbalanced and random that they aren't very fun for at least one person and the rules are not very well written. For me, I needs detailed rules that don't leave anything out. We usually have to fill in the blanks and come up with house rules for a lot of situations.

Still, in all honesty, I look forward to playing the game. It's like an uncontrollable roller coaster ride that feels slightly different every time. Sure, The game is so random that it's hard to control the outcome, but at least if you have a good group of people playing, it's a damn good ride.

RATING: 7
This game’s biggest strengths are tied to some of its biggest flaws: 
Pros:
It has massive replay-ability because there are 50 different haunts. I seriously doubt I’ll ever play all of them while owning the game myself.
I LOVE how the house exploration always give the game a new feel. Even the same haunt won’t usually play out the same way, due to the unexpected nature of the exploration and dice rolls.
Cons:
Because there are so many different haunts, you’ll inevitably run into some rule issues. I’ve seen many haunts that seemed very, very difficult for the traitor to ever win, or the non-traitors to ever win. If you have someone that is overly concerned about these “balance” issues, this game might annoy you at times.
Also about the rules… it can be fairly complex to understand from just reading the rulebook. A quick Youtube video showed me some of the mistakes I made trying to play this one “blind” out of the box. I’ve heard there are even some extra printouts online that can be printed to add to your rulebook to try and clarify some of the confusions caused by this rulebook, but I haven’t gone through the trouble to find and print these yet. A re-vamp of the rulebook would be helpful, and maybe the expansions to the game I’ve heard about also help this.

RATING: 6
My rating of this may be coloured by the fact that I was the traitor the first 4 times I played it (pre-logged games). I don't object to being evil, but it does get old after a while. There's also the issue of the original rulebooks being so full of problems. But once you download the revised Survival and Traitor books (as of Dec. '05) and play a couple games with the right group, it's quite fun.

Make sure to play this with a group that doesn't mind some down time, and who are flexible about making up house rules on the fly to cover specific situations. Also, don't play too often, or it will lose it's charm.

Final suggestion: if you continue to be named the traitor and begin to tire of it, I suggest declaring a "[your name here] is not the traitor today" rule, and switch characters with someone at the haunt if you're the traitor again. Worked for me.

RATING: 9
Love this game! It has such a massive amount of stories to explore (50!)that it just keeps the suspense and excitement fresh with each play. I love the aspect of starting the game cooperatively only to end up with someone becoming a traitor and the change in gameplay that makes for. The tiles are amazingly realistic for the various rooms and areas of the house with detail right down to the rugs in a room. A cheaper alternative to Mansions of Madness with more storylines to play through. It won't have the same depth as Mansions of Madness but it's worth the purchase. The tiles can warp if you get an older set though which is unfortunate but shouldn't ruin the gameplay itself.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is, of course, a classic game that has been reissued and many of its original ideas have been copied in other games. It shows its age a little bit in the first half of the game where players wander around really waiting for the real game to begin. It's fair to say that the game's design "invites you in" but your group has to be willing to add the proper spirit to the play of the game because the mechanics won't drag you in on their own (as do the mechanics of Chaos in the Old World or Twilight Struggle, for example). That said, with the right group in the right mood, this has to be regarded as a game that deserves to hit the table once in a while. The fact that the traitor - along with a whole new set of mechanics and win conditions - are revealed halfway through each game makes this still a highly original and fun game to play. It's a must play game for Halloween.

RATING: 6
The idea of this game really excites me. It is incredibly unique with high variability and a must have with the right group. Needless to say, the components and rulebook are subpar. Gameplay is flawed at any player count and most of the haunts are funny but anticlimactic. 

As a group, you'll randomly wonder around acquiring items with no strategy. You'll want to talk in spooky voices and maybe even laugh a little. Then suddenly, the game has had enough of you... You're placed in teams and given agendas with vague guidelines. Whether you win or lose, or some clarify rules, you realize it's too late... You were the ones betrayed.

RATING: 7
Es un juego de exploración en el que unos personajes se adentran en una casa encantada. Cada jugador lleva un personaje que está caracterizado por cuatro parámetros (fuerza, cordura, inteligencia y rapidez). La partida está dividida en dos fases. En la primera, todos los jugadores son compañeros y se dedican a explorar habitaciones (losetas que se van añadiendo a la casa). La casa tiene tres plantas. Las habituaciones en ocasiones ocultan sucesos, objetos y presagios. Cada vez que se descubre un presagio hay una tirada para determinar si se pasa a la segunda fase del juego o no.
Cuando se pasa a la segunda fase del juego, uno de los jugadores se convierte en un traidor. Según el lugar donde se haya descubierto el presagio que ha causado el inicio de la segunda fase, y el presagio, se determina un reto. El reto es diferente (y oculto) para el traidor y para el resto de los jugadores. A partir de ese momento, el traidor y el resto del grupo tienen que tratar de cumplir con el reto. Cuando uno de los dos lo consigue la partida termina. El traidor puede ganar o perder la partida. Si pierde, el resto de los jugadores ganan.
Está entretenido  y jugado con la gente adecuada, puede ser muy divertido. Rejugabilidad inmensa.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
A game so thin it's almost sickly. The first half is a randomly-generated exploration phase that is meandering and meaningless thanks to nonexistent goals; the second half is more structured and satisfying but still neutered of its complexity thanks to the first half. The thrills of turning over a new house tile and seeing what gets built where wears thin after the first few plays, and a few of the Haunts -- the second half 'activities' -- are either overused or totally broken. This game does serve as a good introduction to more complex, similar games like Arkham Horror, but ultimately doesn't have any staying power once you migrate to games with a tighter design.

RATING: 7
The game that keeps being new. It always starts out the same - characters exploring a haunted house - but there are many different ways the house can be haunted. One game you may be trying to re-unite a ghostly bride with her groom's dead body and the next you may be fighting a frankenstein monster. For most scenarios, there is a traitor so one player gets possessed by the house and starts working on the side of evil (as well as controlling monsters). 

The one drawback is that there are a MILLION tiny little pieces. I highly suggest getting lots of tiny little bags and finding a way to label what's in them so you don't hold up a game that can move fast and have an excited, quick pace by searching for the little cardboard circle labeled "girl" or "rat" or "secret passage."

Some of the scenarios are better than others. Most require teamwork and cooperation, some more than others. 

I've run this game in the YP (Young Player) room at Kublacon and it works great with kids. However, if you are going to play this game with younger people (I don't recommend under age 10), you might want to pre-select the haunting scenario to make sure it will be something that is easier for kids to understand and will keep their attention like one where everyone is fighting one monster and then make sure that the traitor is NOT a kid.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This game has two parts -exploring and building the haunted house and the haunt where one player becomes the traitor.
When this was the first non monopoly board game I owned, it was really fun.
However
the big problems with this game
1) The first phase sucks. All you do is move into rooms and have things happen to you. There is very little real choice in this phase. Everyone just waits 30 minutes for the real game to start.
2) The 50 different "haunts" (ending scenarios) are all sorta same-ish and frequently unbalanced. Many of them boil down to "get x item and go to y room and attempt dice roll while avoiding monster." The first few times they are charming, but the gimmick gets old fast.

It can be a charming Halloween game, especially when paired with silly RP. However, there are better games to play. I'm likely going to give my copy away

D Tier

RATING: 6.5
Betrayal is one of those games you'll either love or hate.  It has very little in the way of strategy, but is long on narrative.  It has more control than Tales of the Arabian Nights, but less than something like Arkham Horror or Mansions of Madness.  We don't play it often, but it does play fine with 2, and it is unique in that the horror theme is kind of general - there are all kinds of plots/story lines that can occur, which is neat.  Really, I own it because it reminds me of Mystery Mansion, which was one of my faves as a kid - building up the manor house is just plain fun.  Long on flavor, light on decisions, but very enjoyable once in a while.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is just a fun game to play. No, it's not perfect: timing of card effects and haunt instructions are often unclear, and the game sometimes does break down. There is very little strategy, and there is tons of randomness. 

But with all the bluffing and the suspicion created by the traitor, the game still makes for a silly, stupid good time. The theme is hilarious (it reminds me of all those campy Bruce Campbell flicks) and the randomness of the events/rolls just makes it funnier. My husband loves it, and I don't mind playing it, so we're keeping it for now. Just a warning for more die-hard gamers: if you take this game too seriously, you are bound to be disappointed.

RATING: 7
Betrayal is probably the Worst game that ive ever LOVED. I say this because of how completely random the outcome is. Sometimes the game is unwinable for one side or the other, and the rest of the time its just very skewed. It's probably the worst balanced game ive ever played. Having said that i have a blast every time. Well most times anyway. Most people i play with get totally into the theme of the game and can leave the need to win at the door, and that is required in my opinion to enjoy this game. Their have been a few plays of this where a person or two cared about winning instead of having a cool experience and they brought the whole table down. For that reason and that reason alone i try to only play with people i know will be happy to almost roleplay this game. Im not sure why the box doesn't say you can play it with 2 players, my wife and i have played it several times each controlling 2 characters and when the haunt happens whoever controlled that character takes that role and the other person takes the three remaining. it's a blast this way.

RATING: 1
UPDATE: Played this again for Halloween, just for grins. You know, it helps a lot if you go in expecting the game to be totally stupid, and probably broken, and prepared to roll with it. If you can be amused by the fact that these are some of the most horridly confusing rules ever, and that you are likely to have to read even a simple haunt 3 or 4 times just to figure out what the hell they are trying to get across, it's possible to come away feeling like the time spent on this game wasn't completely wasted.

The game is still total crap, of course. I was looking over the credits, and I blame Mike Selinker. He's the lead developer. It's clear that this was a complete and total development failure. And Mr Selinker has certainly been involved in more than his share of really bad games. I'll be treating his name as a monstrous red flag in future.
---
Awesome concept, poor execution. Oddly, reminds me of Escape from Colditz, although not as good. You will have fun directly proportional to the number of cards you get to draw and keep. If you are the bad guy and draw few or no cards, you're screwed and the game will be dumb. If you get some cards, you can maybe slow the good guys down. The breadth of scenarios sounds really cool, but it appears some of them weren't even proofread, never mind playtested. If you can get into the spirit of the game, that's cool, but in order for this kind of cooperative game to be compelling, it has to be *hard* for the cooperative side to win. With more players, this is not hard, and can even be a cake walk if the players stick together. An awesome idea and a valiant try I think, but it's just not well-executed. Play LotR: Sauron. People may say "but it's not a game, it's a role-playing experience", but it also lacks any of the good qualities of role-playing, and the utter randomness of the game fails to convey any real sense of theme. It's just Talisman. If you can get into it without much help from the game, you'll be in good shape; but you could say that about almost anything.

RATING: 9
Next to Arkham this is my favorite "co-op" game.  Even though one of your party members will turn on the rest, I still consider it a co-op game.  This game bleeds with theme and flavor.  From the exploration aspect, to the action cards, to the stories behind each scenario.  There is even a room called the mystic elevator that each turn can end up on anyone of the three floors.  If you are looking for a game that will put you in the middle of a slasher movie, this is it. This can also be a slight downer for some. Many of the action cards can be a bit intense depending on your play group. Tons of replay due to the 50 or so scenarios. One word of caution. If you own the game and play with a new group, force the fact that you will be the one to turn on everyone else. Otherwise the newbie might have some real trouble completing their part and making the game less enjoyable for both you and them. Only gave Arkham a 8.5 because of the time commitment.  This game gets a 9 because from the top down it hits nearly everything on the head.

RATING: 6
Update: Kind of took me a long time to be able to articulate why I like Betrayal when I dislike so many fiddly American games, but I think I've finally got it:

To me, Betrayal feels like a light hour-long roleplaying game. The entire first half is like a playable character generator, and then the scenario proper kicks in and you've got to do the best with what you've got and see where the story takes you. Yeah, it's random and unbalanced but if you just embrace the theme it's a lot of fun.

A lot of people find the first half of the game dull and disconnected from the scenario, but I quite like things starting off slow and full of mystery. To me the whole start phase enhances the theme - I really feel like I'm exploring a haunted house and combination of building the map as you go and random scenarios really build excitement for me - [i]oh my god anything could happen! what's going to happen? will there be ghosts? skeletons? is that a vampire's coffin???[/i]

Almost no theme-first games have really stuck with me, especially not over the years. Betrayal has and I suspect it will be continue to be my go-to when I'm craving a spot of horror.

RATING: 8


I have always had fun playing this. Even though the players have somewhat limited control the game is good, simple and atmospheric fun.

The bit when one of the players turns out to be evil (when the "Haunt" begins) can slow the game down a little if it is played with non-gamers who may not be confident with interpreting the sometimes hazy "Haunts" rules.  The fact that it plays very fast with a handful of players is a big plus.

You *need* the Universal Head files for this game that are available on its BGG page.  

Additionally, you also need the guide to counter storage too ( I cant remember the name of the kind BGG'er who made that).  It really works though.

RATING: 4
This is a fun, harmless little game. There is some light decision making, but it's mostly an experience game. And it only takes around 45 minutes, so it doesn't outlast its welcome. 

That said, there are lots of rules ambiguities. And it can be bizarrely complicated when the heroes and villain have to read their special rules, and it is easy to mess it up, and those rules have their own ambiguities. Still, if everyone just interprets as best they can, so long as heroes and spirits are fighting to the death or insanity in a spooky haunted house, it all works out OK.

Also, even with multiple scenarios, once you've blown through the rooms and cards, probably not a lot of replayability. 

Update: Subsequent plays have been terrible. You really need to get lucky with the scenario as to whether it is interesting or competitive.

RATING: 4
I was persuaded to buy this by two of my good friends whom my wife and I play games with around once every two weeks. They had played it before and found it to be a blast, so naturally I had to get it. Furthermore, it would fill a hole in my gaming library which I hadn’t managed to cover as I’m a eurogames guy. After we played it twice, I understand why I don’t like these kind of games but prefer eurogames, and I feel like I had been betrayed... 

It is just a lot of roll and move and overall not any fun. There are some tactics involved about when to use which items etc., especially once the haunt starts. But before the haunt starts, it’s a very uninteresting game which can drag. I understand that if you love the theme and feel you are a part of a group in this haunted house, it could be fun, but I don’t get the feeling of exploring a haunted house. 

Also, once the haunt starts, you need to read a bunch of rules, and if you are a new player and are the traitor, you might have some questions which can be hard to ask about without ruining the game. The actual haunts were quite uninteresting and I really didn’t feel like I was fighting a dragon – and that is important to feel in this game as the actual gameplay is lacking.

RATING: 5
RPG-lite game with lots of 'B movie' atmosphere. It's quite luck dependent and needs to be played with the right crowd who can enjoy the game for the experience it provides. The rules are fairly easy and the games short so player elimination is not too big a factor though it is frustrating when your character is killed off early on (usually by ending up trapped in the basement with the traitor). 

I think WotC missed a trick by not including some 2D stand-ups (like Steve Jackson's Cardboard Heroes) but I notice a fellow geek has provided a link in a thread so players can download their own.

Several plays to date. Here's a record of plays with my new 2nd edition copy (Scenario - Heroes [Dead heroes], Traitor *Winner*):

22 - Jim, Antony, Hugo, Philip, [Me], Chris W the little girl *Heroes*

15 - Steve (the Prof), [Me, Hugo], Jen *Heroes*

Demon Lord scenario - Mark, Ian, Mike B, [Me], Colin the little girl *Heroes*

RATING: 7.8
Based on gameplay alone, Betrayal at House on the Hill is at least an 8 or 9, maybe even a 10, but the utterly abysmal components that this game came packaged with drag the score waaaay down. 

Seriously, the plastic figurines that my copy of the game came with are hideous. I am almost embarrassed to play this game with people because the miniatures look so horrid. 

Despite the crappy components however, this game is just dripping with theme and makes for a great, horror-themed evening. The rules are easy to learn, and that makes it a nice alternative to games like Arkham Asylum and Mansions of Madness. You can easily teach this game to new players in 5-10 minutes, and as soon as you know it, they will betray you and all of your teammates to some kind of terrible supernatural fate. 

This game is a lot of fun, but if you are serious about playing it often, I'd recommend looking for some spare components to replace what is packaged in the box.

RATING: 7.3
A good 'experience' game. I feel like the theme is really strong in this one.

This is one of my favorite games, even though it can be a little 'wonky' at times. Some may say they don't like it because they don't have any direction at the beginning of the game, I can forgive that; I still enjoy that exploration phase. This game is about atmosphere, and not tight mechanics.

RATING: 8.5
Quality Note - plastic clips used as markers on the character cards are the wrong size for the card stock. Ever so slightly too wide. Gently squeezing the tips together while dipping the clips in hot water (not boiling) for a few seconds before dropping them into an ice bath... Did the trick of tightening their grips. If they are too tight, widen them by slipping the clip onto the flat edge of a knife, dipping them in the hot water again and on to the ice bath. It would also be desirable that the clips reach to the numbers they point at, but this is a minor quibble. I am mostly upset that the game is not playable out of the box due to this oversight of the manufacturer.

RATING: 6
The cooperative element is a huge bonus, allowing this to be easily accessible to casual gamers.  The theme is great.  The bits are nice....but the retail price is still too high for what you get.  Consider the source.

Played twice and would enjoy playing again.  This is light, make no mistake.  The rules are quick and simple...and not particularly tight. Be prepared to have to make a couple group rulings on unclear points.  But for a game that you can get on the table and start playing right away...they're ideal.  Just don't expect some intricate miniatures rules.

My two concerns with this game are 1) replayability and 2) niche.  There are the 50 basic scenarios and I'm sure there will be expansions. I also think they'll be pricey.  Once you've played a scenario, its not very appealing to do the same one again.  A lot of the fun is not knowing exactly what your opponent(s) objectives are.  Still, to be able to play it 50 times is probably plenty.  By then you can play "Betrayal at Van Down by the River" or whatever the next edition is.

As for "niche" what I mean is that this is not a gamers game.  Its a fun activity.  If I were meeting for 4-5 hours of gaming...I'd start with something meaty, then play Betrayal and then move on to something else meaty.  You won't get your fix of strategic thinking from this one.

Overall...I really like this game. I think the rating could go down with time...but right now I really want to play it some more.

RATING: 5.5
How much you enjoy this game will depend a great deal on how you appreciate the mid-game twist. Partway through the game, one of you will be declared the "bad guy." On the plus side, with 50 different mid-game twist storylines, there's a wealth of replayability here.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Decent little title from old Avalon Hill. 

To summarize: the game is essentially a move and explore title for the first half, and then a frantic panic with combat affair on the back end. In the early going players are all cooperatively exploring the haunted house, however, as one comes to certain rooms Omen cards are flipped over which are, for lack of a better term, creepy events. Each time an omen card is picked up the player has to roll a number of dice (the Betrayal dice are 2 blanks, two 1's, and two 2's) and roll higher than the number of Omen cards that have been revealed over the course of the game. The first part of the game, this exploring aspect (wherein the party picks up useful items that will make the back half of the game more intersting) continues until one of these omen based (haunt) checks is failed; then the second half begins. The players then have to consult the massive chart in the scenario booklet (which contains 50 right now...I think?) and one of the players betrays the party and is given new objectives while the other players will continue to cooperate, trying to foil the betrayer's plans with the winner being the first team (betrayer or the 'good guys') to achieve their goal for the scenario revealed. 

The game play is pretty straight forward, and without going into it at super length, it works. The title isn't heavy by any stretch, the dice inject a healthy amount of randomness, as do the random mansion tiles, the random omen cards, and the random items. I think this game has to be taken for what it is, which is an experience game as opposed to a mechanically based one. Playing something like this is not about winning or losing, it's about seeing what happens. Like many of these types of games, deliberately gaming the system can lead to degeneration (i.e.: stat bonus rooms) and winning and losing is not even on the radar, at least it isn't if you want to have fun.

I think the hardcore strategy only gamers will be non-plussed by this, but anyone looking for a great horror themed light weight game that would be easily teachable to the casual set while still being fun should check this out.  I must finally add that the one hour playtime is perfect for this kind of game, any longer and the game would likely feel monotonous, but with it the pace is just right.

All of this said, this is one of those "occasionally it sounds good" sort of things. I would be willing to play it again, but on the balance I have now filled this game niche with the more versatile Mansions of Madness 2nd Edition, as that game has a similar vibe but fits a wider variety of game lengths than this one and is less dependent on having at least 4+.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
I like the idea of this game a lot, and used to be a lot more into it, but it rarely turns out to be as fun as I hope it will.

I enjoy that the house is built randomly each game, and the RPG elements remind me of the original D&D boardgame, which has a special place in my heart.

The problem ultimately ends up being the special rules that some with the Haunt phase. They are often very vague, and the person who becomes the villain is therefore so confused we can't progress without everyone reviewing the rules, which gives away the villain's secret goals.

I do really enjoy all the creepy flavour text on the cards, and the items are really fun. I have been able to do some pretty awesome things, like throw a stick of dynamite behind me into a room full of opponents as I lunge through a doorway, safe, into the next room. That was a good game, even though I lost in the end.

I also dislike the black plastic markers that mark your player's stats because they inevitably slide everywhere, and lose their place.

6.5/10 for everyone's frustration with the Haunt rules
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

I _love_ how the game incorporates a distinct narrative arc with what is essentially a dungeon crawl.  I sort of _like_ the relatively crummy components because they remind me of original AH games- i.e., a zombie chit is a round counter with the word "zombie" in a plain font.  Old school!  Neat horror elements- Lovecraft, Dracula, black magic, demonic possession- it's nice to see a darker theme (that's not attached to some clunky game like Zombies) other than the usual Teletubbies-soft Eurogamer fluff.  I'm sure all the "Spielfrieks" will scoff at this one, because there is a lot of randomness (like all those trick-taking card games they seem to love) and the family un-friendly theme.  Bottom line- if you like the theme at all, you'll probably get a lot out of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

There are 50 haunts, each with different victory conditions and special abilities for both the Survivors and the Traitor. Thus, lots of replayability.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.45
A mostly cooperative game, Betrayal felt to me like Diet Arkham Horror Light.  Which isn't a bad thing by any means.  In this instance you still get a bit of the creepy factor, mounting dread, and fervent dice rolling.  While a bit more individuality in the characters would be nice, it's not a big part of the game.

I also like that you're watching the board develop before your eyes as players "explore" the haunted house and reveal new rooms.  The possible downside for hardcore gamers is the massive amount of randomness that's a hallmark of the game.  Which room you reveal next determines what event/object/omen you might face.  There are all those dice.  And to top it off, many different scenarios that determine who might be betraying the group and how.

It's quite a mess of mechanisms, but it makes for a tasty stew.  While I'll always prefer to play AH, a quick game of this one is an option I wouldn't turn down.

RATING: 2
To be honest, part of the reason I hate this game is because I have extended family that want to play this game EVERY time we get together it seems like for the last 5 years. The more I play it the more I don't like it. 

The game only gets interesting after the haunt happens. The first half of the game is seriously move to a random new area, flip a random tile, do what the tile says, roll a die, oh dear looks like a possessed doll stabbed you. Too bad. Next person. Repeat.

Even after the haunt happens, sometimes the person who is the "betrayer" is in a position that is so unbalanced its not even fun. I was the "betrayer" one game, and the other players defeated me and finished the game before it was even my turn again. The number of players never seems balanced. If you have too many players the "betrayer" is at a disadvantage, a small number of players and he/she is overpowered. 

I can honestly see why some people like this game. I sort of liked it at one point. It's one of those games that has random stuff happen, you all laugh, and then move on. There are better games that do that.

RATING: 6
Bought it because of the many positive ratings out there.  To me, it is fun, but not as awesome as BGG crowd feels it is.  

Here's the good:
1) Very cool theme.  
2) Like the multi-story outcomes.
3) Love how someone among you goes bad in the game.

Here's the bad:
1) It's so complex that it's confusing at times.  Actually, confusing at many moments.  Perhaps with a bunch more plays I would sort through it.  Not sure if I want to invest the time.
2) There are conflicting rules because of so many variations.
3) The many variations can lead to some boring combinations of powers/events.  If you are going to invest 60 minutes, the boring combinations should be RARE.  They weren't rare.  

It's not a horrible game, but I was expecting more.  I'll play it a few more times to see if I fall more in love.  Perhaps I will create a house rule to eliminate certain storylines that aren't as fun...

RATING: 7.6
It's the perfect game to play at a Halloween-themed game night. It's pretty much worth having in your collection just for that, especially if you can find it on sale. The game is best played for the experience, not winning or losing. Some of the haunts (scenarios) are wonky, but some are fantastic. It's uneven in that regard, but there are so many different scenarios that I can easily forgive it for the added replayability you get as a result.

I really like the sense of exploration that you get in the first half (or so) of the game. It's very evocative and fun, and, for me, it's the best part. My enjoyment usually decreases somewhat once the haunt begins. I just want to keep exploring, personally, but I understand you have to end the game somehow.

I do wish the components were better. I wish they would do a new edition or a deluxe edition which fixes some of the problems and improves the components, but I don't think that's likely to happen anytime soon.

RATING: 7
One of the best tributes to classic horror movies that I have ever had the pleasure to play; Frankenstein's Monster, Dracula, the Wolfman, the Mummy, Zombies, Evil Scientists, Pod People, enclosed puzzle boxes that will chop your head off... you name it and there is a Haunt in this game that features it.

The rules are a bit loose, in that one often comes upon situations that aren't quite covered in the rulebook(s) - but that lone complaint does nothing to prevent me from playing this snazzy game whenever it is requested.

A brilliant, yet 'sloppy' classic in the horror story-telling genre.  And one that I would recommend.

Claims 3-6 players, but can quite easily be played with 2.

RATING: 7.5
Oozes theme, this is a game that begs to have an entire themed night based around it.  Put some bad b-horror movies on in the background and you'll be set.  

The exploration part of the game is great and again really nails the theme with the various rooms and the events that can happen.  The bulk of the games occurs after the traitor is revealed; then you get all sorts of rules and special conditions added in and the end-game and winning conditions are defined.

My main issue is that the scenarios seem to be very vague at times and it can be tough to understand exactly what is intended, especially when there seems to be conflicting info in the traitor and hero books.  The random nature of the board setup means that a given scenario could be extremely balanced one time and completely tipped in someone's favor another.

The game isn't meant to be particularly balanced, just fun.  You can't take it seriously, but few games capture and invoke a theme like this.  Not something you'll probably play often but it's perfect for taking out from time to to have to have fun with.

RATING: 7
"The Cannibals are going to get you, Nick. We just need you to let them attack you so they can't get to the helpless victims."

"Wait, this house has no exit... the rooms go fully around the 'front door'... wtf!"

This game certainly has a great feel to it. There's the theme and the humor and cooperative feel. Every game is different and new. But it also seems to have a bit of problem with the randomness that makes the game different every time -- it can make the actual "game" portion of Betrayal quick and one-sided. If the Haunt comes at a bad time or on the second turn of the game b/c someone rolled all blanks, then there is no question who will win. And the game either ends before you got started or it ends completely anti-dramatically. The first two experiences I had with this game was the Blob auto-winning because it's Haunt started after Turn 2, and the Cannibals being stomped by the victims without even breaking a sweat. But I can see how this game has a lot of endless potential in it. And we had great hysterical times even though those two games fell flat technically.

RATING: 8
This game is a little silly, but the sheer number of different haunts makes for some serious re-playability.  There is also an equal amount of work expected from each player, which in my opinion puts this game significantly ahead of the similar mansions of madness which requires one player to sit out and organize the monsters.  Some may say the quality of paint on the miniatures is sub par, but I actually think it's pretty cool that all my characters have an African skin tone, though it doesn't really reflect the unfortunately mostly all-white casts of classic horror movies.  My only complaint is that it can be a little nerve wracking for first time players to be cast as the traitor.  But it's better than the alternative of one player having to sit out and manage.  That and the clips for the player stats are constantly falling off.  They need to be redesigned.

RATING: 6

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pros

Lots of replayability in the 50 haunts that the game has. It is a pretty random exploration game where you hope to power your character up instead of hurt your character prior to the haunt being revealed.

Neutral

Very much a medium weight game with small tactical choices. The semi-cooperative nature of the game can't be planned for so it is more of an adventure game than a strategy game.

Lots of the game is dependent upon random tile draw, card draw, and dice rolls. 

Cons

Cardboard quality is good but the art is a bit lacking and the character cardboard sheet is not of the most practical design.

Don't take this game too seriously and you'll have a decent amount of fun in about an hour to an hour and a half.

RATING: 9
+ Scooby Doo meets B-horror films
+ The prospect of having 50 different scenarios offers an unprecedented amount of replay-ability
+ Excellent writing for each of the haunts
+ With the predictability of each haunt being non-existent, the tension and necessity to explore and acquire as many items/stat boosts to prepare for any situation
+ The aforementioned will likely come back to bite you and require that you get assistance from your fellow explorers, or will simply hinder you more than help you
+ Rules are easy to explain, and the unique rules for each haunt are very well laid out and understandable

- The character stat trackers are useless because the plastic stat tracker piece that accompany them do not stay on the character tiles
- No official app or replacement pieces to deal with the above issue, but 3rd party apps are a-plenty and all work well
- While 50 different haunts are available, the likelihood of playing through all of them is low as there is no real way to control how/what haunt will occur

RATING: 7
A game in the same vein as Arkham Horror or other exploration/adventure type games where you pick a starting character and move him/her around the board getting equipment and prepping for the end game (which is the true meat of this game). It is at this point one of the players is revealed as the 'betrayer' and the haunt of the game is revealed and it becomes a competition between the betrayer and the other players.  50 haunts and a radomized way to determine who is the betrayer makes for different games everytime.  I like the production values in terms of look of the game and style of the art and such but this one suffers from poor editing and proofreading.  Butif you like this style of game do not let this discourage you.  Pick up the errata and use some common sense and this thing is utterly playable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A delightfully wicked survival game. Better with a group, this game takes all the tropes you'd expect from a horror film and puts the reins in your hands. The tension escalates with each new Omen and the haunt roll is almost always made with baited breath. The breadth of haunts and the variety of character and item combinations make for a frightfully good time with great replay value. Some scenarios favor different group sizes and some items and omens are way more powerful than others (I'm looking at you, Dog) but each playthrough has been unique for me so far.

Why this is not a 10:
-> Repeated play often yields the same rooms resulting in same-y exploration phases (Junk Room please stop)
-> Horror games aren't for everyone - I can personally only do a few

Unlike most people I do not really care much about theme--the game just has to be good, and Betrayal is good.

RATING: 5
A potentially fascinating haunted house themed game.  You know the story, stormy night, car breaks down, you see a creepy house on a hill and dash for shelter... players spend the first half the game exploring the house by flipping up tiles.  Tiles can appear on the ground floor, the upper floor or in the basement.  Room tiles often have event, item or omen cards in them to spice things up.  At some point in the game, an omen card will trigger the second half, where somebody turns traitor and a scenario is set to finish the game off.  The traitor/scenario selection is very ingenious, based on a two dimensional matrix of omen type/room that tripped the scenario.  A game that very retro in feel (remember Sorcerer's Cave, Dungeonquest, Talisman, etc?), but very fun.  The rules are clean, but some of the counters are a bit fiddly to find.  Tip - don't punch them until you need them!  Overall, you have to appreciate the labour of love this obviously was for the designer - good stuff.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An original horror board game. All players (the more the merrier) start at the entrance of the main doorway. The door shuts and the thriller unfolds. Everyone is trying to explore as many rooms as possible in this abandoned mansion. Random room tiles are placed by players during their movement thus having a ‘new’ mansion on every game.  After having discovered almost half the rooms, under specific circumstances, some dice are thrown. If you score the number needed the mystery starts. Based on the room tile the event occurred one player will become a traitor and try to kill everyone else and the rest try to solve the mystery while avoiding the traitor and if possible to redeem the possessed one i.e. traitor or kill him. Although there are many rules, with one game play everything is sorted out and play becomes thrilling! Items, amulets, weapons, minions, ghosts, trapped doors, secret doors; puzzle rooms, a mysterious elevator, a basement where you have to find the connecting exit to the mansion, more creepy stuff and lots of different mysteries to solve.

RATING: 7.5
This game is great starting out, love the mechanics and exploring the house. The layout of the house changes every time we play this. My group fully enjoys this game, that is, until we get to the haunt part of the game.

The haunt portion of the game just disrupts the flow, it needs a lot more work to naturally transition the pace of the game. Usually the game sits at a standstill until the betrayer reads the haunt book and tries to figure out what they are supposed to do, meanwhile the rest of the group is trying to figure out what they are supposed to be doing. 

On occasion, the haunt can be pretty fun for everyone, but usually everyone just becomes frustrated with it, unclear on what they are doing or how to stop the traitor. 

*The most fun i have had with this game was using the room tiles in a D&D style campaign.*

RATING: 8
A standard coop game with a traitor twist, don't take Betrayal too seriously.  The miniatures are poorly painted, the stat counters require paper wedged in them before they will stay in place, and much of the writing is laughable.  But beneath, or perhaps because of all of this is a light, thematic B-movie horror game which delivers a fun experience for newcomers or those looking to tilt a few and pretend like it makes sense that they inhaled grave dirt for the third game in a row.  Seriously I became a grave dirt asthmatic three games in a row and loved every minute of it.

The only draw-back I see is in the reprints where the tiles have a warping issue, which is problematic where a tile-laying game is concerned.
The original edition seems to be the same thickness of tile, yet no issue.  So, there comes a time when the reprint is no longer supported by Wizards of the Coast, the first edition may be coveted.

RATING: 6
Has the potential to be a huge hit as an "experience" game, especially with non-gamers, but it also runs some risk of falling completely flat, depending on which Haunt emerges from the game.   The box claims this is a "strategy" game...  but not really.   It's mostly random.  But it succeeds at telling a story and creating an atmosphere.   The only real strategy comes when the heroes decide how they are going to tackle their necessary tasks before the traitor can defeat them.   (Kudos to WotC for replacing the entire set of punchboards after the shockingly badly warped components of the intial print run!)   I've never really played a game that's quite like this one.  It stands apart.   I've enjoyed all of my plays so far.  Light, evocative fun.

RATING: 5

Again, few decisions are made other than optimizing the victory strategy already specified by the constraints of the scenario. Victory is also sometimes reliant on the luck of dice rolls.

RATING: 6.5
My tale is no different to the usual: I heard about this unique system, with tailored scenarios built around the concept of a member of the group betraying the rest. I eagerly picked it up - and within two or three games had realized just how broken the system is.

While you can have fun and crazy moments in many games, too often does the game collapse upon itself: the 'Haunt' (when the traitor is revealed and the victory conditions set) triggers, but is clearly evident that one side has already won, the rules aren't clear enough on the correct way to handle a situation, or some madness with the board layout results in a poor experience for one player.

Here's hoping this is all fixed in Betrayal Legacy!!

RATING: 6
Great theme in this game. The scenarios are many and varied. The game is slightly flawed mechanically, though, hence the slightly average rating. What you do in the first half seems to be only indirectly related to what happens in the second half. You can spend an hour exploring the house in the first half only to have the game end after only a turn or two in the second half. Quite a lot of luck, not a lot of strategy, so if it weren't for the great theme I'm not sure I'd play it much at all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My wife and I really enjoy the story telling aspect of this game and so far we have always enjoyed recapping the story after the game. Very fun game.

Edit. Lowered the game by .5. I still like the game, but sometimes the roll of the dice or draw of the cards can really throw the game. In my last game, Person A entered a couple rooms and ended up with 5 items while person B had no items throughout the game.

IMO, its a simple fun game to play with the not so serious or new gamers. Nice fun intro game when Ticket to Ride gets played out and people want more interactions and discussion. 

Edit 2: Played with new-ish gamers and felt bad because the endgame consisted of them giving me a weapon due to higher strength and killing the betrayer while for two turns they really didn't do anything. The game is highly variable so some plays might be dull while others are great, just be aware of that. But it can stink to play if for over an hour and have the game end with a whimper.

RATING: 6.5
I love the theme and the haunts (of which there are 50) are interesting and creative.  Where the game suffers is in component quality and balance.  The cardboard warping has been well documented but my biggest gripe are the little plastic sliders that go onto the character cards.  They are too big and side right off.  Additionally there is too much empty space between the pointer and the number which can lead to confusion.  In terms of balance, some omens or weapons give the player an extra dice (or 2!) when combat rolling.  Getting a perk like this (entirely by luck) can really throw the game.  I would rate the game an 8 because I love the experience but with those production problems and balance issues, I'm gonna have to give it a 6.5

RATING: 3
I was hoping the 2nd edition of this would be my thematic go-to game for when I have 4 players and am 1 person shy of being able to play Battlestar Galactica.  Sadly, it was not acceptable.  If you ask me Betrayal is damned if you do or damned if you don't:

The game is really light and seems to lack interesting decisions and tension.  Alternatively if they made the game rules more complex to allow for more decision-making then the scenarios would reflect that and the mid-game learning would be more horrible than it already is.

I really disliked how in you completely disconnect from the game right in the middle of the game you had to essentially 'learn the game' because objectives and special rules aren't revealed until half way through the game when 1 of the 50 scenarios are randomly determined.  Alternatively if you are familiar with the rules to a scenario then the game is less interesting because you know what to expect.

The components for the new edition have been detailed as pretty horrible due to the warping.  I also can't believe they introduced a hidden traitor element and want you to use markers that regardless of the monster type you choose they are all essentially marked because the tokens are different shades within their specific color/type.  Alternatively you can get the old edition, but then you would have errors on a tile or two (?) and have to update all of the scenario booklets because the first editions rules were even worse than they are now.  

My final complaint was that even with these updated rules there was still more ambiguity in them than I would have liked.  I'm so disappointed with this game.

RATING: 9
This game works relatively well as a traditional exploration/character advancement game, but really kicks into gear when it comes to the second part, where one player will be the evil traitor and the other players fight together to overcome one of 50 totally different evil scenarios. Some of them play like little wargames, others demand deduction and skill. Great fun for everybody involved, as the game really depicts the theme well, and the scenarios have been lovingly crafted to represent every imagineable haunted house story/cliché.The replay value is high, as the endgame is always different, but the exploration stays a bit samey. The game would profit from expansions, which could easily be integrated. Great design with wonderful atmosphere, easy to pick up, relatively short playing time - what doth the geek wanteth more?
