RATING: 7
I have a love-hate relationship with this game. When it works, it works great. When it doesn't, it feels clunky and poorly playtested.

The setup for the board is ingeniously worked into the game itself--players explore rooms and flip over tiles until one triggers the Haunt, which is the [i]real[/i] game. The scenarios are enjoyable and flavorful, but usually cause some rules confusion. The rulebook and cards are in need of a great deal of editing and streamlining.

Speaking of streamlining, there are too many tokens. TOO MANY. This is my biggest gripe with the game. Most haunts will use five or six tokens to represent ghosts or secret passages or weapons or what have you. But instead of making generic tokens labeled "enemy" or "item" that could be used in every scenario, the game includes a separate token for every single thing you'd ever come across. The game grinds to a halt whenever the Haunt begins as players dig through the piles of tokens to find the appropriate one, though smart (and frustrated) players will just grab the first available token and ignore what's printed on it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pros
--Absolutely fantastic with a group who's willing to delve into the theme.
--Unique game that can be a great gateway game
--Creates stories that can last for years.


Cons
--Very unbalanced, and I don't mean in terms of fairness.  Length is variable, betrayer vs. group can be very uneven in either direction, some scenarios are just outright better than others.
--Way too many nuanced rules for how simplistic the gameplay is.  Just a poorly written rulebook perhaps?

Overall, this game has grown on me.  At first I didn't like the wonky, loose mechanics, but I've grown to tolerate them.  This game is an absolute treasure if you're in the mood for it.

RATING: 6
Betrayal at House on the Hill quickly builds suspense and excitement as players explore a haunted mansion of their own design, encountering spirits and frightening omens that foretell their fate. With an estimated one hour playing time, Betrayal at House on the Hill is ideal for parties, family gatherings or casual fun with friends.

Betrayal at House on the Hill is a tile game that allows players to build their own haunted house room by room, tile by tile, creating a new thrilling game board every time. The game is designed for three to six people, each of whom plays one of six possible characters.

Secretly, one of the characters betrays the rest of the party, and the innocent members of the party must defeat the traitor in their midst before it’s too late! Betrayal at House on the Hill will appeal to any game player who enjoys a fun, suspenseful, and strategic game.

Betrayal at House on the Hill includes detailed game pieces, including character cards, pre-painted plastic figures, and special tokens, all of which help create a spooky atmosphere and streamline game play.

RATING: 5
A light, Ameritrashy game that must be played in the right mood with the right people so that you can at least have some laughs if the game goes off the rails in terms of balance. I don't think they were too concerned about playtesting the haunts for any semblance of balance; rather, it's a novelty game in the vein of Tales of the Arabian Nights. I'd play again if asked, but then again, if I don't ever play again I won't miss it. I actually find it more enjoyable than Tales or Arkham Horror, for that matter, since this provides a thematic experience of the horror genre with a fraction of the overhead and time required.

RATING: 6
This game has so much potential, and when you're playing with the right group, and get the right haunt, well, it can be a real blast, and will provide you with plenty of "Remember when.." moments that will be evocative for a long time. The key words there, unfortunately, are 'potential,' 'right group,' and 'right haunt.'
As you probably know, much of the game is flat-out broken, and there's nothing that kills a vibe quicker than getting a haunt that you simply cannot play. Errata abounds, and there is a revised haunt book online, but it's still not perfect.
Having the right group, I think, is an even bigger issue. If you don't have people who are going to get into the game, and really run with the theme and have a good time with it, then it can be quite the lifeless affair, as mechanically it's a very dull game.

RATING: 6.875
I love, love, love:
- exploring and revealing rooms to a house that's different every game
- the creative Haunt scenarios and different gameplay for each

I dislike:
- there aren't many Omens, Items, or Events, so there's a lot of repetition of seen cards by game three
- that the Haunts are so poorly explained that we always end up spending 15 minutes asking each other if we understand what's going on and at least one of us ends up checking BGG for answers

Final verdict: Love this game because the house set-up is always different and the Haunts all play so differently that it feels like we're getting multiple styles of games in one box. On the other hand, there needs to be more variety in cards and better explained rules for the Haunts.

RATING: 8
First off, let me say I am an owner of the first edition, not the revised one.

This game is great but you have to set it up correctly : it must be dark outside, put in some eerie music, dim the lights, fill up the glasses. The game is all about the immersive gloomy-horror experience. You will read text. Read it loud. And you need to be somewhat a good reader. Keep that in mind for your first game and warn everyone that it's not a «Spike» game.

Your adventure will have two parts - at first, you'll get into that strange mansion which you will explore. The tiles being independant, you're playground will be different everygame. Strange stuff will happen. You might not understand anything. That is alright. Nothing right can happens, right ?

That is until the second part - the revealing of the mission. Anything can happen, litteraly : there is over 50 differents scenarios that can happen - collaborative or not, with a traitor or not. That is the real fun begin, but be warned : in the first edition at least, some quests are NOT clear at all.

To sum it up : great experience, great replayability, well-paced BUT some quests are sometimes mixed up.

RATING: 10
Based on 25 plays.
+ One of the best games I've ever played.
+ This game provides good memories for a lifetime, as most role-playing games do.
> The game is at its best with people who are ready for a light role-playing experience.
> In my opinion, best with 5, 4 and 6 players, respectively. Haven't played with fewer players to avoid wasting good scenarios. The larger the crowd, the better the experience?
- You should download revised scenario booklets (in color here on BGG, by UniversalHead). Also, you should have some kind of chart in order to find appropriate tokens fast.
- The players must be able to make up rules for unexpected situations every now and them.

Updated 9->10 in 2011 after 25 plays. I've come to accept this game as it is, even with its major flaws. I still have a constant urge to produce custom stuff to this game: new scenarios and alternative Finnish translations (in addition to the one I already did).

Since 2007, updated Dec 2011

RATING: 10
An outstanding mix of co-op and competitive gameplay, with enough scenarios to ensure many enjoyable replays. This is one of my all-time faves.

My group has a house rule that I’d recommend: A first-time player can never be the traitor, but don’t tell them that unless the occasion arises that they should be, that way it maintains some suspense. We adopted this rule after a couple of games were...I don’t want to say ruined, because we still had fun...but definitely altered just because a first-timer trying to get their head around the scenario, win-condition, various tracking stuff, etc, didn’t go well for us. The situation seemed to favor the group over the traitor. Still fun, but less challenging for the group.

RATING: 7
The game I owe the most in all my collection. My thoughts on the subject can be read here, on Slate (http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/gaming/2015/11/betrayal_at_house_on_the_hill_and_the_golden_age_of_board_games.html).
I will add that it's delightful and fun and a great starter game for a collection. Wizards of the Coast has done a terrible job fixing errors and balancing the game (some haunts will haunt you for years). I suspect the new expansion won't change this as it only adds more, but hopefully the prospective game designers who wrote the new haunts did so with care and a keen eye. Only time will tell. Still, holds the highest place in my heart.

RATING: 6
A salesperson talked me into this one, but I hated the graphics on the box so much, couldn't open it--especially after I read mixed reviews.  So this was one of the first games I ever sold.  That was a couple of years ago.

Tonight I saw the insides of the box for the first time, and played it.  Wish I hadn't sold it.  A very good party-style game that eventually turns into a co-op/team game.  It is just the kind of game board I like--one that changes each time because you build it as the game progresses. Also, many different game scenarios included. 

And, the game graphics are much better and do not match the horrible, cheap, total turn off, box graphics.  

I purchased the new version, but the tiles are thin and so badly warped the figures won't stay upright on the tiles--huge disappointment. 
NOTE: Contacted Wizards of the Coast publishers, replaced immediately.  Obviously a guality company--admitted problem & fixed it.

I don't usually like co-op games, but this one is only co-op for about half the game, then someone betrays you - and no one, not even the betrayer, knows its going to be them ahead of time.  You explore an old haunted house, picking up artifacts, finding secret passages, suffering curses and illusions, or getting blessings.  Then at some point, that happens somewhat randomly, someone is assigned to basically get possessed by a demon and try to kill the rest of you.  There are 50 different betrayal scenarios, and the house builds randomly as you explore it, so its got good replay value.

Honestly, though, its a little creepy of a game.

RATING: 7

One interesting thing is that the board is always different: the board is made up of individual room tiles that are different each time. The ending is also different each time. I'm not sure how many endings/bad guys there are total, but you can play the game for years without having played all of them.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
True Ameritrash, with piles of randomness, stats that may or may not come into play, tiles, miniatures and custom dice, hidden powers and victory conditions, and lots of theme.

Duration: The game I played was pretty short; we kept it fast paced but supposedly it was the shortest the owner had played.
Design: I enjoyed the exploration, the traitor mechanic, and the variety of possible encounters. I liked that neither side had a good idea of what the other could do. The rules had massive gaps and I doubt they would produce a consistent experience. Lots of random things happened to the characters even during the exploration.
Strategy: This was cooperative when the traitor appeared, but we couldn't say anything that would give the plans away. Things happened quite randomly, so it was more of moving and rolling than of applying deep thought.
Components: Tiles, miniatures, character sheets with clips, custom dice, 3 decks of cards, and a million labeled tokens. There's a lot of stuff in there, and it did bring out the theme, though I wasn't a fan of the miniatures, the character design or the writing.
Theme: B-movie horror with a corresponding level of polish.

RATING: 6
Great concept, clunky implementation. There are 3 parts of Betrayal. Part 1 - Flip tiles, kinda interesting, ultimately dull. Part 2 - Sit around for a half an hour while the betrayer figures out what the hell he/she is supposed to do. Part 3 - Best part of the game, as everyone races to fulfill their victory conditions. Unfortunately the last and best part of the game is over way too quickly and can be subject to runaway players who got lucky in the early game. 

Would love to see an updated game based on this concept.

RATING: 1
First half - dead boring. Second half - broken (I feel justified using "broken" here - the sides after the Haunt begins are rarely well-balanced, and the badly-written rules, especially those dealing with the Haunt, compound the problem). Highly unsatisfactory, BatHotH fails both as a game AND as an experience. It's not fun, it's not suspenseful, and it's certainly not strategic. Did they playtest this thing at all? Don't even start with the "it's in the roleplaying" nonsense - this is not even in the same neighborhood as CoC or Kult, proper "horror RPG"s. Theme? It's no better than any other game, and no theme in the world will save a broken game. And I'm not even complaining that it's random (dice and tiles and cards, hello) because you don't expect non-random games from Hasborg's kiddie division. Avoid like it's the zombie plague and you're its lunch. *** UPDATE: This is the worst piece of crap that anyone tried to pass off as a boardgame in 2004. The rules are unusable out of the box, and the only people who seem to enjoy it only do so because they've never experienced anything better in the horror RPG genre. I deny that this thing is a game, because it not only has abysmal balance, it has no working rules. That stupid "make up your own rules" disclaimer only works in REAL roleplaying games, morons, NOT in boardgames. Whoever greenlighted this at Hasbro/Avalon Hill/WOTC should be very, very ashamed. Oh, and at that price point, they should be able to produce something that at least rivals Ravensburger games like Java and Tikal. The shoddy bits only make this an even bigger horror story for the boardgaming populace. Do NOT buy this thing that's masquerading as a game.

RATING: 8
Played my first game of this today (7-16-2011) with Mr. Billington and Gayle.  I ended up the traitor (Haunt #45, the bomb-maker) and lost the game when Mr. B's character killed mine. Again Gayle rolled the start of the haunt.  This time Gayle and I won and Mr. B lost (but we all liked the game better than last time).  2 and 1/2 hours for a second game, including setting up.  I think, though, that this will be it for this game for awhile, since I don't want to overplay it.  I want it to stay interesting and fun.

RATING: 9

Get away!").  The winner ended the first game one move away from losing.  ONE MOVE!  It made for a great intense finish.  OH!  One other thing that knocks it down to a '9' from 10 -- one scenario we played called for a certain character, and there was no token to represent it.  The thing has three hundred and ninety eight million tokens, you'd think there's be one for every situation!  We just used a random one.  They might as well not even label them.  That was frustrating.  But, again, the game is cool.

RATING: 5
The more players the better and longer the game is. You don't want this game to last too long though... uggg. It's also hard to find the pieces you need for each scenario. Completely overshadowed by Arkham Horror for the best spooky game title. 

I used to have this at a 7, but with Arkham in my collection there hasn't been a need to get this out again. It's been fun though, I have a few fond memories from the scenarios.

In one game, one of my friends kept opening up a cabinet that has you draw a random encounter card. "AHH! Spiders! *slams door shut and opens it again* Ahhhhh FIRE! *slams door shut and opens it again* Aggghh ghost!"

In another game, a giant worm was slithering around the house and the person playing the athlete, amidst all the other players that were slowly being defeated, heroically saved the day with luck, preparation, and daring. 

In 2015, I think I'm ready to sell this game. It doesn't have mechanics or a story as interesting as others. Sold in 2016.

RATING: 7
How did it take me this long to finally play this absolute gem of a game?  The bits are lovely (pre-painted minis) and the game is immersive and incredibly thematic.  Mechanically the game is simple and easy to learn.  The variety of haunts makes it highly replayable.  One play in and I am hooked for the reprint.

Update:  Just got the 2nd Edition reprint.  My tiles are all warped pretty noticeably within hours of being punched.  I don't think it is the humidity, its the fact that they used cheap, thin cardstock.  The game is great and certainly still playable.  I wish they wouldn't have cheaped out on the materials.  The new haunt we played was smooth going and seems to be a great update of the the game overall.

Update Feb 2011:  WOTC replaced the cardboard and all is well.  The game plays great and is a hit with non-gamers.

Includes: Widow's Walk expansion

Betrayal is beyond a dice-fest, but I think it works thematically, adding tension to encounters.  There are still meaningful decisions throughout, but it's not exactly high-strategy.  

Betrayal lives and dies on the group playing it.  I find reading the omen cards is one of the highlights of the game, and a critical component of building the atmosphere that any horror-based game should have.  With the some of the groups I've played this with, they just rush through the cards, focusing on the effects rather than the story. The other aspects that make this game worth playing is building the house as you explore and hauntings (particularly the diversity).

RATING: 6
I've played this game many times over the years, it usually comes out around Halloween. I enjoy the thematic of the game and the way things unfold, especially once the haunt starts. The haunts are both the strong part of the game and the weak.

Pro - Tons of replayability. You never quite know what's going to happen and what kind of game you will be playing. Highly thematic

Cons - The rules can suck. This is really hard to fix since the traitor has their own rules/goal and the rest of the players have theirs. But you aren't suppose to know what the other person can do so rule mistakes/oversights happen a lot along with unclear rules. Also some haunts are super easy and others are impossible, very swingy. Also it can be really hard for non gamers to be the traitor and read the rules


I think the best way to play it (if you have someone willing to do this) is to have a moderator person that can help assist with the rules and make sure both sides are doing things correctly. My rating for this game would go up if they could just fix up the rules for each haunt to make things very clear

RATING: 9
This game is absolutely amazing with the right group of people. It has a ton of great RP opportunities without having to require someone to write up a campaign and deal with stats and combat in any real demanding way. If you like board games and you like roleplaying, this is an excellent game.

However, it does have it's problems, but none of which really detract from it's score.

* The event, omen, and item cards will grow a bit tiring after a few games. There aren't many of them and you won't get many surprises once you've played more than 2-3 times.

* The game doesn't really start until the "haunt" begins. Before that it's primarily exploration and reading events, omens, and items mentioned above. Before then, it's entirely luck of the draw and doesn't have any skill or strategy to speak of.

* The game is heavily cooperative, and if you don't have a group that works well together I can see you having a really bad time once the haunt begins.

That all being said, none of those problems matter once the haunt begins. There are 50 scenarios and it will take a long time to go through all of them. Each scenario makes one player the "traitor" who has a goal that ranges anywhere from killing everyone, to filling the house with monsters, to trying to complete some secret task known only to them. This will range from seeking out certain rooms to perform tasks in, collecting items, or killing the traitor before they complete their own task. The rest of the players have their own secret task they must work together towards in order to win. During the haunt, the game becomes a 1 vs Many dungeon crawler RPG, and it's an absolute blast.

Feel free to message me if you're curious about the actual scenarios. I can't really go into more detail without spoiling anything.

RATING: 8
Betrayal at House on the Hill is one of the few games that got me into board games a decade ago. Combining RPG elements, co-operative gameplay, tile exploration and a betrayer mechanic with unique end-game scenarios, there was nothing else like it at the time. Even though I've owned this game for a decade, I still haven't played through all 50 scenarios, even though it has made it to the table dozens of times!

It is worth noting that most of the scenarios are horribly balanced in one way or another (and that overall the game suffers from balance issues), but this is a game that you play for the collective storytelling experience, and in that regard, it succeeds masterfully.

This used to be my go-to game for friends that were new to gaming and it still holds a fond spot on my shelf, but these days we are more likely to play Mansions of Madness, which clearly draws so much inspiration from Betrayal, but polishes so many of its rough edges.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The betrayal aspect of this game is quite neat. I can see playing this with a wider group of players so that gives this one a plus. I do wish the game had better quality components.

RATING: 6.5
Originally I had this at 8 and recently dropped it to a 7. Mechanically, the game is merely average, but it is dripping with theme. My one complaint is that you can trip the haunt very early in the game almost unfairly. Once, I played it with my wife and another couple and we tripped the haunt when the first omen was revealed because my wife rolled all blanks. That created a bit of a chaotic finish as nobody had any special items or cool cards to play out the rest of the game. While I understand that the odds of this are remote, it's still a flaw in the design. You shouldn't have to roll for the haunt until at least a few omen cards have been revealed, that way at least some/most of the mansion will have been exposed. On this particular occasion, I think only 2-3 tiles had been revealed! This one will probably go back up to an 8 around Halloween.

RATING: 9
Fantastic game. I played this regularly with two seperate roommates, neither of whom was particularly fond of board gaming but who both loved this. The rules are simple to understand, and the traitor mechanic provides enjoyment for everybody, even when the scenarios are unbalanced.

Despite the game's "Minimum Player" settings, we were able to fully enjoy the game with two players, perhaps because imbalances weren't actually a major issue to us. In fact, I find it tends to slow down a bit after the haunt starts if we have more people. A great casual game. Taking it too seriously will tarnish the overall experience, so put aside your need to dominate for this one.

RATING: 6
Matt's (He has a ton more plays with his family too)

Dice rolling (Output randomness) and random exploration don't have me very enamored with this. The absurd replayability with different haunts/layouts is nice, but I don't know if it saves the fact that I'm lukewarm on the core mechanics. Having some haunts with random traitors/turning into the traitor midway through this game has a very awkward "competitiveness" to it: You spend the first half not caring about your fellow players, and then the second half being unsure of how trustworthy they really are.

Strategy/thought is almost entirely unnecessary for this game, it's usually obvious what you should do on your turn. Theme is well executed and the game is low enough weight for more casual gamers to understand and enjoy, but I might tend for something more raucous/non-competitive like Galaxy Trucker.

RATING: 2
Lots of dice, so no surprise that it's not exactly my toe of game.  Not a bad concept... co-operative exploration of a haunted house, until the Bad Thing happens and one of the adventurers turns into a Monster!  Could be fun with the right crowd if yo like to read out the event cards in full, including flavour text.

The rulebooks for the Monster and the Heroes about how to play the rest of the game are annoyingly complicated and interrelated.  How much can you share with each other?  If you're unsure of a rule as the Monster, you can't show the rulebook to the Heroes or you'll give things away!  That could be a problem in some game groups.

After a second play, I decided that I never want to play this again.  The rules really are complicated (there are three rule books and lots of text on item cards) and you have to trust that the monster gets the rules right, because the heroes can't read those rules.  And furthermore, if a player dies, they have nothing to do but wait for the end.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My feelings on Betrayal are mixed.  I've played two sessions so far, one where I was the betrayer and one where I was the hero.  Our group tends to like cooperative play more so than competitive, so the person who is singled out to be the villain might not have as much fun as the other players.  However, I think it would all depend on whom you play it with.  This game requires a group of people to be dedicated to the game and to be paying attention.  

I wish the rolelpaying aspect was a little stronger.  With so many scenarios that are possible, it didn't really feel like one was any different than the other.  Sure, there are different win conditions, but it seems like that's where the players get tunnel vision.  By the time the haunt happens and is set up.. players are eager to end the game as fast as possible.  It has no time to breathe and for people to get lost in it.  

Don't get me wrong, I would still play this any chance I get - there are just a few nagging issues that I wish were improved.  Also, be prepared to struggle and fight against the sliders on your character cards.  They're terrible.  You're better off making your own markers, or better yet - using a sheet of paper.

RATING: 5
I feel like my enjoyment of Betrayal diminishes every time I play it. After so many playthroughs, the event cards, exploration, and haunt scenarios feel repetitive and lose their appeal, which is a shame since the strongest element the game has going for it is its theme. Many of the haunt scenarios aren't entirely balanced or are just plain confusing, which makes for an awkward second half where we're more concerned about playing the game correctly than actually enjoying it. Friends who don't own it love it and always ask to play, but I just can't seem to get into Betrayal like I used to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
The game starts out as a co-op with everybody exploring the house, and eventually (when enough omens showed up and the die rolls for it), one of the players will become a traitor. Since nobody knows in advance who that traitor will be, the dynamics of that first phase are interesting as well, and due to the tile laying nature of the exploration, the playing field for the second stage will be different every time, with bottlenecks and open areas.

I really like how due to the many different scenarios, you never know in advance what you'll get with this game. All you do know in advance is that eventually, everybody will have to fight the traitor.

What is a bit odd are all the chits and pieces that look the same (triangles, squares and pentagons) and have different meanings based on their text, that could have been streamlined a lot.

On the other hand, there actually are individual tokens for each of the type of monster or whatever that show up in the scenarios (spider tokens, bug tokens, alien tokens etc. etc.), I guess that is a plus. Bagging them however is a must.

A little downside maybe (making it more casual friendly though) is that the game involves quite a bit of dice rolling and lucky draws for tiles and cards. Strategy is less important than the experience of exploring a haunted house here.

RATING: 8
1-2-11
Looking back on my first few plays of this game, I wanted to like it more than I did because we had some laughs and some fun, but the lack of control holds me back from doing so.  Basically, my character did next to nothing in the games I played.  We almost won one of them simply because of the Dark Dice item, the most overpowered, gamebreaking card to put in this type of game.  The second game was very random in how things went down and I lost simply because I switched sides a turn early.

Random is the problem with this game.  You search random rooms for random cards and random events, which ends up in a random set of properties called the 'haunt' to give some victory conditions, where you finally have some control and some direction in what you're doing.  However, if your character was crippled by random events previously or is super powerful, that pretty much decides the pecking order of the endgame.  Similar to Tales of the Arabian Nights, it's more of a tabletop story, and less of a game.

Certainly it can be fun, but without any real control of your character, its novelty wears off fairly quickly.

RATING: 10
Moreso than Arkham Horror, this game is more of a roleplaying game than a boardgame. I would say that having a Gamemaster as a player is a definite plus. As such, gamers who aren't into RPGs will likely balk at the scenarios' imbalances. In an RPG, no one even considers questions of play balance, winning, or losing -- the play of the game is the only important thing. BaHotH plays incredibly smoothly and is suitable for non-gamers and Roleplayers alike -- as long as a Gamemaster is present to adjudicate. Admittedly, the extensive errata is a drag, but that hardly makes this game unique. I've noticed that most of the criticism levelled at this title are from gamers who are focussed on competition -- who wins and who loses is important to them -- clearly the mark of folks who don't play RPGs. To those who simply play games to have fun, this is a true gem. Folks who enjoy old horror movies will feel right at home.

Regarding the 2nd edition:

What did the little birdie say?

"Cheap cheap cheap cheap..."

The room "tiles" are printed on super-thin card stock that began warping as soon as I removed them from the shrink wrap. Probably less than half the thickness of the first edition tiles.

Sure glad I kept my first edition copy, since I'll be using its room tiles, character templates, tokens, and basically every scrap of card stock in the game.

Component quality of the second edition is extremely disappointing...

Tengo que ser honesto con esta opinión. Solamente lo he jugado dos veces y en ninguna fue la experiencia completa.

En la primera ocasión no tuvimos tiempo suficiente, a pesar de haber jugado algunas cartas de augurios, no hubo traidor. En la segunda vez, el traidor no leyó bien el instructivo del traidor por lo que los sobrevivientes tuvieron una noche demasiado difícil y terminaron perdiendo.

Espero poderlo jugar bien la próxima vez, con tiempo de sobra y sin malinterpretaciones.

RATING: 8
A very cool "atmospheric" game, best played at night by candlelight with one of those haunted house records spinning in the background.  Replay value seems high at first glance (50 different scenarios!) but in reality the card text, while chilling the first time around, gets old with later plays.  My advice:  don't take it seriously (it's far too random for that) and play it as a party game.  Once a year, on Halloween.  In the dark.

[b]After 11 plays:[/b]  As of November 2013, all of them in darkness and firelight, with that goddamn piloerecting spooky soundtrack—[i]A Night in a Haunted House/A Night in a Graveyard[/i] (1992)—whose sound effects invariably, eerily, line up with the action.  Never playing it during the day or in artificial light makes the whole affair rather... [i]mysterious[/i].  Straining to read cards with a candle in the fist really adds a lot to the proceedings.  Even now, in the happy shine of morning, I feel a vague unease upon catching a glimpse of the box...

[q]Highlights from the last couple years:

• Once the traitor was revealed, he didn't want to go into the other room to read his plot synopsis.  He was too freaked out—and we're talking about a grown-ass man here.

• My little dog had worked her way under the table and into the forest of our legs without anyone noticing.  The toll of a bell on the soundtrack made her bark and everyone at the table simultaneously leaped out of their skins and crapped their pants.[/q]
UPDATE OCT 2016:  Picked up a copy of 2nd Ed. for component-matching with the upcoming expansion as I have no confidence that the 12-year-old OG printing will line up [i]at all[/i] (cardstock and card sizes will, no doubt, be [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/3066908/hivegod]radically different[/url]).  I've heard they've rejiggered some of the haunts, not that this was ever a problem for us as we're RPGers first and quickly adjudicated any rules weirdness with the wave of a hand.  I do like the severe reduction in tokens, however, and the use of generic markers instead of having to search through a giant pile for the single "eyetooth of a penitent murderer" by candlelight while the narrative tension sags to the floor...  Though it must be said that I miss the Underground Lake in the attic (an accidentally thematic misprint in the original) and the twin "Image in the Mirror" event cards where one had actual mirror-imaged text.

[imageid=3348136 small]
[size=7]Fig. 1 — [i]♫ DING DONG ♪[/i][/size]

[filepage=143027]So You're a Traitor! pamphlet[/filepage]

FINAL ANALYSIS:  Parallel-universe me (the one with the evil goatee) would probably give this an unreserved 10!! (with two exclamation points) because 1) he's cool with the excitement graph having both peaks [i]and[/i] valleys on it and 2) because he's slightly stupid when it comes to exclamation points.*  Variability makes or breaks the experience—on the one hand this means no two games are alike; on the other it means sometimes the climax is more denouement.  The question, always, is will [i]this[/i] haunted house configuration make for a thrilling contest, or one that's impossible (or otherwise unfun) for one side?  There's only one way to find out...

[size=7]*One for shouting, three for comic effect; two if you're a moron, and "like a [i]ton[/i]" if you're a tween girl.[/size]

RATING: 9
Betrayal like being able to sit down and play a tabletop role-playing game without all the fuss of preparation of someone having to be the GM. This is an atmospheric and creepy co-op exploration thriller which flips and becomes a competitive game of survival at the halfway point. With 50 different scenarios there's a huge amount of replay in this game.

Only downsides: characters with slower speed tend to have less fun in the first half of the game as they can't explore as far as other players. The default miniatures in the game, while functional are far less attractive than miniatures in other games. All require a decent repaint or replacing with other 25mm figures, if you're fussy about such things. Also, due to the random nature of the tile layout, sometimes the traitor/hero challenge is unbalanced.

RATING: 9.5
Betrayal probably scores only a 6.8 due to terrible, terrible production quality - warped cardboard tiles! But, I still would purchase the game - it's simply amazingly fun and incredibly well designed, warped cardboard aside.  Also, extremely high replayability.  You play the part of one of up to 6 explorers searching a Haunted House, at some random point in the game (based on dice rolls with increasingly higher odds as the game develops), a "Haunt" happens - that's when one of the explorers may become a traitor and things go awry!  It has different scenarios - from digging up a hidden treasure in the house, to attempting to kill a Mummy, to trying to return the house back to your own dimension. (And of course, zombies, werewolves, and vampires!)

RATING: 4
This a really fun game to play. Almost everything about the game is random each time you play, the house will unfold different for each play as well as what items and events will occur per game. 

Due to this randomness, sometimes the haunt can be extremely in favor, or against the traitor making for some underwhelming games, but there are few and far between, so most times you will have a good game. The game also suffers due in part of the component quality of the game from Wizards of the Coast/Avalon Hill. The cardboard used is very cheap and can start to warp after only a bit of time. A real shame on WotC part. Also, the game is 10 years old so doubtful this will receive any type of expansion/support. Still the game has 50 unique haunts each with weirdly different win conditions for both sides. A good game hindered mostly from component quality and the chance of a poor game happening, which seems to be the outcome as of late. We've had some terrible haunts occur that has caused our game group to just put the game away and switch to something else.

I'm hoping the new expansion will bring some much needed life back into this one. 

UPDATE: After my most recent, and possibly last playing of this game, I lowered my rating to a "4". After so many plays the events get boring, the game loses its luster since it is so themed. But the game overall is not exciting and recently hearing the expansion does absolutely nothing to fix the broken parts of this game really hurts its rating as well. I feel that the designers are content in keeping it that way, since it fits the "c-movie" horror feel. 

Betrayal at Baldur's Gate looks to be the game that completely replaces House on the Hill. Hoping none of the rules and same design mistakes plague that game. Still, I wish Mansions of Madness 2nd edition wasn't another Cthulhu-themed game and more generic horror themed. How cool would that have been?

Update(er?) Wow so Baldur's Gate seems to add nothing new to the mechanics, just a component re-theme. Plus they still kept those retarded pentagons to track stats! Why, oh why?

RATING: 5
Interesting two-stage game of a group trapped in a haunted mansion.  In the first stage, the group explores the house, which is created by placing randomly drawn room tiles.  At some point a random scenario is created, and one player (the bad guy) is split from the rest of the group.  Great idea, but the execution boils down to the quality of the scenarios, which in both of my plays was not great.  In particular, I didn't care for the fact that the players are secretly playing from two different scenario books, using two different sets of rules.  The first clue that I had that the other players were winning the game was when they told me they had won.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Would be rated higher if it wasn't so uneven. Some parts are excellent. The tension of one person having secret goals that the other team may not know about is very entertaining. I also enjoy the kind of schlock horror movie aesthetic, and that you can see the callbacks to horror media.

On the whole though, it has too many warts for me to look past. The sheer amount of random chance is too punishing. There is player elimination, and not the satisfying type. The different haunts can be hit and miss, and sometimes the writing is so confusing that you end up with completely different interpretations of how you are even supposed to win the game. On top of that, the production value is absolute trash. Pieces are warped, tokens are half-assed, you get the picture.

I have had games that were fun, and tense, and creepy. I've also had games that had all the tension of a wet fart, and ended about as quickly. In a way, it's the perfect send up of horror as a genre. Occasional strokes of brilliance, buried in a deep deep morass of cheesy jump-scares and bad effects.

RATING: 4
Take heed the comments that claim this is only half of a game. Actually, it's probably even less than half. The first "part" of the game is a monotonous chore devoid of any meaningful player interaction, input, or choice. Nothing happens unless someone "explores" a new room, and so really the only option is to explore new rooms, and wait for the actual game to start. There are no tasks to accomplish, no advantageous positions or setup to try and guide the game towards, no strategy. Basically the first part of the game could be boiled down to "elongated setup, and stuff may or may not happen to you." Even if things happen, it is basically just the game telling you what to do in order to get to the "real" game.

Once the actual "Haunt" phase started, the game was  pretty fun (although the necessary break in gameplay to go read a new set of rules is terrible). The haunt phase brings with it goals, and enemies, and a sort of soft time limit to keep things moving. Players all can make decisions solo, or at the suggestion from other players to help or hinder their goal in the haunt. Player elimination is a bit of a problem, negated slightly by the mechanic that people have the potential for turning sides during the haunt instead of dying instantly. However, perma-death is still an issue in this game. 

I don't feel the fun I had playing the second part of the game makes up for the relative lack of a game in the first part. It's ok, but certainly nothing spectacular. 

A game with a lot of interesting ideas, but for the most part they are poorly executed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I WANTED TO LIKE THIS GAME!  It is such a great concept, and has such great potential for replayability.  You go into a creepy old house.  The tiles are placed as you explore.  The artwork is great.  There are multiple scenarios for what happens to you in there...  Genuinely creepy and intriguing every time!

But, especially for such a good concept, it's a pretty big hassle. 

The rules and instructions on many of the cards are badly written.  There are some fixes online, but there are too many to keep up with.  You eaither have to mark up your cards, or keep a large list of the fixes handy.  

The first part of the game is spent wandering through the house trying to build up your stats and weapons.  After a few plays, this can get boring, because you'll be so familiar with the "event" deck.  More event cards would have made this much more tolerable.

Another problem is, that when "IT" happens in the house, there are different possibilities to what chases after you.  This begins the part of the game we call... "THE LOOKENING".  You have to look for something like 15 chips of "zombies", or 5 chips with the word "mummy" on them... out of a pile of 75 or so.  There is no artwork to help you (The text is color coded, but it doesn't help, really). 

Another result of this, is that when you're running away from let's say, a bear...  you're actually not.  You're running away from a chip with the word "bear" on it.  The only thing scary about that chip, is that you and all your bored friends just spent half an hour digging through the bag of chips looking for it.  Sometimes we just write "bear" on a post-it note.  *sigh*.

I'm not saying they should include 75 miniatures, but COME ON!  How about some artwork?  On BOTH sides (to shorten "the lookening").
________________________

So, in summation: this is one of the coolest games I own.  Too bad my friends and I can't stand to play it.  It has a lot of potential, and all these things could be fixed pretty easily in a future release... if it wasn't an "Avalon Hill" game.  And if Avalon Hill wasn't owned by Hasbro Mega Corp.  OH WELL, guess it won't be re-released anytime soon.  Tough luck!

RATING: 6.5
Exploration:co-op:modular board: dice:rpg

Very cool themed game where you are exploring a haunted house and you do not know who/what is haunting it until it progresses. The absolute best part of the game I thought is that one of the players randomly becomes the 'monster' and tries to kill eveyone else! 

Not without faults, player elimination (not too bad as game should last an hour but it is there) and a lot of dice chucking, also very light with limited strategy but that last stuff is to be expected. 

Good things include lots of flavoured text, modular board, decent variety especially endings, characters not upgradable but do have 4 stats, somewhat easy to pick up and play and scales decent (3 - 6 decent but maybe 4 or 5 best)

A decent and fun light little romp in the house that I would play again, if you like this and want more detail see Arkham Horror

RATING: 7.6
10/27: This was a first time playing the game. Since it was Halloween time, we figured to go ahead and learn the game.

It took us a minute to notice that the rule book is more of a guideline for the flow of the game. Everything else was listed during the game. The order play and what a player can do is about what the rule book does for somebody. The tiles and cards are what determines the game at that moment.

I've found the first half the game kinda boring with just trying to improve the character. The fun of the game is the haunt. The tone of the changes dramatically when this occurs. We are now in the action phase of the game. Death becomes real as we learned through our first haunt. Yes, the good guys lost.

Overall, we wanted to play this game again.

11/3:  This was the second time we played the game. We enjoyed this around of play more since we weren't encumbered with learning the rules.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An old favorite of the group.  Loads of theme and atmosphere!  Coop game where you are exploring a very haunted mansion.  You can add one more room tile a turn.  You're trying to load up on goodies before a dice roll triggers the second part of the game, which is where one of the players (usually) turns out to be an evil betrayer!  There are fifty different such scenarios and you don't know which you are in till it happens.  They are often rather poorly written, causing confusion, but they are all fun and imaginative.  Folks will often rehash particularly amusing sessions for months afterwards, like with a good roleplaying game session.  It's very luck-driven and many of the scenarios are wildly unbalanced towards one side or the other so you have to play it with a tongue-in-cheek attitude.  If you play it enough times, you start knowing all the cards, unlike Arkham Horror where there are too many to know them all.  This desperately needs an expansion or two.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
This is one game in my collection that my friends are always asking to get out and play.  It's an enjoyable foray into the horror genre where you and your friends enter and explore a scary mansion only to find out that one of those friends is actually a traitor in disguise who has invited you there for less than noble purposes.  With over 50 different random scenarios (haunts) and  a mansion built from randomly placed tiles that you uncover as you explore, this game has a lot of replayability.  And replay it you will.  This is a great game to introduce newer players into board gaming and one of the most fulfilling aspects is seeing the broad smile on their faces as the traitor and scenario is revealed.  

Now that isn't to say this game is a perfect one for all gamers.  While there is strategy to this game, randomness in the encounters you face and the stats you gain while adventuring will cause imbalance during the haunt phase, much of which you will have very little control over especially if you roll poorly.  So hardcore strategic gamers or eurogamers may find this game lacking.  But I also think that isn't quite the point of a game, a game in which you are immersing yourself as a character from a B movie, and a horror one at that.  A genre where not everyone gets to be the hero, makes the right decisions, or survives against the seemingly impossible odds.  Where sometimes the most heroic action for your weak character is serving enough of a distraction to give your stronger teammates that one extra turn they need to win.  And in this way, this game is always different as sometimes you're the weak player playing against an insurmountable foe, sometimes you're the strong hero who vanquishes the ultimate evil, and sometimes you are the powerful traitor doing all you can to destroy the people you considered friends only a few minutes prior.  This is a tremendously fun game that hits its peak when the players immerse themselves in the theme.  And when it does hit that peak, you keep coming back for more.

Final Rating: 9.5/10  (loses a half point for the loose fitting stat markers)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This comment is for the first edition of the game.

2013-03-12

Initial Rating: 7.0 (July 2010)

Betrayal at House on the Hill (First edition) was one of the first games I ever played and I really liked it at that time, however, since I have played many more games, this game doesn’t appear to me as good as it was before.

Still a fun game to play from time to time. The game has a huge replayability as each scenario is different, however for the same reason the game has a limited life span as the scenarios are limited and I would not want to play the same scenario twice. I really like the traitor mechanic. The game forte is the theme and narrative, it is hard for us to play sometimes because many friends doesn’t understand English and the game has a lot of text. The traitor has to understand English perfectly or he can ruin the game. Also the game has a lot of randomness in many levels but as I don’t take seriously the game, I don’t mind much. 

The components are pretty good and I generally was entertained by the game. I want to play it every two months or so. Good game to introduce non gamers to the hobby. 

Current Rating: 6.0

RATING: 7
Fun. Really, it is. The rules are a bit loose and I don't think it's all that bad as the game is suppossed to be loose too. The errata is needed for the haunts though and that does lower the ratings a bit. With those points made, and they really do need to be noted, the theme in this game is incredible and carries it a very long way; It's almost every horror film in a box. I, almost, tend to think of this a seasonal game (Halloween) and not one to play into the ground, but to bring out when the mood strikes and the group is up for it.

I do like it and it's fun to play, but the group needs to "have fun" with it. If you have a mess of stuffy players it may not go over well. You have to bring energy to it and laugh or it's really just a game of lay a tile, move, and roll. That's what all games are though in the end. 

This is not a 'dry' game in my mind...it 'drips' atmosphere and it's fun. What was that? Did you...? The house! The house is...what? the walls? what's in the walls?!  THE WALLS!! CAN YOU NOT HEAR THE WALLS???!! Hey relax sweetheart, relax...it's ok...there's nothing in the walls...just kind of lost my head there for a sec'....what? Oh don't get all prissy 'bout it; I mean, I'm only mostly dead right? This part ain't rotted yet...well, that's a bit over ripe I grant.... and, well, the house says I needs a bride; so, how's 'bout it? THAT's theme.

RATING: 7
Played several times so far, Love the game for the most part... it feels like a dumb-down version of the Arkham series games without being able to be lost in time and space for eternity...

What I like:
The dungeon crawl into unknown spaces and element of finding loot along the way is amazing, if you like imagining a haunted mansion and crawling through the rooms one by one, this is a fantastic effect. 
It is indeed suspenseful as a haunted mansion should be!
Super great Tiles and explorers for the game, Like the cards... would love to have more of a backstory to what lead this random party to exploring this house. 
the mechanics of character stats. 

What I do Not like:
I don't love the haunt mechanics. The dice are a must, but need to be more... well just more. I feel like the story needs more of a story, and after the haunt there needs to be an epic climax and well.. there really isn't... it's kinda like... "Ok... do we win? or does the Haunted? Cool... What's next" there's virtually no Epic battle with the haunted or limited game interaction after the climax of the haunt. 
The rulebook and the haunted going to figure out the role he/she will soon play - this just feels awkward. it was a co-op adventure/exploring game and now it's a plot between one of the explorers and the rest... with limited interaction and about 5 mins of figuring out what and how to do it... there needs to be more thought, more play and just overall a more epic battle to see what will become of the explorers and their haunted Foe. 
Wish there was an option to save the insane friend. 
The Mechanics post haunt are pretty not fascinating. 
I feel like I only got Half a game experience. 

Overall I give it a 7 for fun factor of the dungeon crawl. 3 star dock to the lack of post haunt play or an epic ending which will forever be burned into our memories as a Haunted encounter should be!

RATING: 4
The best part of Betrayal is the horrific imagery it paints via event cards. As you explore the house, each room can hold an event, and each event comes with its own flavor text. Let your imagination run, because that's the only source of fun in this game.

The characters are thin, consisting of a few attributes and some window dressing in the form of interests that have no effect on the game. The challenges presented by the event cards are nothing more than stat rolls against your character's attributes. Roll well and receive a boost. Roll poorly and suffer a penalty.

The game is divided into two parts: pre- and post-haunt. During the pre-haunt phase, the players explore the house and discover rooms containing event, item, and omen cards. The rooms are revealed randomly, so there is no incentive to choose one direction over another. Each character has a speed trait that allows them to move a number of spaces each turn, but their turn ends upon encountering any of the aforementioned cards, effectively nullifying the importance of that trait.

After a number of turns, the haunt will trigger. At this point the game grinds to a halt as the players are instructed to read a special section in two separate manuals (one for the newly-appointed traitor, and one for the rest of the players). These introduce new rules for the players to absorb and shifts the game into something that could be called tactical. Unfortunately the game has dragged on for so long everyone just wants it to be over.

A great horror story-telling opportunity marred by poor design decisions that limit choice and drag the pacing down to a slog.

RATING: 10
My rule for a "10" rating is that it is a game that I will always be willing to play over any other game that isn't another 10. This game has fun theme, great production value and the replay value is huge. The board is made of tiles that are shuffled and reveal as you walk through doors and explore the haunted house. It begins as cooperative play, but then a haunt occurs and somebody in the group becomes the villain of the story. There are 50 different haunt scenarios! Couple that with the variable board, and you've got a lot of bang for your buck. At my house, wee turn off all the lights, light a few candles and give each player a flashlight to heighten the mood. Get into then story element of it and it's way more fun.

Having said all of that, and rated it a 10, I will grudgingly add that it is fairly complex, for some tastes and can be difficult to teach/play with newbie or nongamers. It can sometimes be difficult to even get my game group to play it, so it sits on the shelf a lot. That doesn't change my feelings about it, but know your group before your drop the cash on this one.

RATING: 7.75
A game that doesn't take itself too seriously - and neither should you. Somewhere around the first 'Scream' movie, horror flicks started to become self-refferential, pointing out and playing off their own tropes and cliches. Betrayal follows in those footsteps, with a set of horror movie archetypes to pick from, and a setup not that far removed from a Scooby-Doo episode. And then at some point in the game, everything goes to hell (sometimes literally). 

We've been fortunate enough not to have run into any of the 'broken' scenarios in our limited plays of this, and I can understand how that would likely cloud my perception of it if we had. But by putting yourself in the horror movie cliche frame of mind, and just going along for the ride - there's a fair amount of fun to be had with this game.

RATING: 10
This game is brilliant. I was initially dubious about buying because of its current ranking but the theme and concept interested me too much. Glad I bought it. I've played 8 games so far - Traitor 5; Heroes 3. Each game has been well balanced and perfectly 'win-able' by either side. Best moment was when Dracula appeared with all heroes safe on other levels...until my clutz of a friend fell into the basement with Dracula, discovered the stairs allowing Dracula to get out of the basement and was promptly turned into a vampire, leaving me to fend for myself. I won...just! Whew. Best part about this game is that anyone can pick it up in moments and play. I usually play 2 to 3 games in a 2 - 2 1/2 hour sitting. Can't do that with many games. The haunts are fantastic to play and huge variety. Sometimes you've got to kill the traitor. Sometimes you've got to kill the monster/s. Sometimes you've got to put items together in the right rooms. As neither party is quite sure of the others objectives this keeps you guessing too. I was going to rate this a 9 as the rulebook is lousy but it's just so much fun I couldn't. Really hope they bring out expansions. If the theme and mechanic interest you then buy it. ###Parental warning### Some of the flavour text can be a little frightening for primary school age kids. Flavour text can add some frightening imagery. Suggest not reading it out. Just tell them how many dice to roll or such.

RATING: 7.5
Really enjoy the theme and most of the mechanics. Have had tons of fun with this, and it is great for those looking for a horror theme game, especially during october. Rating would be much higher, but some of the haunts (scenarios) are unbalanced, and some are even flat broken. There are 50 haunts, so lots of variety, but it would have been much better to give like 25 in the original box, focus on perfecting them, and coming out with new haunts later on. There is an expansion which I think has better haunts, but I haven't tried it. You can also find haunts online that are supposed to be more balanced, but I haven't tried any. Another issue is with the triggering of the haunt. Sometimes it can take a long time for the haunt (which is the whole point of the game) to trigger, which makes the game last too long. 

If it weren't for issues with the haunts, my rating would be more like an 8.5. I just heard that a Betrayal legacy game is in the works, and I could not be more excited.

RATING: 4.5
Recipe for a serving of BaHotH:

[1] Enter a room, place a new tile, roll against one of your attributes to get a card, avoid getting hurt, etc. Repeat until:

[2] One of you is exposed as the adversary to everyone else. He/she will then have a unique goal which is generally opposite to that of everyone else. 

[3] If the adversary achieves their goal, he/she wins; otherwise, everyone else wins.

Each time the game is cooked, one of a multitude of different goals is possible.

Definately thematic, but few decisions and lots of randomness make it a spooky party game at best. 

...better than Tales of the Arabian Nights though.

RATING: 3
Love the concept, but this is a deeply flawed game.  I would very much like to see this concept done well. 

The biggest problem is that the pre-Haunt portion of the game creates virtuous circles and vicious circles that often severely unbalance the Haunt.  A player character passes a test and gains enhanced skills, which in turn helps them to pass more tests and/or gain additional items (seems odd that someone trapped in a haunted house would actually improve themselves beyond acquiring the occasional item and/or clues that could help with the Haunt).  For others, their characters just spiral down a vicious circle of failed tests and diminished abilities.  It can get even worse when an unequipped and diminished character becomes the Traitor - then you are about to finish an anticlimactic, boring, and stupid game.  Ideally, I would like to see on balance an edge given to the Traitor.  Further, the house layout is often so chaotic and weird that it detracts from the game - Mystic Elevator(?!), how about another staircase tile or two.  Lastly, the game has problems with rules and components well noted by others.

Despite the game system, I have played one particularly fun and memorable game of Betrayal at the House.  I've also played many bad games always in the hope of experiencing a good/fun game session.

RATING: 5
Based on one play.  The problem is that for an ostensibly experience-driven game, it just doesn't pull you in.  You spend a few turns wandering around bumping into stuff at random, and then the haunt randomly triggers, and you get to spend 15 minutes sorting out the counters that you need and reading the special haunt rules and then rereading the special haunt rules and then re-rereading them and trying to figure out how to address edge cases.  All of this takes you out of the moment, and the random bumping into stuff phase never really drew you in that much to begin with -- you see some iconic horror tropes but there's not (nor is there intended to be) a coherent logic to how they fit together.  And then when the haunt kicks in, it's just a stat-off.  After wanting to play the game for over a decade, I was really underwhelmed by the experience and frankly surprised that it made it out of playtesting.

- Length: Medium-Long

This game definitely has some flaws (horribly imbalanced and some of the game components are below par) but every group we have played it with has absolutely loved it, so it's hard to knock it. Together you all explore a haunted house that is procedurally generated (at first the board is very small. Every time you go through a door you place a new room, creating the haunted house on the table. Makes the game different every time and adds greatly to the replayability) until something horrible happens and one of you (probably) turns against the rest. The theme is very fun especially with a group who will really get into and read the many event cards in fun ways. A great party game that we and all our friends have loved.

RATING: 7.5
A pseudo-cooperative exploration game, where the players begin by working together to investigate a haunted house.  Eventually, the evil of the house overcomes one of the adventurers and they turn into a traitor, trying then to kill everybody else.  What I think is most unique and creative about the game is that you don't know how to win (or lose) the game until after the "haunt" occurs and the traitor is chosen.  The game is a little random and fiddly, but is a lot of fun to play.

RATING: 8
Betrayal at House on the Hill is a great example of a story-based board game, but has bad balance.

To summarize how it's played: each player helps explore a house, collecting items and experiencing events. In the middle of the game, the "Haunt" begins and one of 50 (or 100 if you have Widow's Walk) scenarios begins, where one player becomes the "traitor" and the others become the "heroes", and each have different objectives. (NOTE: Some haunts don't have a traitor, but the vast majority do)

Betrayal is incredibly fun if you're looking for a game that takes you through a unique story based on the way the house is built (the board is fully modular and different every game), which characters are being played, and what haunt is activated. This makes the game feel very rich and full of things to discover. However, the game requires very little skill or thought to play, and there's not much strategizing. Oftentimes, the Haunt is terribly unbalanced because the investigator that became the Traitor was in the best situation, or vice versa. Also, some haunts are poorly scaled to deal with variable player numbers, as the game supports 3-6 players. This can make for a 1-turn Haunt that leaves everyone at the table wanting for more.

At the end of the day, it's a great game that a wide variety of players can enjoy. It may leave the adept gamers wanting more in terms of balance, but it's one of the best story-driven board games I've played.

RATING: 3
This game frustrates me to no end.  I like the premise of the game and the theme; however, due to the numerous uncontrollable, random elements I rarely find myself enjoying this game.  More often than not, I find myself stumbling upon some hidden trap or open pit that horribly cripples me at some point in the game (sometimes even the first turn), and then the rest of the game is spent waiting to die at the hands of the monster/betrayer (or the players if I happen to be the betrayer).  A lot of time is spent wandering around the house, setting up for the betrayal, but when it finally happens the game is frequently resolved in an anticlimactic couple of rounds.  As a result, I feel very much like the guy on the box, pulling out his hair.  The only reason I do not give this game a two is that my gaming group inexplicably loves it, and they occasionally convince me to give it another chance.  I will consider raising this rating if I eventually play a game of this that I enjoy.

If you like playing games where your moves/actions have even the slightest impact on your chances to win, this game is not for you.  In my mind it is the equivalent of a horror-themed "Chutes & Ladders", especially when you fall down a coal chute into the gaping maws of a newly summoned, two-headed snake god.  However, if you *like* games where you can watch your character fall down a coal chute into the gaping maws of a newly summoned, two-headed snake god, this is the game for you!

RATING: 8
Having played only a few times, my impressions so far are very good.  Turn play goes quickly, as there is not too much decision-making on each player's part, especially before the Haunt is triggered.  There is huge variability from one game to the next, so replayability is very high.

The first few games go a little slow as rules are learned, as with most games.  However, you do not need a table of 4+ players who all know and understand the rules.  You can jump into play and learn as they go.

One complaint is the mismatch between the thin cardboard stock of the game pieces and the markers for each players' stats.  The fit is so poor that markers slide too easily or fall off entirely, so much that they are useless for keeping track of stats.  This can be fixed with a few layers of clear plastic tape, but it's a pita that owners shouldn't have to mess with.

RATING: 8
Betrayal at House on the Hill quickly builds suspense and excitement as players explore a haunted mansion of their own design, encountering spirits and frightening omens that foretell their fate. With an estimated one hour playing time, Betrayal at House on the Hill is ideal for parties, family gatherings or casual fun with friends. Betrayal at House on the Hill is a tile game that allows players to build their own haunted house room by room, tile by tile, creating a new thrilling game board every time. The game is designed for three to six people, each of whom plays one of six possible characters. Secretly, one of the characters betrays the rest of the party, and the innocent members of the party must defeat the traitor in their midst before it’s too late! Betrayal at House on the Hill will appeal to any game player who enjoys a fun, suspenseful, and strategic game.

RATING: 6
The first half is definitely a lot more fun than the second, because the focus is more on exploring the house than on defeating the traitor. I feel as though the game is heavily stacked against the traitor, and whoever is determined to be the traitor never seems to have as much fun. For example, one scenario calls for the players to battle the traitor and some enormous tentacles that appear in various rooms throughout the house. the only way for them to win is to use certain items that only appear in certain rooms. Rather than have to continue exploring the house to find them however, as soon as the haunt occurs those rooms are pulled out of the stack and added to the house. Inevitably the players have the tools they need to win within a turn or two and it's only a matter of time until the traitor is defeated.

I feel like this game is more fun if you don't play it frequently, otherwise it gets very frustrating to repeatedly fall into the same situation of defeating the traitor without them really being able to do anything about it. The best game that I participated in actually had a scenario with no traitor, so it was more like the first half of the game flowed smoothly into the second, rather than an abrupt shift.

RATING: 8
Semi-cooperative, story-telling game. Basic game rules are easy, and pretty self-explanatory once started playing. The win conditions are different every game, though generally the heroes want to stop the traitor, and the traitor wants the heroes dead.
There are some complex edge cases, however, that requires more attention and explaining. Such cases are monster movements, item usage, speed effects, and more. It requires reading a lot of text, especially for the revealed traitor, thus English proficiency is recommended. 

Replay Value: 3, once you know the story (there are 50 of them), you know how to play against the opponent
Difficulty: 2
Time: 30-90 minutes

RATING: 10
This report contains spoilers.
.
.
.
Its Saturday night, wife has gone to sleep, nothing on TV. Time to play a game. This was my first solo run to learn the game. Really easy to pick up the rules. I just referred to the rules book as I went along.

So, Father Rhinehardt has persuaded Vivian and Heather to accompany him back to his childhood house, to re-live old times. During the exploration Vivian finds a dog and a young girl. Heather gets a few frights, and gets caught in a web for a while, until freed by Vivian.
Felt like I was in my own B movie. Rhinehardt triggers the haunt. Turns out he died in the house many years ago, and only has a living body due to a magical medallion in his possession. He wants the girls to join him in the afterlife. His batteries die in his flashlight so he can only move one room at a time. The girls managed to escape the sinking house.

RATING: 7
It's a neat, light exploration game which goes from "individual" gameplay and shifts into a "team/co-operative" style by rolling into a randomly determined monster scenario (of which there are 50 different types).  This is probably it's best feature, so depending upon which scenario/special monster turns up, and which player becomes the traitor, nearly every game is different with a different set of winning conditions.  The board tiles are modular so the haunted house is also different every time.  There is, with this kind of game, of course, a fair amount of randomness but also some "luck by preparation" as well.  This game reminds me a great deal of another haunted house tile-laying game, Chill Black Morn Manor, but this is much better as it's more balanced, rules are clearer/better and it is a cool "magic fun house" romp creating a fantastical haunted house with lots of fluff.  This may also possibly draw comparisons with Fury of Dracula and Buffy the Vampire Slayer games.  I really enjoy the quick gameplay and especially the theme as light games go.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Excellently thematic game. The traitor mechanic is a huge bonus. The game mechanics are simple enough to teach to a non-gamer. Some of the components are poor quality though (I'm looking at you, plastic sliders). Comes with pre-painted minis, which are nice addition. This game has a big luck factor (you roll dice on everything), so if you don't like it, don't play this. Some of the scenarios are unbalanced, but in my opinion that is not the point of this game. I just can't take this game competitively. It's still an issue for people who like to test their skills against worthy foes. The novelty of the traitor mechanic wears off though, and after that you have a decent game with a fun gimmick.

RATING: 8.3
Type: 3-6 players, half coop exploration, half traitor competitive board game.

Best With: 4-5 players
Weight: medium
Duration: 1-3 hours
Notes:
Traitor reads/interprets game rules alone in different room.
Role-play
Minor card reading.
Dice-and-stats combat

I really like this game, and works best with 4-5 players. The initial cooperative exploration half is pretty fun and flavorful with just enough tension and bite to keep things interesting.

The Haunt half, though, is super fun and varied as the rules change with every play. The downside, though, is if someone who isn't so good at reading and following rules on their own gets chosen as the traitor. That person needs to leave the room while the other discuss the other new rules in secret, and then all come back together to play the rest of the game out based on the new rules and goals. If someone doesn't get the new rules, the game breaks down pretty quickly and becomes less mystery and more just raw mechanics/race.

But with a group who can all handle consuming rules on their own, this game is crazy excellent.

RATING: 4
Betrayal (or BatHotH) is an interesting concept broken into two halves that ends up failing in the second one. The idea of exploring an old, haunted house is terrific thematically but the game bases this exploration around building up to 'the Haunt', which almost always turns out to be incredibly lame because it does not control for what happens in the first half. Haunts are either a complete rout of the players or a complete rout of the traitor with almost no in-between, which makes the game a foregone conclusion. It is not well-designed, but it is well-intentioned and can be fun if you're not picky about design or are looking for a low-complexity game.

RATING: 6
Haunted house themed Ameritrash game made by the creators of D&D. The game starts as a co-op exploration of the house via laying unique tiles and drawing event/item/haunt cards. 

Once the haunt starts there will likely be a traitor with possible monsters. The haunts are flavorful and have a B-movie feel to them, so they are kind of funny. Unfortunately, some of the explanations of how specific haunts work are vague and this leads to confusion, especially if the traitor is a new player; in most cases, we try to play with whatever makes the most sense when the specific rules are lacking. In the end it doesn't really matter because most haunts are imbalanced (either towards the traitor or the heroes) and everything is determined by dice rolls.

Overall, this is a game that is fun and can really be enjoyed for the flavor as long as expectations of tight rules and balance are checked at the door. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
The game-content is OK, although the tiles for the House on the Hill are too think and wobbly; the miniatures are OK, but they lack the detail and finesse compared with other boardgames with miniatures;
the rules are excellent and very easy to learn and simple to be applied to the game;
the theme is caught nicely;

But here we lack the gaming experience, and this is only a certain pessimistic outlook of the game.

RATING: 7
This is a great game provided you have the right group of people! The first time we played was late at night, and we read all the cards by torchlight and really got 'in' to the game.

The second time we played, with some other people, some of our group were getting bored waiting for their turn and didn't really 'get' the story.

If you can get in to the game, and the atmosphere, then it is great. If not, then not so much!

We haven't really had any problems with the rules yet (second edition). It has all made sense so far.

I can see there might be an issue if a more inexperienced gamer becomes the traitor - they might get very confused by all the extra rules that can come in to play during the haunt.

Overall I gave this 7.5 because we had such good fun on the first play-through, but I can see that it isn't for everyone.

Edit: Taking it down half a point because the balance in some (most?) of the haunts is a bit squiffy. Had a couple of cases now where it is literally impossible for one side to win. A little more care needs to be taken to balance up the haunts I think!

RATING: 8
This game has so many problems, yet I still seem to enjoy it! The main issue is that the game will often end anticlimactically. However, you will -- every so often -- have a great game that comes down to the wire. The fact that the game has 50 (!) scenarios is cool: the downside is that implementing the scenario requires pausing the game in progress and reading a bunch of crap, much of which will be somewhat confusing. This can really kill the mood/momentum. 

But: theme! Oodles of it. Can be fun with the right (read: rowdy) group. Easy enough for casual gamers. Deeply flawed, but the theme, short play time, and occasional to-the-wire finish make up for it.
