=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

Looking for a simple game that all mystery and horror fans can play and enjoy? Probably you are in the right place. Betrayal at house on the Hill is an easy to learn game that offers 50 horror stories to play! Thus, no one can complain about the replayability of the game. Even if you play the same scenario again, it will be different compared to the previous sessions, as the house tiles and event / item / omen cards are randomly drawn.

In my turn I simply move my character from room to room. When I reveal a new room, I place a new house tile and I usually draw a card that matches the room’s symbol (omen, item or event). Then I follow what the card says and that’s it. It is common a card to ask for a check in one or more of my characterer’s traits, which are Might, Speed, Sanity and Knowledge. In such a case, I roll the corresponding number of dice and I see what happens depending on the result. The fun part begins when the haunting of the house is revealed. Every time a player draws an omen card, he have to make a haunt roll. This means that he rolls 6 dice (result 0-2 on each die) and if the sum is less than the total number of omen cards in play, then the haunting is revealed. One player becomes the traitor and his purpose is to kill the others or prevent them from put an end on the haunting, while the other players (survivors) are stuggling to survive and stop the evil plans. There are two books, one for the traitor, one for the survivors, which describe what is the story and what should be done by the players.

In order to enjoy this game, all players have to be in the right mood and like this horror / mystery stuff. I don’t recommend this game for players that want absolute control, as there are too many random elements. Sometimes a scenario is ruined by the game itself due to high randomness. For example, it may end too soon, even in the first or second turn after the haunting. My advice is not to take this game seriously and just play and see what happens like watching a movie but in this case the star is you!

Keep in mind that good knowledge of English is necessary by all players.

(+)
Atmospheric gameplay
Replayability
Easy to learn, even by non-gamers
Beautiful tiles and painted miniatures
Plays well with any number of players

(-)
Simple tokens with no artwork
Some scenarios need errata and clarifications

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
I have a lot of problems with betrayal (like a lot!) but its appeal is pretty undeniable. I play with a lot of people who don't play a lot of games themselves, and literally everyone loves this game. Even when I feel it went on to long, didn't have very many actual decisions to make, and ended with a whisper rather than a bang, when I look around everyone seems to have had a good time, and it gets requested pretty often. the theme is fun and its really easy to play (for the most part). the first part of the game is spent aimlessly walking around, falling into various horror movie tropes (evil doll, ghost, collapsing floor, etc), and collecting items, weapons, and spooky items (omens). each time an omen is found, dice are rolled and if the number rolled is lower than the total number of omens found by all players then the second part of the game starts (the haunt). When the haunt starts one of the players is revealed to be a traitor, determined by the specific omen you found and which room of the house it was in. the traitor player goes into the other room with a special traitor book and reads how exactly they win this specific scenario, while the rest of the players do the same with their own book. most of the scenarios are just some kind of monster(s) trying to kill all the other players, but there are a few that are more interesting and complicated than that. It comes with 50 scenarios in the base game and another 50 in the expansion so there is lots of replay-ability, but because of the way the scenario is determined, its very possible (guaranteed) to end up playing a few of them many times before you've played them all.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In the game, a motley crew arrive at an old creepy mansion and promptly decide to break the law, by trespassing when they enter uninvited.  The group explore the mansion trying to accomplish whatever the scenario dictates until eventually one member goes insane, or becomes demon possessed, or whatever the case, and turns on the others.  After that the traitor's goal diverges from the rest as that person tries to kill off the others, while they try to get out alive.

It's an interesting idea for a game, and pretty fun to play through.  The components are very good.  I especially like the pre-painted minis that represent the various characters.  As you explore the mansion you turn over thick cardboard squares that nicely depict the various rooms.  This mechanic ensures that the mansion will never be laid out exactly the same from one game to the next.

The game can grind to a halt for awhile, sometimes quite awhile, when the traitor is revealed.  When this happens that player, and the others, physically go their separate ways to read from different books to study what will be expected of them for the rest of the game.  After that everyone comes back to the table to continue play.

Overall, the game is fun, and usually not too lengthy to be a distraction.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I love this game's concept. The idea of building the mansion as you go is innovative, and makes for a unique experience almost every time you play. The miniatures (although not the greatest quality) are all colored, and varied (per character), which is a nice touch.

The rules... hmm... the rules, aren't too confusing. Well, okay... there is a little bit of a learning curve, I'd say. The strongest selling point for this game also happens to be its biggest flaw, in my opinion... the betrayer. Yes, the idea that one of the people you've been searching this maze-like mansion with suddenly turning against you is a BRILLIANT one. However, it's the execution that leaves a little to be desired. I appreciate the mechanic of a random betrayer appearing at any time, but that time could be faaaaaaaaaar into the game when everyone's stacked with equipment and stat boosts (including the traitor), or it could be your first turn... literally. The odds are EXTREMELY rare, yes, but I think I played a game where we'd gone around the circle of three players once, and on turn five we rolled the betrayal scenario. The game knows this is a possibility and has scenarios in place specifically to compensate for such an event, but it can still be rough.

Then there's the problem of actually becoming the betrayer. You leave the room to read from your "betrayal tome" while the other players discuss their strategy. So you read over the rules, and maybe it's just me, but some of them aren't exactly easy to understand. There's a certain level of ambiguity to what you're supposed to do, and since you have no idea what the survivors need, it's sometimes confusing since "A" isn't communicating with "B". And you can't really ask anyone for clarification, either. Maybe after enough times through, you figure you'll get the hang of it... but there's fifty different scenarios (not counting the additional fifty with the expansion), so there's going to be A LOT of learning, with little practice. The biggest issue is that if it's your very first time playing this game, and YOU end up as the betrayer... good fucking luck... you're going to need it.

Look, I don't want to come off like I hate this game, I actually like it a lot, it's just very unforgiving. I recommend it. And if you buy it, I HIGHLY recommend getting an insert. I found a great one at inserthere.me and it's made setup a lot easier. This game has like a THOUSAND tokens, most of which you will NEVER EVEN USE, and a lot of them have the same shape with only slightly varying color, so it's in your best interest to find a solution to sorting them out before you start a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Good: 
It can be entertaining exploring a haunted mansion and see what happens to you and your friends as rooms are revealed. 

Finding items and powering up characters before the haunt feels rewarding. 

Because you don't know exactly when the haunt will happen there is a level of tension to the game leading up to the haunt.

Rooms are placed as the mansion is explored, and the haunt is determined by which character triggered it so each game is different.

Bad: 
The game is unbalanced to the point where some hunts feel broken. The haunt is when someone is changed to a super villain but the timing and power is a bit random. During the 3 plays of this game during 2 of them they started so early the heroes had little to no chance of overcoming the villain. 

When the haunt happens the gameplay comes to a stop, literally. People have to pull out manuals and see their win conditions, the villain has to go into another room and read up on their powers and their win condition. It can really kill the game's vibe altogether.

RATING: 5.8
This is a game that I think really depends on the group. A good group may make up for the copious flaws of the game. It is extremely random with very few meaningful decisions to be made before the haunt begins. After the haunt begins, the place of the board and luck of card draws before the beginning of the haunt has more influence on the outcome than player decisions. You are along for the ride in this game, and if you don't have good passengers with you, it won't be very fun. To add to this, many of the scenarios are written so poorly that without looking at both books, you can't tell what the scenario rules are. The tiles are also about 30% bigger than they need to be. It takes way too much space to play this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game was an absolute blast to play.  It starts out somewhat like a cooperative dungeon-crawl game, but after a certain condition is triggered, a traitor is revealed, and the two separate teams of players must now compete to complete secret winning conditions.  Every game plays out differently, since the house layout is discovered randomly and the traitor and scenario are determined based on in-game conditions, which gives this game a ton of replay value.  I am concerned that the "secret" winning conditions could be easily remembered once all of the scenarios have been played several times, which would make the game far less exciting, but with 50 different scenarios to use, I can't imagine that this would become a problem until we'd played it many, many times.  While it's certainly not a strategy-heavy game, Betrayal is extremely fun to play, and it should be a long time before I ever tire of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Game in a Nutshell: Explore a house creating a modular board as you go collecting items to potentially help you later on. Eventually something will happen and a trader amongst the group will emerge and a series of tasks are set so that eather the betrayer or cooperatives will rule the day.

Played as: 3 player

Pros: The sense of exploration created while playing brings tension with every turn. The different scenarios that occur when the betrayer is revealed are brilliant and well written. The co-op nature of the game made me care much less about the general randomness.

Cons: The game basically plays itself and takes the players on a ride. High on luck, low on important decisions. It'd be nice if the characters were fleshed out a little more other then a picture and some stats.

Other: I had a lot of fun playing this even though I didn't feel challenged or in control. Basically, I just loved the ride.

Best Use: A light-hearted haunting game of fun and the unexpected that's less mind-numbing then a strategy but more interactive then a movie.

RATING: 7
I've only played once, and I ended up as the traitor: Crimson Jack, the maniacal killer.

I enjoyed the game. It's got a great theme, and game play really flows. The rule book seems a little dense, but once you get into the game it all makes sense, and it's actually quite simple. I could easily see this moving up to an 8.

It appears, based on having read the rules and now having played once, that there is a luck element that can diminish the fun of certain scenarios. In my case, Crimson Jack rolled a 1, 2 and 2 on his movement dice and couldn't get in any early attacks. And the heroes had already found the weapon that killed him, so it turned out to be a romp for them. I think that's a minor criticism, but a criticism nevertheless. Probably a monster should have a minimum move in that situation.

Thanks to The Lone Gamer for trading this to me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
OK, so Betrayal is not a deep strategic or competitive game, but for me anyways, it is an entertaining, light adventure/experience game that generally works well and often provides a good narrative.  Not every Haunt will be balanced and some may be less than entertaining, but if so, the group is only out 90 minutes.  I've suffered through much worse.

Of the adventure/rpg/boardgame hybrids that I've played (Arkham Horror, Runebound, Android, Fury of Dracula, Legends of Andor, Tales of the Arabian Nights), Betrayal is simpler and plays faster than other games in the genre.  The game's accessible nature means that it can be played with a wide range of gamers.

Might be a good game to breakout with kids.  I also like the co-op and traitor game mechanics which work well and thematically with the game.

With 50 available scenarios, Betrayal offers a good amount of replayability, and is a game that I hope to continue to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This is a really special game - it holds a unique place in my collection. It manages to create a perfect atmosphere within an hour or hour and a half timeframe. The artwork is simplistic, yet well made and very evocative. The scenarios are exquisitely written and provide for a different game each time - both storywise and regarding mechanics.

The big problem with it is the quality of components though. Room tiles and character sheets are made of thin cardboard and become warped, and the characteristics sliders are loose and inaccurate. The cards are very thin, and some of them even seem slightly worn even straight from the box. I don't find this to influence my game experience, but have still reduced my overall rating of the game for poor production values.

Had it been manufactured in better quality, it would have been a 9 or 10 for me - I'm very happy to have this game in my collection!

RATING: 7
+2 immersive, descriptive, thematic 
+1 makes for great 'collaborative storytelling' - leading to yelps and giggles and banter. 
+1 huge replayability with lots of different scenarios 
+1 despite a lack of strategic depth and high luck factor; there's still an RPG "I can save the day with my cool gear and stats" factor which is enjoyable. 

-1 for such a big-box game, it is very light on strategy. 
-2 Rules can be frustratingly vague. (Broadly forgivable for a 'storytelling' game, but if you're the traitor, trying to figure out a confusing, conflicting rulebook on your own, in a 'everyone vs me' situation can be upsetting/stressful for some newer/shyer players...and can eventually lead to a rules lawyering, unimmersive anticlimax) 

This game is enjoyable how DnD is enjoyable: Collaborative storytelling. Not for rules lawyers or shy, but With "rule of cool", it can be awesome.

RATING: 7
I have the 2010 2nd Edition.

Like a combination of Mansions of Madness and Zombies!!!, BaHotH is surprisingly lighter weight then it looks and plays relatively straightforward from the first game.

Most of the mechanics and difficulty level relies heavily on luck, so Eurogamers better look the other way and go back to counting their cubes, but if you enjoy theme over strategy then you might like this.

Love the modular house and Haunt/Betrayal feature. 

Unfortunately I find getting a game in quite difficult, as my serious group were initially put off when a scenario rule broke logic (they drowned whilst in a boat) whilst my casual group don't like the responsibility of being the traitor, and can't handle their own unique set of rules when the Haunt starts.

A ton of story and fun packed into 60 minutes of play. Atmospheric. We always get into character creeping around the old house... waiting for the betrayal.

The two phases of the game - set up/exploration and betrayal/action - mesh very well. You get that tense build up each game. 

With 50 scenarios, I've only scratched the surface with this one. But I've already seen a wide variety. It's just plain fun not to know whether this time the players will all be fighting each other, on teams, or one against many. I won't ruin any the scenarios but each is interesting and unique.

The clips to keep track of your stats suck, though. Really bad. They never stay on.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Players are a character with hit points on might, sanity, knowledge and speed. Players are exploring a haunted house, building the house with tile draws, until a "haunt" begins, then one player becomes a traitor. The victory conditions then depend on the haunt scenario, but usually involve killing off the traitor for the rest of the players or if you are the traitor, killing everyone else off. It's a fun, campy game and if you are young and impressionable, you are bound to like the game. However, the rules do not appear to be very clear in some of the scenarios, so you may have to make up the rules as you go along. Some neat ideas, too bad the execution of the ideas wasn't worked out in detail.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
I have the remake and I like it a lot. Well produced (though not good enough for the price tag in component quality its still worth it overall)

Makes for an easy to play, roleplaying experience that is high in luck, high in fun, fast-paced, takes little time, offers a lot of diversity thanks to the wonderful variety of scenarios and wonderful fluff. Probably the best halloween game and a very good novelty game. It's not one for taking out every week but it's certainly fun to pull out for a nice easy but spooky time every once in a while and for casual or non-gamers.

This is not a game I would pull out unless I was playing with young people, casual gamers, or had a large group such as 6 players who wanted to play a proper thematic board game (not resistance or something) but there were definitely players who wouldn't understand something more complex than this. It's highly luck but still a lot of fun and a good game.

RATING: 8
Main strength: Total Randomness. You don't know who the traitor is, what scenario you're playing, or the layout of the mansion when you start. Even if you'd replay a haunt, the random placement of tiles and characters would still make it different.

RATING: 4
What Betrayal At House On The Hill tries to be is the Swiss Army Knife of horror games. It wants to be 50 horror movies in a box, and at first glance it seems to have that potential. Seeing tokens titled 'Blob', or 'Dracula' or 'Spores' gets the imagination churning. The choice of playable characters, plus the randomness of the room placement, Event/Item/Omen draws, and the Haunts allows for millions of potential variations (no hyperbole).  The randomness of where tiles are placed makes each mansion unique and artistic and exploring the old house is like being the Scooby-Doo gang, you can just picture The Mystery Machine parked out front.

But the game is almost unplayable when the Haunt begins. The instructions feel like they are lacking vital pieces of information required to execute a successful Haunt, making the game confusing, or downright impossible, to understand. 

Also, I wish there were miniatures instead of cardboard for most of the components, even though that would have jacked the price up. Oh, and the character artwork sucks pretty hard.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
---Preliminary thoughts---
Cooperative with a traitor (like Shadows over Camelot of Galactica)

The theme is very similar to Mansions of Madness, but the evil player (traitor in this case) is not revealed until after 30 minutes of play, when players have geared up exploring the house.

I like the tile system allowing very different houses each time you play. Also, there's 50 different haunts (adventures) -> replayability is high.

Components are nice, but no way as great as in Mansions of Madness.

The biggest drawback 30 half an hour, where you wander aimlessly through the house. This and the components make me prefer Mansions of Madness over this game.

For cooperative with traitor games, I prefer both Galactica and Mansions over Madness. It's not a bad game, but it's one I would not play, because I have better ones.

RATING: 7.5
Fun, silly. Decent enough game and worth the 1-2 hours it takes to play. Matches the theme well. It is a game that I find I enjoy more with each play, especially if all the components are bagged (there are nearly a half-ton of small chits in this game).

When I first tried it, my initial thought was "won't the number of scenarios restrict the replay value?" The answer has, so far, been no. The game's silly immersion into the depths of creepy horror and morphing board design make this a different game each time. I find that you get a lot for your money with this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My group has a running joke. Every time someone asks a rules question about a game, I snap-reply: "It's not clear." The joke started with this game.

BaHotH has a well-earned reputation as a game with a kludgy ruleset, with lots of ambiguous corner cases and curious omissions. I'd also argue the game lacks a strategic element. Without an mechanic for learning the traitor's identity or a clue as to what the haunt might be, the players have no way to prepare for the second half of the game that differs meaningfully from session to session. You're always discovering as many rooms as you can; you're always avoiding rooms that threaten to lower your stats; you're always heading towards rooms that boost your stats; you always want items; etc.

After the haunt, your best strategy is usually clear -- and it's usually "run up and punch bad guy."

I suppose it's not meant to be a deep game, but it has so many bits and pieces it seems like it should be a little deeper than it is. The rules aren't simple or clear enough to justify its reputation as a "casual" game either.

That said, it works best as an "experience generator," when players can really have some fun hamming it up as they read the Event cards aloud, or throw themselves into the role of traitor with malevolent cackles and witty taunts.

But it's a game that's begging for someone to come along and break it open, to find the real gem of a game that's hiding inside it.

RATING: 6.5
Here's the reason I can't rate this higher - if you get the right haunt with the right amount of time elapsed in the game, it's an 8 or even a 9.  When that happens the game is interesting, challenging, and does a great job of capturing the flavor of a horror movie.

The problem is, there are haunts that will really make you wish you'd picked something else instead.  They can be long, overly fiddly, too easy, or too hard.  Or a combination of the bad.  When that happens, the game can be a 4 or a 5.

There's a lot to like in this game and I've heard that the newer version fixed some of the issues with the haunts.  If that's the case, it could be a dramatically improved game.  But the flaws in the version I purchased are enough that it rarely sees the table because there are more consistent options available.

RATING: 8
Good game but quite complex and fiddly. Players explore a haunted house until one horror scenario is revealed, at which point one player 'betrays' his friends and takes on a role to kill them off, using whatever tools are applicable to the scenario. Ranging from werewolves, vampires, zombies and psychos to bizarre witch and cat stories, the game kind of relies on the 'traitor' knowing the game inside out, as they have all the secret knowledge. The random cards drawn through out the game are great for building up a degree of 'horror film' tension until the big reveal.

RATING: 7.5
Finally Updating my Score, down from 8 to 7, and I feel that it belongs here for two reasons:
1) The value of this game is entrenched in who you play it with.  It's 'heavy theme' and too many rules are up for debate.  Make sure you play with easy-going people.
2) Big luck factor. If you hate luck, don't bother. I happen to like an element of chance in a game and so it works for me.
My group is able to look past the erratas and simple rules, and we enjoy the fun atmosphere that this game provides.  Just about every scenario has been fun, and for the most part, favoured the heroes.  Some haunts are better than others, and some are used way too liberally.  I really hope AH come out with an expansion pack with new tiles, new heroes, new haunts, and reprints for misprinted tiles (ahem, underground lake, anyone?)

All and all, I like this game.  The last time that I played I started to like it less - one haunt was fun, the other was totally pointless. With this said, I believe this game deserves a high rating because I'll continue to have fun with this title as it's a fresh, low-strategy choice for beer 'n pretzels.

Update:  This can easily be a party game for your 'boardgame inclined' friends.  They'll love it, because it's pretty simple and fun, with great atmosphere.  Plus, they're totally turned-on by the fact that there's 50 scenarios.  Their eyes will light up like your own when you first read it.

But I repeat - rule heads and chaos haters avoid!

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very popular game with the group I play with. Had it for years, only play sporadically as it's always seen as a filler game, but only if there's definitely enough time to play it. Consequently, there are still plenty of haunts we haven't yet seen.

The initial period of the game, prior to the haunt reveal, when the players are searching the house, creates a nice atmosphere of expectation.  To add to the mystery, the eventual traitor isn't necessarily the one who draws the trigger haunt.

Once the traitor is banished from the room, each side reads its version of the rules.  The traitor returns and the remaining heroes get to see any set-up changes.  The game continues with each side trying to determine the other's new abilities/powers and aims.  Once one side realises (or thinks it realises) the other's route to victory it's a race to the end: sometimes, the heroes have to actively battle the traitor (and his minions); in other scenarios they merely have to avoid the traitor, in short, running away.

I think we've probably played about 10 of the 50 scenarios, so far.  Mostly, the scenarios have played out well, providing an initially neat guessing game followed by a well balanced fight or chase.  However, 1 or 2 have proved a disappointment, either because they seemed an uneven contest, or because the scenario was won in an incredibly short time.  Another problem can be that the traitor has no one with whom to check his version of the rules: he can't confer with the others without giving away some of the secret.  One of our damp squib games occurred because the traitor had either misunderstood or just misread his rules.

Overall, as I've said, this game has maintained its popularity with my group.  It's a good game to include a new or casual gamer, provided that the newbie can be included in the hero team rather than be the traitor against Hill veterans.

RATING: 6
Cute little quick cross between mansions of madness and Dungeon run. Just like in Mansions, you explore a spooky house and encounter little events here and there that can earn you items or push you towards death, and just like in Dungeon Run, at some point one of the players becomes the antagonist and the other players have to scramble to beat them.

The game is a little to random for my taste, but it's quick so it doesn't overstay it's welcome. The minis are pre-painted which is nice, but the paint job is a little rough. Additionally the markers you use to remember your varying stats slide around way too easily making it ripe for error.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
This game is built around a very cool idea, but is just as likely to be arduous and boring as it is fun and exciting.

You see, the game is split into two parts: the adventure, and the haunt.
During the adventuring phase, players take turns exploring the mansion, finding new rooms, and picking up items.  This starts off interesting enough.  Ooh! We're exploring a creepy place full of creepy things dripping with flavor text.  Nice.....  
Except after a little while you realize that there aren't any meaningful decisions to be made during this entire half of the game.  You never know what you're about to walk into, and every circumstance is decided for you by dice and card draw with zero player input.
But this is just the beginning, right? The portion where we're exploring and powering up before the Haunt, that special moment when everything goes crazy.  We can wait.  Right?

Well here's the thing: since the start of the haunt is random it might start way early, before anyone's had the chance to prepare enough to stand a chance against it... or it may start hours late into the game when every player has become strong enough while waiting around bored to tears to have absolutely no trouble completing the challenge.

Ultimately you have a game in which the majority of plays are either lopsided for the co-op team, or for the Haunt player, but still wants two to three hours of your life to get there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Classic "horror movie in a box" type of game. Cooperative until a haunt triggers then  becomes a one vs. all which can be tricky as the rules tend to be vague for the traitor. Benefit is that everyone knows who the traitor is so that player doesn't need to worry about being obvious or anything. (Mostly) modular tiles and 50 haunts in the base game allow for great replay-ability. The exploration of the house is enjoyable although theme and logic can be broken depending on what you draw as you struggle to explain why some rooms are where they are. Components are so-so quality but the game is fun enough and has that stereotypical horror theme that has yet to be replaced by any other game.

RATING: 4
This game definitely comes with the caveat that "Your Mileage May Vary".  It is very luck-based and you if you have any expectation for enjoyment you should be sure to just relax and go along with story.

The haunt was interesting, and hearing about other haunts makes me want to try again.  With my experience in the game, however, I'm probably only going to play this game again while drinking a few beers and on Halloween.  There aren't enough positive things going on otherwise.

First, player elimination.  I don't understand how games can still have that.  We had one person die within the first round of the haunt and just sat there for the next 45 minutes.  That, in and of itself, ruins this game for me.  So, so bad...and the designers should feel bad.

Second, there seem to be dominate characters.  I've heard this might change from haunt-to-haunt, but my wife and I spent the entire haunt trapped because we weren't strong enough to break free.  We had ZERO opportunity to increase our might before the haunt.  So, effectively we had one person eliminated and two others rolling dice on their turn to eventually just sit back in their chair, which is the same as being eliminated.

So, so, so bad.

RATING: 9
I'm aware of many of the problems with this game (lopsided player balance at the start of the haunt, over-abundance of tokens, strange narrative stories due to random card draws, etc.), but I have enjoyed every play of this game.  

I love the change in mechanics half-way through, the modular board (with the mistaken pool that can show up on the top floor), the haunts as well as the story lines they spawn, and the semi-cooperative nature that can either become fully cooperative , one-vs-all , or fully competitive.  It all keeps you on your toes and makes every play different.

RATING: 3
The biggest mystery here is why other people gives this game good scores.

For the first 80% of the game you'll be moving your playing piece around a map and randomly seeing if you take damage and/or find objects.

Then, after that pointless grind is finally finished, there will be a boss fight. The fight will have a mildly interesting concept i.e. a poltergeist that must be controlled by reposiitoning candles etc. But it will simply require the same grind of obvious decisions and randomness to resolve it.

That's it.

It's worse than the similar Mansions of Madness, which does itself suffer from the same problem but does other things better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Theme - 5/5. Yes please. Haunted creepy house? Awesome scary movie group dynamics? People turning traitor as the night goes by? Every horror trope in the book? Sign me up.

Complexity - 4/5. Complexity wise, it's really not too complex that it's impossible to explain, but not so simple that it's super easy. However, some scenarios are just difficult to understand at times unless you've read the rules multiple times. So the varying complexity is both a good and a bad thing. The rules are well laid out however. Read the rules before you play, this is not a read as you go game.

Length - 4/5. This is definitely a whole night game. Again, same issue with complexity, games can run from 30 minutes to 2 hours depending on what you run in to. But it never was so long that I wanted to just step away.

Fun - 4.5/5. This would be a 5/5 if not for certain scenarios being so ridiculously one sided that either the traitor or the survivors just want to go 'fuck it' after all of that build up. That drops it down a point. The amount of those kinds of scenarios that are SO one sided that they're annoying are relatively low though.

Replay-ability - 5/5. You can play this game until the cows come home because it changes each and every time. And with so many scenarios, you'll probably be playing it for years before you see every single traitor scenario.

Production Value - 3/5. The pieces are nice, especially the character pieces, as are the cardboard rooms, however they damage easily, ESPECIALLY with those damn sliders. It's not horrible value, but I feel like it the cardboard and the sliders together along with the tiles in general, while amazing, could have used some serious work. Also no easy way to organize all the various different bits and pieces in the box itself. I love the game, I do not love all the parts I have to sort through every single time to set things up with no base way in the box itself of finding them other than plastic baggies.

Overall - 4.25/5. A great game that has some problems that need to be ironed out, but are mostly fixable with a little bit of elbow grease. Hard to get tired of it.

Bonus: Customization - 5/5. It's pretty easy to make your own scenario or character for this game. Look online, they're all over.

RATING: 6.5
Betrayal can either be a great game or a terrible one, depending entirely on how lucky you are in he setup of the mansion when the haunt begins. The premise is simple enough, split up and explore a haunted mansion until one player turns traitor, at which point the game divides into teams that are fighting for survival. There are over 50 different scenarios for the haunt, but while the sheer volume of content is great, balance can be an issue.

I've seen games where the heroes don't even have a chance to begin before the tiny house with an early haunt drops into hell, or games where the haunt began with the toughest fighter in the hero party already having the gear he needs to kill the monster the haunt revolves around.

It's a fun game with the right crowd that doesn't take it too seriously, but can often be too one-sided from the moment it really begins.

RATING: 7
Betrayal is a very fun game. What's not to like about a group of people exploring a haunted house?!!?! :)

The modular board ensures that games are always different. The betrayer mechanic works very well and the way that the betrayer doesn't know that they are the betrayer until "The Haunt" happens is very cool. So everyone is a team player until things go bad. The random "Haunt" effect means that it will be a new adventure every time (at least until you've went through the game 50 times (this is how many unique haunts there are). If 50 aren't enough (that'll last you some time!), you can even get new custom ones on the internet for even more replayability.

If I have a minor quibble - it is regarding the quality of some components. The player pieces came bent and seem a little flimsy, so I'm a little reluctant to try bending them back into shape. Though they do have nice basic paint schemes. The other complaint is the sliders on the player stat board. The sliders fit terribly and always require a bit of user fixing (sliding a bit of paper underneath usually helps a bit, though is untidy) to work at all. Apart from that, the board components are really top notch.

Quite a fun game that I rarely turn down the option to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I've played this game 6 or 7 times and have never had an even moderately enjoyable time playing this game, win or lose.

Most people who like the game say it's all about the theme, and the theme is what makes the game so good, but that has never been the case for me. A good theme draws you in and has you make compelling decisions that make sense with the theme. This game does not have that.

The first half of the game (Pre-Haunt) is the same every single game. You wander aimlessly, discovering flavor text that by the 5th time you play you've already seen before. It doesn't feel any different from playing a roll and move game.

Once the haunt starts, it gets even worse. The vast quantity of haunts suffer from an appalling lack of quality. 

Firstly, the wording in the book is confusing and unclear much of the time. In most games, the betrayer has to clarify something about his abilities and objectives with his opponents, which seriously takes away from the immersion and theme.

Secondly, almost every scenario is paint by numbers with obvious choices, so you just go through the motions until the scenario is over. Where you need to go is obvious on every turn, unless you want to take an obviously sub-optimal move in an attempt to avoid the monotony.

Lastly, and most importantly, in almost every scenario it is blatantly clear who the "winner" is going to be as soon as the haunt is read and understood. Either the betrayer is overpowered, or the non-betrayers are able to easily find some sort of exploit to make it impossible for the betrayer to progress. I've never played a game where someone doesn't say "Well...this is unfair." within 5 minutes after the haunt is revealed. In the rare case it isn't, it is just standing in place rolling dice hoping to reach an arbitrary total to end the game as soon as possible.

Yes, I know that many would argue that being focused on the result of the game is the wrong way to go about it. After all, it is about the journey, not the destination. 

I would counter that Betrayal at House on the Hill takes the easiest lay up of a theme, a story driven Haunted House game, and goes out of its way to ruin the enjoyment and immersion of the players at every given opportunity through repetitive game play, no compelling decisions, and a broken end game.

RATING: 7
16-07-2014. Rated after 5 plays or so (2 recent). Fun game, in which you explore a house to improve your character. Some rooms in the house allow you to take item/haunt cards. Then, at some point a haunt is triggered. The game comes with about 50 haunts, which are triggered by which cards were flipped in the game. Then, one of the players betrays the others and starts with an objective to win (often by killing other players or achieving something nebulous). The other plays try to stop him.

The game is not perfect. The components are pretty poorly executed. Tokens could've been much better. Sometimes depending on the layout of the board/house haunts are impossible to win for one of the parties.

Regardless, if the game works well, it is amazing and easily one of the most interesting experiences to be had in this genre of games. Very fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is one of those situations where a rating is more reflective of my enjoyment than the quality of the game itself. It's not that Betrayal at House on the Hill is not a well-designed game. Quite the opposite in fact. It is a very accessible thematic experience that has an insane amount of variety, creating situations and narratives that continue to surprise even after numerous sessions. It's an absurdly generous game, and one that most non-gamers will really enjoy. It somehow manages to strike the balance between spooky and aggressively goofy, which is impressive.

But it is also a very leaky experience. There is an enormous amount of variance in how games can go, very little of which is in the players' hands. One game might be down to the wire, and another might be basically impossible for one side. The Haunts are all (in my experience) at least entertaining to read and go through, but there's also a real chance that the game can kind of collapse in the back half. It's this wobbly nature that will keep some people from really enjoying the game, assuming they can tolerate the huge luck factor. For my part it is the price you pay for one of the most entertaining games out there. Warts and all, it's earned its place as one of the most fun and distinct games of the last 20 years.

RATING: 3
I loathe the first act, for the same reasons I dislike the D&D adventure games - move on a grid, draw a card, read some text, roll some dice, say, "Oh. Now I'm stuck for three turns," and repeat. All this sans any role-playing element or enjoyable interaction. What's more, no mistrust of the villain exists until, well, the villain exists, so there is no tension or negotiation at work, unless you're negotiating to play Anything Else: The Board Game. 
The second act is fine, I suppose, but no narrative or decision led to its unfolding. Just random events. Plus I'm convinced half of the haunts are broken or wildly unbalanced. 
The only redeeming aspect of this game are the good-natured folks I've played it with, but by hour two I'd much rather be killing their armies or stealing their grain or blocking their workers. Or letting them give me a root canal.

RATING: 9


One of my faves. Can totally tank (usually when playing with the wrong people--stay away from engineers when playing this one, IME), but more often than you would expect, plays out excellent creepy stories. It's not actually scary, mind you (you want Psycho Raiders for that), but it's hella fun.

Again, not a game where you want to be too attached to the results, as they will be largely random, but the trip to get to them is golden. A game where reading out the cards is essential.

I've replaced most of the tiles with figures (my old Dreamblade habit came in handy here), to get the most out of the theme evocation. Works well, especially as the characters are so small, it feels right to have all of the monsters be a whole scale larger than them. Monsters are larger than life, that's the whole point of them!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A group of strangers arrive at an old house on the hill. Do we need a reason to be there? Hell no. Oh yeah, and the front door is locked behind us, hmm, that's odd. Once we're there, we get to explore the house, have a whole bunch of strange or painful things happen to us, and then at some point one of us snaps. This person (the traitor) goes nuts and is hell bent on killing us, and those of us with any shred of remaining sanity try to stop the traitor. There are fifty scenarios to explain what happens to the traitor and how you stop them.

This game is dripping with theme. It's somewhat like a DM/GM-less RPG: you pick a character with unique stats (knowledge, sanity, might, and speed), and you roll against your attributes to determine the outcome of most events. There's really not a lot of strategy here, it's a very luck-heavy game, but this is not the kind of game you play to win. You play to make a story, and there's a fair amount of replay variety to these stories, especially after "the haunt." With the right light-hearted group, and the right mood music, this is a fun game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Appearance: 7/10
Mechanics: 7/10
Clarity: 7/10
Pieces: A lot

This is a "Nothing Else" game, meaning when that board hits the table, the TV is cut off, cell phones are put on vibrate and all the lights except the one illuminating the table are turned off. This is NOT a game you break out during a rowdy party. It has a story telling components that can't be fully appreciated with a lot of distractions.

The artwork is a bit dated looking, nearly all the pieces are made of cardboard and the plastic miniatures are uuuuugly, like painted army men. Another bothersome feature is the little plastic pointers used to keep track of your stats. They aren't tight enough to hold onto the character tile so you have to place them on top of the numbers and hope you don't knock them off.

The mechanics aren't the best, simply because there is always a chance that The Haunt (essentially the critical moment) can be triggered so early in the game that the players are completely unprepared which can end in failure.

The rules can be a bit iffy, especially if an event calls for the addition of creatures/monsters to the board. One of the best features of this game is that you can create your own scenarios or find some online, essentially giving the game way more replay value.

I do highly suggest that you buy or make foam board trays to hold and separate you cards and pieces. Using baggies and rubber bands is very time consuming when setting up/breaking down.

I would recommend trying before buying on this one.

RATING: 7
I love the first half of this game, exploring the house by laying tiles and drawing encounter cards. The second half is unreliable entertainment, depending heavily on whether the scenario is any good or not. I have downloaded and printed off the new and improved (edited) scenario books, but have not tried playing with them yet. I wish that the counters had better artwork, and stat sliders are slowly damaging the character pentagons.

Btw, all you geeks are wrong about the Underground Lake tile. Look closely at the tile, and you will see two levels worth of smashed floorboards above the lake itself. So, the actual lake may be at the basement level, but the room tile is properly labelled for the second floor, because the entrances are a couple of levels higher than the water level.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.1
As far as game mechanics go, there were a lot of interesting things going on; that may have been the problem - a game too enamoured with clever mechanics. Streamlining is called for, in my opinion.

The theme is okay, but spooky ANYTHING is very, very difficult to pull of successfully. Especially written down on little cards, and read out loud. I think the games authors made a reasonable effort at something that would require a superlative effort to really sing.

The mechanic of the "Betrayal" is way too clunky, and stops the flow of gaming dead while everyone searches for little pieces of cardboard. The blatant break also makes the first half of the game seem irrelevant. I understand that it is intended as an opportunity to pump up the stats of the characters, but in our session it didn't seem to function that way.

Then I can start nitpicking the design - cards the same colour on both sides, resulting in easily being boxed, symbols that don't read well on some room tiles, and plastic number indicators that are ambiguous also point to a game that was rushed to market. I felt a little like WE were playtesting it.

Too cludgy.

RATING: 7
Very thematic game - when you're playing the game it does feel like you're in a haunted house movie.

New players sometimes have trouble with the start of the game, where it isn't clear what exactly you're doing (or supposed to be doing), so it helps to have an experienced player to link the game to the haunted house tropes. The experienced player will also help keep the pace up. Without that, the combination of the rolling rules, combat rules, and two stages (and sometimes the second stage has multiple steps) will slow the game down and undermine the tension.

People tell me that it is very hard to beat the betrayer, but my experience has been that the betrayer usually loses. Perhaps we're playing it wrong?

RATING: 7
I really want to love this game.  I love the subject matter (staying overnight in a "haunted" house), all the expected clichés, and the pre-painted miniatures of the main characters.  I enjoy slowly building the house tile-by-tile. 

Somehow, though, it's not terribly spooky.  We've had some good Haunts and the "betrayal" causes an interesting shift in the dynamics, but something about the mechanics just doesn't quite click.  Are the attributes unbalanced?  Are all the attribute buffs/debuffs a little too arbitrary?  Are the found items not effective enough?  Whatever it is, we ended up vaguely disappointed the first several times we played.  

Our last game, however, felt much more like I think it should have and we all enjoyed it, despite a kind of sucky "haunt" (we were fighting evil music - duh duh DUUUUH!).

After a couple more games, it's slowly growing on me.

RATING: 6

Sure, there are some ambiguous places in the rules with respect to the scenarios, but it's easy to just make a house rule and move forward. I think Betrayal actually does a very good job of capturing the table-top role-playing vibe.

RATING: 6.5
I enjoy this game, especially the initial exploration phase. Moving and interacting with the rooms is supported by intuitive mechanics. While I appreciate the huge variety of haunts, they can be overly convoluted for non-gamers, grind the game to a much slower pace, or lead to quick and anticlimactic endings. It's these haunts that make this game horribly, horribly broken.

The dozens and dozens of tiny tokens make this box an absolute nightmare. If you have access to a 3D printer, I highly recommend printing an organizer, available on Thingiverse. There's a separate listing for a lid made by another individual. It makes finding tokens much easier, and you will no longer cringe whenever opening up the box.

RATING: 7
It's a really intriguing game. Played for the first with some friends last weekend. Our first play through was over 2 hours, the 2nd was a bit less than 2 hours. Uncovering rooms and triggering events was surprisingly exciting to me. I initially rolled my eyes at having to put together a house but many of the rooms add a good deal of interest to the game. Switching to the haunt was definitely the highlight. Reading your new roles/goals, planning a strategy, and setting up the new board is awesome. 

That being said, the haunts that we did varied immensely in difficulty for the traitor. Replay-ability is also a factor. Since it was our first time all of the haunts were new to us. But, in the future if we were to get one of the same haunts both sides would know how to prevent the other team from winning. I guess that would allow more strategy but it would really suck for the traitor to have the rest of the group gang up on him. 

The amount of pieces is a bit daunting. SO MANY little tokens. My also group doesn't typically play dice games either so having 8 was new for us as well. On the positive side all 8 dice are the same. 

I would keep playing the game. Definitely at least until we get through all the haunts.

RATING: 7
Betrayal at the House on the Hill breaks my heart. I absolutely love the way the game works with the exploration of the house, the finding of objects and the creepy omens. The atmosphere of this game really shines. Particularly when assisted when people really get into it.

But then the game screeches to a halt for the 'haunt'. 

The idea of the haunt is good in that each time a different story will occur based on the things that the players have done so far, but the different rules for each haunt are what really break the game's flow. The traitor has to go off (often having to literally leave the room) and read a few pages of rules and everyone else has to get to grips with new rules as well.

This can be particularly difficult when you are playing with people who are not especially used to this kind of game or there is one person in the group who is not comfortable with reading, doesn't understand rules easily etc. and then they are the traitor.

I wish the creators could come up with a way to make this all work better but I suspect the problem is too deeply entrenched in the game to be fixable....

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A friend once told me that this is a really entertaining game. 
He was right.
I played it several times and it is always funny. Gameplay and mechanincs are easy but interesting and well designed imo.

The Game itself does not contain alot of miniatures or tiles with extra ordinairy artwork. Enemies are usually only little markers. 

But the Storyline and the huge variety of scenarios (several dozens) combined with the horror themes (lycanthrophs, vampires, ghosts, Frankenstein) always make me grin deviously.
Every game is different due to the puzzle like maps and events. The real fun starts after the haunt begins and the parties get assymmetric information about how to win the game. The scenarios incorporate FFA, 1 overlord against the rest, 2 teams and hidden traitor, backstabbing (maybe more, i dont know all scenarios).

I absolutely recommend the game for friends of explorative semi coop games with a favour for mystery/horror themes, but: u should have fantasy. U dont get miniatures for all the evil minions. (nothing for pure fanboys of cool plastic-matter)

My advice: play it with more than 3 players. The more, the better.

RATING: 6.6
Components - .7/1 Cards and tiles are fine. Points deductions come from 2 things. The "clips" that are put on the character card to track you skill points are rubbish. They don't have enough friction to keep their place at all so you spend an unacceptable amount of extra time trying to manipulate them or simply not blow away your current attribute values. This is such a pain point I took off .2 for it. The 2nd is that the rules for the haunts tend to be a little to ambiguous about some of the rules (this isn't every haunt) but it's happened on several. This causes issues because generally because of the nature of the asymmetrical information once the haunt begins. For example if the traitor doesn't understand, they have to ask one of their opponents to help (or spend time looking up the answer).  

Fun - .7/1 I think the people I play with have had more fun with the game than I have. That being said, most of my issues come well after play. I find that in the moment I'm having a good time so that's why it gets a high rating in this category. 

Replayability - .9/1 There are several dozen different haunts that are triggered by a combination of where the haunt starts and which card triggered the haunt. In addition since it happens based on a die roll it can happen early with none of the mansion explored or after everyone is properly tooled up. 

Strategic - .5/1 This gets a meh rating on the strategy because early on you want to explore, there isn't really any strategy, it's just explore and hope that luck of the draw gives you things. Then since the haunt is completely randomly chosen you don't really have much to decide with that either. Once the haunt begins, that's where you actually do have to make decisions. In the number of games we've played so far I find that there still isn't a whole lot of decisions, either you have the stuff you need or you don't, so you either need to go do what you need to with the items, or you need to keep exploring to acquire the necessary items. The traitor generally has the more strategic decisions to make in my experiences so far.

Theme - .8/1 They've definitely got the spooky house bit down. The tiles and the cards definitely reinforce that narrative. That being said, it's a bunch of haunted house tropes all encompassed in one so it does seems a little all over the place (hence the small point deduction). 


Personal Review - 3/5 It's a fun horror game that in my mind is really about the experience as opposed to the gameplay. I just don't know what else to say that I haven't already stated.

RATING: 3
This is exactly how a game with a traitor mechanic should NOT be designed.

The game plays out with players picking characters and exploring a mansion waiting for something to happen.  Essentially the game's setup is "played" is the best way to describe it.  You unlock different rooms and collect items and special effects until a Omen roll is made that matches or exceeds the total number of Omen cards drawn thus far (so it usually goes until there's on average 6+ Omen cards drawn).

Then a player is randomly chosen to be the traitor and the scenario actually starts.  The traitor and the rest of the players are given different scenario books that detail their win condition and you play it out until one side wins.

This is not a good game.  I don't mind the random selection of the traitor, in fact Battlestar Galactica with a similar mechanic is one of my favorite games.  What I mind is the aimless first phase of the game.  You have almost no control over what you do, you're just discovering rooms aimlessly and collecting items and stat bonuses (or detriments if you're unlucky).  Then when a traitor is chosen you have no idea whether or not you'll be woefully unprepared for it.  In our game we actually explored a large percentage of the available tiles until the second phase started and it was nigh impossible to beat the traitor in the second phase.

You could even (though unlikely) potentially start the second phase with the first omen roll, or turn over 6 omen tiles in the first six turns and still start the second phase early.  With literally no idea what the win condition is for 3/4 of the game you have no idea what to prepare for.  Not that it would matter anyway since what stat bonuses and items you collect is completely random anyway.

Just no.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
The portion of the game before the haunt begins is pretty boring.  All you do is wander around a house, drawing tiles and cards until someone causes the haunt to occur.  It's not very interesting and after a while you'll see players get bored and ignore beneficial rooms just to get the haunt started sooner, which is probably not a good sign.

The flavor text on the cards is actually surprisingly eerie and really helps the game not become total drudgery in the beginning.  My favorite is a card where two boys are playing with a top and one boy offers the other the chance to play with it.  That boy, Jonah, then says, "No, I want ALL the turns," and beats the other child (presumably) to death with the top.  That's fucking brutal, man.

However, that may indeed be one of the problems with the game.  The flavor text is so good that the production quality just can't match it.  Sure, that might be a really cool text description, but the components are made out of relatively mediocre art and laughably cartoony drawings.  I thought the game was supposed to be more pulpy than the text makes it sound.  The problem seems to be that the graphic designers went the 1313 Dead End Drive route with the artwork and monster tokens, while the scribes (what do you call board game writers?) took a much more Edgar Allen Poe bent with the stories written on the cards and in the manuals.  It's such a cognitively dissonant effect that I can't decide whether the game is trying to be completely malicious or satirically cheesy, and it hurts any atmosphere that it was trying to develop.

Believe it or not, though, the haunt is actually worse.  Mainly, this is because every time you play, you're basically learning a new set of rules.  Some of the haunts are straightforward and balanced, but I am assuming that many are not based on our sample size (28 games, 16 of which were completely decided almost before someone even made their first move).  The straightforward ones are quick and fun for everyone.  The more complex haunts, however, are often total disasters.  If you don't have more than one person comfortable with reading and interpreting rules in your group, the game will basically turn into a complete disaster as one side does something that's not allowed simply because they mistook the rules for a certain action.  It is also hard if the Hero side includes a lot of visual learners, because then everyone in the group will have to read the rules to get them, turning the setup into a 20 or 30 minute slog as everyone familiarizes themselves with the objective and how they can accomplish it.

You might think, well, maybe that's a problem with your group.  Surely, I'll take that, if not for one thing:  the rules are also poorly constructed.  This is the major flaw in the game for me.  I could live with people flubbing a rule every now and then as long as the game were still fun or at least playable, but too often we've hit the haunt, tried to soldier through it, and just had to quit because the rules were ambiguous or unfinished.  We have to go to this room and make Knowledge/Sanity checks, but it doesn't say how many or what they do.  We have new combat rules that contradict those in the rulebook, but they aren't fully fleshed out so someone doesn't know whether a certain move is legal or not.  It's big issues like this that can often make the haunt unplayable, which then just kills the game and makes the initial 30 minutes of exploration feel like a waste.

So why a 5?  Well, I want to like the game and we HAVE had at least 4 good games of it.  Still, I fear that it may get traded if it continues to give us a horrible ending to a middling first act.

RATING: N/A
Not recommended in its current version, based on production deficiencies and unwillingness by WotC customer support to address the issue.

The 2nd edition (apparently it's 2nd printing of 2nd edition) has clips that are manufactured to work with thicker cards than the ones provided. They simply fall off and are utterly useless. The boiling water trick won't help, even if you hold the clips together with pliers while cooling; it's a different kind of plastic than the figures.

WotC customer support says they will to provide replacement clips (identical to the ones in the box, which means no help at all) but will not provide replacement cards (which could be glued to the originals, doubling the thickness and fixing the problem).

Anyone purchasing the game should know in advance that this is effectively a kit, not a finished product. In order to play you'll need to build up 24 card edges (6 cards x 4 edges) with tape of sufficient thickness to engage the clips, or find some other means (e.g. pencil and paper) to track stats for the characters. For a retail boardgame by a supposedly major publisher, I find that unacceptable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Okay, so this is not "Chess"!  In fact, it is rather the opposite of a "strategy" game, falling squarely into the category of an "experience" game.  In fact, in the first half of the game there is almost no strategy at all as you explore the house, and when the haunt starts and players have identified their new goal and seen the new house setup, the strategy usually becomes quite obvious.  Truth be told, you are pretty much there for the experience as the game plays you (just like if you were in a real haunted house!).  But the most important thing is, it is a FUN experience!  And with 50 possible scenarios, you get an entirely new experience every time you play!  Unfortunately, since this game was not properly playtested, a lot of work has to be put in before the first game can be played (downloading the updated Hero and Traitor booklets and FAQ, correcting wording on a couple of the cards, reading this thread... http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/159868 ...in order to pencil in some changes to the updated booklets).  If not for this, I would have probably increased my "game design" rating to a 4.5.  But, in my opinion, it is worth all the time and effort (and paper and ink!).  In fact, this is one of the best "gateway" games out there, due to the fact that it takes almost no time to learn, it is largely a co-operative effort (you can always choose an experienced player to be the traitor), and, as I have already discussed at length, it is more about a fun experience than brain-burning strategy.  In summary: good times!  Game design: 3/5  Personal enjoyment: 3.5/5  Total: 6.5/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is all over the place.  Sometimes it's too long, sometimes it's very short.  Sometimes it's a close, down-to-the wire win, sometimes it's a complete blowout.  Sometimes it's interesting, sometimes it drags.  I play it fairly often for its rating because it's hard to find good 6-player games, and this one scratches a particular itch.

The good: it's a nice bit of B-horror-movie fun. Some of the scenarios are incredibly interesting and tense (like a recent one I played that had the house collapsing as the heroes struggled to exorcise it). The random-traitor setup allows for some light screwing-everyone-over fun without the desperate keeping-secrets tenseness of Shadows, which can be a welcome respite.  

The bad: Oh, god, attack of the zillions of indistinguishable bits.  Why not have a few generic bits that say "Monster" or something, rather than 10,000 little circles, some of which say "Rat" and some "Dog" and some "Aliens from beyond the grave"?  It makes it impossible to find what you're looking for unless you have a really OCD storage system.  The scenarios can be terribly unbalanced, or they can be really boring for the traitor (one had me doing nothing but, I'm not joking, reading results from a die-roll table every turn to the heroes. That's it).  

It can still be a decent game, but it could desperately use a reprint with some rules clarifications and overhauls and a solution to the bit problem.  I'm not sure it's worth the slavering, pay-100-dollars status that its out of print nature has bestowed upon it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is interesting and unique. The board builds itself and the 50 different scenarios allows for ultimate replayability. The haunt mechanic is key, as it picks a random person at a random time to play out a random scenario for the crew to survive.  The game never plays out the same way twice.

Now this does cause some people trouble when they get fixated on a knowing the rules and knowing what to do at all times, but this game is meant to be played with a bit of mystery and secrecy.  The good guys do not know what the bad guy knows and vice versa, including abilities and what objects do under certain circumstances, and even often how to prevent catastrophic quest failure.  

To enjoy this game in the best way, have at least 4 players, (hopefully a full compliment of 6), and don't focus so much about not knowing what to do.  Try things and move on. Failure is a surety for someone, and the game is balanced pretty well, where the success or failure of the mission is going to rely on the relative tactical skills of the party and the betrayer.  You are going to lose half the time.  

If I had any gripes about the game, its that the shere number of tokens you need to search through in order to find what youre looking for makes the game flow slow down for a bit, but separating these out in advance could help. Also the figures, (only 6, one for each player potentially), are a bit flimsy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Not much of a "game" in the 'strategize, play to win' sense, but lots of fun anyway.  Definitely has problems though.  The big flaws (IMHO) are not the imbalance or the sometimes unclear rules, but the haunt normally does not offer options or encourage movement; it simply becomes a question of hoping you roll better on your combat rolls than the foe.  Scenarios that encouraged running around the house would be much more interesting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Betrayal can be a lot of fun. It has a very well established campy horror-flick feel, an entertaining exploration mechanic, a hidden traitor mechanic, and an absurd number of possible end-game conditions each with special rules for both the traitor and the rest of the group. The trouble with Betrayal is it's lack of depth. Players explore the house and roll dice until one of them trips a supernatural switch by mistake and becomes the game's villain--a role which up until that point was fulfilled by a predominantly harmless house.

This is essentially a party game that dresses up as an Ameritrash game for Halloween. It requires a large group to work well, and relies on the group dynamic and table chemistry that results from the theme to elevate this game above average. It is a game worth playing once, and worth adding to your collection if you enjoy the theme and feel enough. The dice rolling can get a little bit fiddly for non-gamers and the absence of strategy can be taxing for gamers, but overall it can be a lot of fun to play with a group looking for a casual, thematic experience with some dice rolling on the side.

There is a good balance of secret information for the traitor and the rest of the group.  Best played with 4+ people.

RATING: 8
This game is easy to learn and quickly explained - that makes it very accessable for non-gamers.
I also love the re-play value this game has thanks to its 50 scenarios.
The first phase can become a bit boring, when you just keep adding rooms and reading cards (mainly event cards), as there are a lot of rooms with card icons, and movent has to stop when entering such rooms. Player could feel like they can't do a lot.
That usually changes once the haunt phase starts - then the game can become a crazy race for the lifes of the survivors.
Sometimes, the scenarios can be over quite quickly, just because the important rooms are already revealed and close to each other. This is (of course) a bit unsatisfying.
On the other hand, other scenarios can be a crazy race against time (and each other) and make you burst with laughter.
Games never last too long, so even if you had a "bad pull" in one game, the next one to make up for it can just be played straight afterwards.

RATING: 7
What do I say about Betrayal? Betrayal was, for a long time, my favorite game. There's a reason for this. There really isn't another game that does what it does well as well as it does. You're exploring a spooky house with your friends. Spooky house things happen! The flavor text is wonderful. The scenarios are varied and you don't know which one you might get going in. That said, it's really random. You could start a haunt almost dead. You could start a haunt with seven items and your skills buffed highly. It rarely has to do with skill. New players playing as the traitor can break the game. The scenarios being triggered in a certain way can break the game. The game can break with little provocation. But until there's another non-mythos horror game with this lovely atmosphere and feeling of exploration, I'm going to hold onto this one and keep breaking it out on nights when we don't quite feel like playing something else.

RATING: 7
Literally Scooby Doo in a box.  This is a cooperative game where you and your cast of characters get locked into a large, deserted house.  As you explore, you uncover haunts that eventually turn one of your party members into a traitor, completely changing the game into a race between the traitor and the rest of the cast on who can complete their objectives first. It is a highly thematic game, so put your roleplaying hat on and grab a drink.  Time to find out why there's a surgical room next to the kitchen upstairs and a crypt overlooking an underground lake downstairs.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This has been a favorite of mine since I first picked it up in 2010. I am a huge fan of themed games. This game is dripping with theme. You are just a lone soul trapped in an eerie house that seems to have a mind of its own. But you are not truly alone, for there are others trapped in there with you. You might trust them from the start, and maybe you will even help each other out when your flashlight goes out or when something terrifying grabs you from the darkness. But soon enough, one of those strangers will betray you. The atmosphere is always so tense and mysterious. 

The mechanisms are very luck based. Most things you encounter will require dice rolls, and some characters are better at certain things than others. However, I think this fits will with the uncertainty and mystery that comes from the act of exploring a strange house.

The fact that there are so many scenarios is what really drew me to this game. You will rarely hit the same scenario twice if you play this game often. I have played this game over 20 times and the most times I have done a single scenario is 3.

This game is a good one to pull out during Halloween or if you have a group that gets really into the theme of the game. Again, it is one of my favorites.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
+ Widow's Walk
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
My biggest gripe would be that the books should tell you what the other group should know or not. In our haunt, the heroes were told how many hits the monster needed to take, but the traitor didn't have this information until we have him a way to track his damage.

Another thing is that some information seems to be shared when it shouldn't. We were told the revolver doesn't work on the monster and the traitor was told that too. He felt it would be cool for us to have attempted to use it only to find out it didn't work. I agree with that because it would have been a good moment thematically.

I also don't like the fact that some of the haunts base the amount of damage something might need to take on the number of players. It seems a few players die within two turns of when the haunt starts, so you have to count them but don't get their help at all. Scenarios are either too easy or too hard because of this.

The good news is that this is all dependent on the books. AH can sell an update or expansion with two new books and maybe a sheet of counters to fix these problems or make corrections. Maybe add a few new room, too.

RATING: 6
This was one of the first games in my collection and I really liked it at the time. As I've played better designed games, its flaws have started to stick out like a sore thumb. The first half of the game is pretty boring. You are just moving, collecting stuff, and really just waiting for the haunt to happen which is where the real game begins. Once the haunt does begin, however, the game is often times not really balanced at all. 

Really, the best way to look at this game is as storytelling game with little strategy. I have nothing against games that focus on the story, but I never really feel engrossed in the story that unfolds in Betrayal. 

I will still play and enjoy the game, and I will always have a bit of nostalgia associated with the game. My hunch is that I will continue to play this game quite a bit (especially around Halloween), but its luster has faded a bit with time.

RATING: 3
A co-operative game, where you run around aimlessly for a while and then someone becomes a traitor?  I was skeptical, partly because I dislike [thing=37111][/thing], which has a lot of similarities.

[b]Pros:[/b]
:star: Unique characters and stats are somewhat amusing
:star: Huge variability on the scenarios

[b]Cons:[/b]
:nostar: Basically no decisions the whole game
:nostar: Co-op then random traitor mechanic means the first part isn't really co-op at all because your best chance of winning is to make yourself strong
:nostar: Theme relies heavily on flavor text instead of mechanics
:nostar: Midpoint of the game (where traitor is revealed) breaks the immersion because now you need to figure out how the rules work.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
Wow, was this a dud for me.  The first part of the game is so structure-less.  You move to an open room, flip the tile, possibly roll some dice, then possibly take damage or get an item.  There are virtually no decisions at all or the decisions are obvious.  The cards have some flavor text, but relying on flavor text alone feels very dated to me.  I just didn't get into the theme, and the theme is the only reason to play this game.  The twist in the middle was an amusing story, but then again everything felt quite obvious.

To be honest, part of my negativity may be because of how poorly I did.  Every card I flipped over was negative, and I failed just about every roll.  My physical stats were reduced to the minimum by the time the twist came around, then I turned out to be the traitor and the other heroes just slaughtered me and my minions for an easy, anti-climactic victory.  I felt like I was just watching a bad movie for an hour instead of playing a game.  Hopefully I never have to play it again. 

UPDATE: I let myself get talked into another game of this and it was another miserable experience.  An hour or so of aimlessly wandering around a mansion and watching random events happen at me, followed by the plot twist.  In this game there was a dragon and some ancient armor we had to find to defeat the dragon.  We got the sword and armor on one person before everyone else died.  Then the epic battle with the dragon!  Except, both the dragon and the "knight" had damage reduction built in.  After 30 minutes of swinging back and forth and neither person taking a single point of damage, we decided to call it a draw.  

What a trainwreck of a game.  [thing=205059][/thing] has a similar theme but is 1,000 times better.  I will do everything in my power to avoid playing this again.  I am completely baffled by how this game is ranked in the top 500.
