RATING: 7.5
I would never call this a "great" game -- there's a serious luck element to the first half of the game, and it's frustrating to have your character start the haunt badly mauled by a variety of events or room tiles you had no idea you were running into.  That frustration doubles if the traitor is the one player who avoided all the pitfalls and is now armed with dynamite and a revolver.

But the haunt...ah, the haunt changes everything!  It's still a bit easy to get screwed over through no fault of your own, and an early or late haunt can certainly seem unbalanced.  That said, no one I play with seems to care, ever.  It's pure survival-horror fun, and the unpredictability makes it thrilling.  

It may not be great, but it is fun, and that's still a big reason why I play games!

RATING: 7
More of a shared experience than a game, though there are some strategies to figure out once the traitor is revealed.

This game requires a LOT of fixing and needs to be played once to figure out how it all works.  But once you've done it the game is a blast! Buy some monster miniatures too! 

I cannot stress enough that you should download the correction and organization files.  Then be patient with the game the first time through, though it is a light game there are a lot of rules.

A real shame it is out of print.

Update: Rating stays the same. I cannot get this to the table. It has the same problem for me as Funny Friends - I am scared to teach it because it is so convuluted. Don't get me wrong, I really like it, but if a newbie ends up being the traitor they rarely know what the hell to do. This should be a social/party game that I get played a lot, but it just doesn't work that way. I really do want to play this a lot more than I do.

Back in print now.  That is great.  




Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 1
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 1
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 4
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 1


Overall - 1

RATING: 6
This is fun if you enjoy B-movies and games with a strong theme.  If you want any sort of balance to your gameplay, you'll be disappointed.  Everyone works together for the first 2/3 of the game, encountering events that change your stats and your inventory almost randomly.  Then suddenly one of the players becomes the bad guy, a "plot" is read, and the two sides fight to the end.  The game has usually been unknowingly won or lost by the time the scenario is determined, though -- It all comes down to whether the items and rooms associated with the scenario have been found, or whether you had good luck with the random events that changed your stats.  Fun for what it is, though.

+/- If you are looking for a strategy type game than this is not it, has a lot of luck elements, but that's what makes this game fun to play as it is not meant to be taken seriously. 
- Because it is heavy on the luck element, it can be pretty brutal on players if things are not going their way.
- When the haunt happens, the flow of the game shifts which is cool, but the time it takes to read the rules and get things worked out on the board can hurt the interest level of a game group (especially if there are new players).

RATING: 7
The problems are obvious, but WOW what a fun game. Dropped to a seven from an eight after a few games, since I've seen more of what can (and does) go 'wrong'. It's still a blast to play.

******

The 'problems' are that missions can be, by pure strokes of luck, incredibly easy or impossible for one side or the other. If a fluke die-roll brings out the haunt turn one, it may be impossible for the heroes to win. If it happens very late in the game, it may be a matter of taking object A (which they found early) to room A (which has been explored, along with the almost all the rest of the mansion, for the past two turns). As long as you don't play it too much, I think it's a definite winner.

RATING: 8
I played the 2nd edition with the Widows Walk expansion. Highly recommended! 

Things I love: The expansion does a great job adding to and in some cases fixing the game. (it finally gives the house a bathroom!) The randomized house structure keeps things interesting. Love the theme of the game. The mounting suspense/ dread as each Omen shows up is great and can't be beat. 
Things I don't like: Some Haunts are somewhat broken or unbalanced. Many rules are unclear and take frequent visits to the forums for fixing. Easy for players incorrectly play any of the myriad of one-off modifiers (events, items, room conditions, etc)
The Weird: Everybody has a pentagram room in the basement of their house, right?
 For 100 possible Haunts and a dozen plays or so sessions it feels like I've experienced multiple haunts 2 or more times. Not sure why that keeps happening. 

Some games go quickly, some take forever. Just keep an open mind and enjoy it for what it is. Scooby Doo + House on Haunted Hill + Random cliche horror movie.

RATING: 10
[img]http://boardgamegeek.com/jswidget.php?username=Thrift+Thopter&numitems=10&header=1&text=title&images=medium&show=top10&imagepos=right&inline=1&domains%5B%5D=boardgame&imagewidget=1[/img]

I really enjoy this game because I like its theme a lot, and the fifty different haunts, along with all of the different combinations of room tiles and event cards, make it so that the game never plays the same way twice.

The game has both cooperation (with your allies,) and competition (with your enemy,) at the same time.

The haunts also vary greatly. Some times the heroes will have to fight monsters, while at other times, they'll need to solve puzzles, and retrieve items, or bring special items to a specific room in the house.

Mansions of Madness is my 3rd favorite game, but Betrayal at House on the Hill is my 2nd favorite game, because I feel it's more haunted housish.

In most of the Mansions of Madness Stories, the Keeper is able to start putting monsters on the board from the beginning of the game, and even if they're not near the investigators, the clock is ticking. The players also sort of know what they've gotten themselves into, based on what actions the Keeper has in front of him.

In Betrayal at House on the Hill, there is no sense of urgency, at the beginning of the game. Your characters came to the house because they thought it would be interesting to explore it, not because they believed there was something going on inside, that needed to be stopped.

The players also have no knowledge of what the house's layout is like, and they can accidentally fall through holes, into the basement, and have other such mishaps.

The explorers will leisurely wander around the house, finding strange objects, and sometimes witnessing events that can't logically be explained, unless you accept that the house is truly haunted.

All this goes on until one of the explorers betrays the others, and the heroes must put a stop to him, if they want to leave the house with their lives (and the players had no idea which of the fifty scenarios they'd be playing at the beginning of the game).

I like this change of pace from leisurely (if somewhat nervously,) exploring the house, to frantically putting a stop to the horrors the traitor has unleashed.

I also like the zaniness of the house, that the Mythos cards in Mansions of Madness can't replace. The house's mystic elevator can go anywhere, the very walls themselves can swallow an explorer and spit him out somewhere else, and as I eluded to before, players can get lost in the basement.

Both games are great, but I just find the unpredictability of Betrayal at House on the Hill's modular rooms, wonky encounters, and fifty different Haunts a little more interesting than Mansions of Madness.

Cons: game length varies significantly with either phase of the game capable of being too short or too long, little strategic depth, limited player control, high randomness

Not necessarily a competitive strategy game, but one that is still quite enjoyable for its theme.

RATING: 3.5
The traitor mechanic is something I've been interested in for a while. I was very excited when this game hit the table and went in ready and willing to love it. Unfortunately, the experience was dry and stale.

The gamestate before the traitor reveal seems to not matter at all. The players mindlessly roam the house, placing new tiles, collecting items and changing their stats until the haunt begins. 

Even though I was really bored by the time the haunt began in our game, it managed to rejuvenate my excitement - now the game really starts! The traitor left the room and read his instructions and we read ours.

When he came back, he was pretty confused (as he should have been) and we had to all read the "for the traitors eyes only" rules to try and figure out what was supposed to happen. Well, that was a mood killer. It didn't even matter because the traitor in this scenario (as the game has many different scenarios that can happen) basically doesn't do anything. In fact, we didn't even know if he was a good guy or a bad guy, or if he was even supposed to play. If he was a bad guy, and his goal was to kill everyone, then he was best just sitting still and doing nothing. It didn't matter because of how the scenario panned out, he was stuck, unable to move. The game then proceeded to end in a few turns because of random luck.

It was an incredible let down. Part of me wants to try again with a different scenario, but even the pre-haunt stage is an utter bore, so I'm not left with much faith in this games design and don't have much interest in giving it more of my time.

RATING: 9
The only negatives I have with BAHOTH are the health markers (the little plastic pieces for the character cards). They do not grip the cards properly. You can easily fix this by lining the edges of your character cards with electrical or scotch tape, but games as amazing as this should be playable out of the box.

Replacing the cheap cardboard markers and tokens with small plastic 3D tokens would increase the visual attractiveness of this game but would also make the game more expensive. I will be toying with a 3D printer soon and will be attempting to create full 3D token kits for this wonderful, highly replayable, and easy to learn fan favorite of our tabletop group. I am also toying with the idea of creating 3D rooms to use instead of cardboard tiles... Our gaming group is also working on rules for 5-8 players (possibly up to 12) that will include a team of betrayers instead of a single betrayer to accomodate our ever-growing group of tabletop addicts, but I digress.

Amazing game with a few non-critical flaws here and there. With exploration, strategy, problem solving and minimal RPG aspects to this game, it is HIGHLY recommended for any gaming group.

RATING: 5.5
Do I enjoy it? I guess. As in, I enjoy it more than doing nothing. Would I ever pick it? No.
Let me outline what you do for half of the game: 1. Move into a room. 2. Randomly draw a tile and place yourself on it. 3. Draw a random card. 4. Follow card instructions, usually roll dice.
Does this sound fun? Let me continue. In Shadows over Camelot and Dead of Winter, one of you is a sneaky traitor. You lie and outwit those pathetic, honest do-gooders. And you know what? It feels good. Dang good.
In Betrayal at House, a traitor is randomly selected HALFWAY into the game. And it's no secret either, so there is no opportunity to trick your opponents. In fact, there's no teamwork either in the first half because what's the point? You might be helping someone who's destined to become the traitor get even stronger.
After the traitor is selected, you will play through a scenario with your friends. I have to give the game credit because it does have many scenarios. But this is also where the nightmare begins for me, or the shit hits the fan so to speak. This is where the rules get so darn fiddly it'll make you want to flip the table. Movement rules are so goofy, actions you can take are unclear, is there any reason to explore?... what are we supposed to do again?... so wait monsters block movement, but not when they are stunned. They miss their next turn right? oh shit the traitor took his turn BEFORE he took his monsters turns. Can I transfer followers? So if I drop this item you can't pick it up and use it because I used it's strength boost in a strength check on this turn.
What. A. Disaster.
Let me say though that it was not my game, and I had not read the rules. My friends watched a video of how to play the game, which was annoying so I had to go through the manual myself. STILL it was very confusing and I've played enough games I usually know this stuff easily. After several plays it's still just as confusing. I'm not kidding.
This game has great theme. My wife and my friend's wife like it. Something about a spooky house, ghosts, and monsters is fun. As a gamer though, I just don't see the strategy or anything else that's good about it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game unapologetically chooses narrative over gameplay, and it's so committed to it and sets the stage so well that it mostly works.  There's rarely an interesting decision to be made, but the atmosphere and narrative matches the gameplay well enough that you barely notice.  The feel of exploring a spooky house from a b-movie horror flick is captured perfectly.  Something about the discovery of the house by tile plays and cards fits perfectly with the setup of a horror movie.  The first phase of the game never fails to build up the suspense before the big reveal.

That's not to say that the game is without flaw.  The reveal is sometimes anticlimactic, as either the adventurers or the traitor have an easy path to victory.  The rules, even in the second edition, are a mess, and players need to be comfortable with houserules to cover the rules holes.  Characters have stats that mostly are irrelevant except as hitpoints, and the method to track these stats are chintzy little pointers that don't work well.

But all-in-all, this is a good value for a theme-first group.  You'll get plenty of plays out of this game before you get tired of it.

RATING: 9

Highly random setup adds a lot of variety, so even though there are a finite number of scenarios it never gets stale.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
As the first boardgame that I've bought, I really enjoyed the game!

Pros:
1. Every time you play the game, it's different! It was probably one of the first few games to have this feature. Not only is the map different (because you build the 'house' as you explore it), the scenarios are *almost* always different, too! :D
2. Interesting horror-themed game, where you explore rooms and don't know what will happen.

Cons:
1. It's a little old, and probably have some new games with similar mechanics in the market now.
2. There is a HUGEEEE amount of small tokens involved. If you hate tokens, you'll find this game to be rather troublesome.
3. Lack of expansions - lack of character variations. There are 'stats' for each character, but they have no unique abilities of their own. That's one of the biggest 'cons' for me.

Overall, I really loved the game! The amount of replayability makes the game very worth it, especially if you love the horror theme! :P

RATING: N/A
------------------------------
NOTICE : Due to my poor spoken & written English, the rest of my comments will be written in French only but you can read my profile for more informations about the kind of games I prefer and how I rated them.
------------------------------

►ÉDITION : Avalon Hill games, anglais, 2010, 2e édition.
Éditeur, nb joueurs : 3 à 6 joueurs.
Éditeur, durée : 1h00/partie.
Éditeur, âge : 12 ans et plus.

►PUBLIC(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
☺ Jeu thématique (ex : coop ou semi-coop, améritrash, univers adapté).

►JOUEURS, NOMBRE(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
# Meilleur :
# Recommandé : 
# Non-recommandé : 3?
# Non-essayé : 4, 5, 6
3 joueurs : 1e essai à 3 joueurs. 2 gentils contre 1 traître et les 2 gentils n’ont pas fait le poids. Après la partie, nous nous sommes demandé si cela était dû à notre configuration 2 vs 1 ou au scénario généré aléatoirement (et qui aurait peut-être mieux convenu à plus de joueurs).

►COMMENTAIRE(S) ABRÉGÉ(S):
+ THÈME : assez présent; relativement bien intégré.
± Ambiance : est dépendante de l’implication des joueurs.
+ Configurations multiples : disposition modulaire.
- Élimination : le(s) joueur(s) éliminé(s) en cours de partie pourrai(en)t devoir attendre longtemps la fin de celle-ci.
+ Expériences multiples : personnages individuels personnalisés.
+ Icônes : sont faciles à comprendre ou à mémoriser.

►REMARQUE(S) PERSONNELLE(S):
® Je crains qu’il retienne peu l’intérêt des joueurs lorsque le stade de la nouveauté sera passé.

Jeu de maison hantée où chaque joueur incarne soit :
A) un explorateur qui doit anéantir la(les) entité(s) maléfique(s) de la maison afin de s’en libérer;
B) un sbire (traître) au service de la maison et dont le but est de tuer les explorateurs.

1e essai à 3 joueurs. L’une des particularités du jeu, c’est qu’au début d’une partie aucun des joueurs ne sait s’il est un traître ou non, les alignements étant révélés pour tous seulement au déclenchement de la seconde étape de la partie appelée "La chasse". Lorsque la chasse est déclenchée, les joueurs doivent alors se regrouper selon leur alignement et lire secrètement le scénario qui s’applique dorénavant à eux. Cette mécanique de "2 scénarios secrets" a comme défaut que chaque groupe ne connait pas les règles particulières de l’autre et ne peut donc pas valider si celles-ci sont appliquées correctement ou non, ce qui fait qu’on se demande parfois ce qui se passe... De plus, si un joueur est seul dans son groupe (ex : le traître) et qu’il a des questions sur son scénario, il lui est quasi-impossible de se valider auprès des autres au risque de dévoiler ses informations confidentielles. D’ailleurs, je dois mentionner que ma première partie s’est déroulé avec une copie anglaise et que mon niveau d’anglais n’était pas suffisant vs l’abondance de règles et de "flavor text" à lire (et c'est pourquoi j’ai profité d’une opportunité de "suicide accidentel" afin de me sortir de cette partie). De ce fait, je considère que ce jeu est injouable pour une personne qui n’a pas une excellente maîtrise de la langue du jeu. À noter que si j'avais joué avec une version française, j'aurais été plus encouragée à continuer la partie malgré mon impression que le jeu a mal vieilli (très forte présence de hasard dû aux tuiles et événements piochés, ces derniers étant résolus en brassant des dés…).

►JEU(X) COMPARABLE(S) ESSAYÉ(S):
= « Room 25 » (2013) : pour la mécanique d’exploration par tuiles et présence de traître(s).

RATING: 7.5
I really like the concept of having a different haunt during the latter half of each game. It adds a lot of replayability to the game. However, I did find that, when playing with a small group of 3, some of the haunts can be largely in favor of the traitor. That is, the traitor will often get bonuses to stats to help make up for them being outnumbered. This, in general, makes sense. The problem is, in a 3 player game, it becomes 2 vs 1 during the haunt. This, combined with the increased stats, makes it extremely easy for the traitor to win as all he really has to do is to take out one hero. Overall, unless you are playing in a larger group or have uncovered most of the rooms before the haunt is revealed, my bets will go to the traitor winning.

RATING: 10
Fun game with two phases: 1) exploration, 2) haunting.  All through out, this is a co-operative tile-laying exploration game of an old mansion.  When the haunting kicks in, one player betrays the others, so it's a contest between the betrayer and the rest of the players.  For the sake of variety, a book of scenerios is consulted at that point to find out how the game will proceed.  As the nature of adventure games, it's not balanced, but the end result makes for an interesting story.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Wow, is this game awesome or what? OK, sure, there isn't much going on before the haunt, but afterward, everything becomes very tense and thematic. Since you never have to play the same scenario twice, the game doesn't get old and repetitive in the way that Arkham Horror does. This is a great game because not only do I enjoy it a lot, but very casual players do as well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Betrayal is a nice alternative to other more complicated one vs. many games like Descent, Mansions of Madness or Battlestar Galactica. Gameplay is essentially a very simple dungeon crawl, but at a certain point the players split into opposing camps (usually one person becoming the villain) and then try to make their push for victory.

There is a bit of unevenness in the game's complexity. The exploration of the haunted house is right out of gaming 101, so players can get up to speed in 5-10 minutes. The haunt phase requires each team to add a page or so of secret rules to the game, so it can be problematic if an inexperienced player gets singled out as the "traitor".

RATING: 3
The crappiness of this game hurts all the more because the idea is so awesome.  But, man, there are a lot of problems:

1) The exploration mechanic is almost exactly like the old Mystery Mansion, but all the fun is killed by the fact that bad stuff, which you have *absolutely no control over*, keeps happening to you.  What this devolves into is finding one good room and "exploring" it repeatedly to beef up your character.  

2) The haunt is a really cool idea and can be fun if you can figure out the horribly written and error-ridden rules.  Basically, it works well enough if an experienced gamer gets drawn as the bad guy, and fails miserably otherwise.  

3) And of course, there is the ridiculous search through 10,000 chits preceding the haunt, completely killing the momentum.  Why, oh why, did they not just include 20 colored blocks or tiddly winks or some other generic bits?!  Do chits with the word "Zombie" on them really add to the atmosphere?  This is frankly one of the most glaringly stupid component decisions I've ever seen.

A very cool idea and some fun at times, but really poorly executed.  Here's hoping the second edition gets it right, because despite my negativity, there's a really cool game in here somewhere.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
For a short, light, storytelling experience, this game is a solid choice.  There aren't a lot of meaningful decisions to be made throughout, and that's going to bother serious gamers.  The gameplay is like reading the cards in Arkham Horror without any of the strategy stuff.  You kind of just wander around and stumble upon stuff. 

The lack of decisions isn't all bad.  This game works well with casual gamers, and I've brought it out several times with the extended family.  Like with Arkham Horror, the game is mostly cooperative which is nice for non-gamers, but unlike Arkham there isn't much worry about the Alpha Gamer/Quarterback problem since the decisions don't really matter anyway.

Fun game if you're okay with being taken along for a ride without much steering.

RATING: 6
Betrayal at House on the Hill has a ton of theme and is great for playing in October with people that can really get into the theme of a game.  It's a blast when you have the right people playing.  

The reason you need the right people playing is that the game has significant balance issues.  I love how you get a "random" haunt every time you play and the house configuration is always different as well.  The problem is that the haunting can happen way to early (or late) in the exploration and it can make it really hard to win for one side or the other (most often in our games it is the house/traitor that wins).  This is fine for those of us that play games for the experience and not for winning.  For those that want well balanced games and close competition, this game would not be recommended.  

We have a great time with it when it is the season, but otherwise it says on the shelf.

RATING: 7
I was recommend this game at a con after playing Evolution and was wanting to get my hands on Betrayal, I don't regret getting this game as I quite enjoy it.

Betrayal is a game where you're a group of explorers exploring this old house with randomly generated rooms based on what tile you get, collecting items and such until the haunt begins when triggered. Once the haunt is trigger the game enters a new phase where you play a scenario that may or may not have a traitor among you. With 50 haunts there seems and sounds like there'd a a good chunk of replayability. Also there's dice rolling and skill checks like a DnD game which I like.

I enjoyed Betrayal and would recommend checking it out.
If I there were any cons to the game, I would say that everyone at the table needs to know how to read and I say this because I had someone in my group who DIDN'T know how to read and that was unexpectedly frustrating. Another is the rules are a bit unclear, and that replayability I mentioned earlier while is in theory true, but after a few games the first half will start to play somewhat samey as you see the same cards you pick up, the same room tiles, and you're really hoping that the haunt comes up because there's the main fun of the game. Though the first half could be considered the setting and stocking up as you prepare for the haunt which is a good mindset I'd say.

Would recommend at least a playthrough despite some issues

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pros: 
~ Very good role play value.  You feel like you're in the house. Your mind creates visuals as if you were reading a good book.
~ The visual quality is excellent, particularly the house tiles and the little figurines for each player.
~ If you have (or are) a good game master, it's quick to get new players playing quickly.  There's only a minute or two worth of rules that you need to explain when you start, then you can just explain the rest as they come up.
~ Perfect for Halloween time!

Cons:
~ There are a lot of rules. It is highly recommended that the game owner learns the rules on their own first, then game-masters it for other people.  Do not unbox the game with a group and attempt to learn the rules all together; you'll get bored.
~ Given the high volume of rules, it's ironic that in pretty much every game, you'll encounter situations where the rules aren't solid.  If you're the type of gamer who enjoys the occasional make-it-up-as-you-go-along situation, you're fine.  If you're a strategic gamer who expects rules to be tight, you'll get driven a little crazy.
~ Caveat to strategic gamers: Although you make a lot of decisions in this game, you'll soon realize that your decisions are more or less meaningless.  The outcomes are almost entirely driven by the luck of the cards, house tiles, dice, and haunt.  

Overall this is a very right-brained game.  It is clear that the designers are very good storytellers and graphic artists, while being not so strong at writing tight rules and generating intriguing strategic decisions.  If you're into role play/storytelling/visuals/characterization in your game, you'll love Betrayal.  If you're into making strategic decisions, you might not like it so much.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Despite 5+ plays, I have never been the traitor. Maybe my opinion of the game is skewed by that. Betrayal is definitely more of an "experience" than a game. It relies on the large number of possible traitor scenarios to keep the game fresh from play to play. The conditions which determine each scenario are largely random (though once you know what a particular scenario's conditions are, you can try to steer things in that direction, but I don't know how successful you would be) and the determination of the traitor is similarly done by looking at some arbitrary condition in the game which is satisfied by only one of the players. Exploring the haunted house can feel a little pointless and dangerous if the pre-traitor phase of the game drags for too long. The game outcome of the scenarios themselves is excessively determined by the initial conditions of the scenario (what items each player has, how good their stats are, what the position of each player in the house is, etc.) which leads to most scenarios playing out far too easily for one side or the other. I do like that each side has a secret goal within each scenario, and that the players do not know the rules for the traitor; but this lowers the replayability of the game, since this interesting aspect is often lost if the scenario is replayed. As I said, Betrayal is focused on the thematic experience of playing, rather than creating an interesting, well-balanced system for players to interact within. It's not my type of game, but I can see why it has a lot of fans.

RATING: 6
Played 4 times. Pretty interesting (despite the terribly warped tiles that came in the box: how hard can it be to produce normal tiles, like most companies do???). José enjoyed being the traitor. Sophie found the game a little scary and wants to play it in broad daylight next time. 

The game is pretty random, but it is really thematic, especially if you coincidentally draw an Event Card that really matches the room (e.g. Sophie drew a card about laying in a coffin when she tumbled into the Coffin Chamber from the Collapsed Room). The one haunt we've played was incredibly fun, trying to find Voodoo Dolls around the house, while the traitor ran around trying to kill the weaker characters with a spear (however, she was ovecome by me and Wouter, who had a ridiculously high speed to dash around the house like a maniac). 

Overall: fun, thematic game with quite some randomness and annoying warped tiles. I definitely wanna find out more of the haunts!

However, it is marred by a variety of problems associated with the different scenarios.  Not to mention ambiguous rules that require a ton of errata to clear up.  Depending on when the haunt starts and if there is even a traitor involved, your experience can sometimes be very unsatisfying due to how it is resolved.

Overall, I think Betrayal at House on the Hill is very thematic and well worth playing.  It just sorely needs an update to make the game more balanced and less confusing.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is as close to perfection as a game can get... in my book at least!  I love  the fact that every session incorporates both co-operative and competitive playing variations.  Although the game inherently contains some minor flaws, almost all of them can be ironed out with the supplements provided here on BGG. 

The game elements are very nicely done and my only complaint is in regards to the villains - actual miniatures would have really taken this to the next level.  I understand that this would not have been at all possible with every boss monster though.  All in all, I love the survival/horror theme and the idea of pitting one player against the rest half way through! 

The game components are top-notch!  The character wheels are very unique and avoid the excessive use of more counters (there are so many as it is!) to mark health in all the different categories.  The character pawns are not painted the best, however, they really are of high-quality materials and depict the characters well.  The modular board has to be my favorite of all!  It is durable and attractive.  It contains some pretty interesting elements as well.  

As I mentioned, this game comes with an excessive amount of chits in the first edition!  Be prepared to sort through them all!  The second edition does an excellent job consolidating the amount of chits included in the game quite nicely.

The new release of this is game has had so much negative feedback concerning components, haunts, actual "new" additions, etc.  I am happy with my first edition, but I really love this game and ultimately decided to purchase the second edition as well.  I am happy I did so, because it contains new items, updated rules, etc.  

This is THE perfect gateway game and it should be a staple in every horror gamer's collection!

RATING: 5
An interesting "experience" game that no one should be playing in order to display their superior skills/best someone else. If you would rather play and win than play, lose, but have "fun" - you probably won't enjoy this much.

The theme is well integrated. The storylines that emerge tend to be enjoyable in a B-movie kind of way. But, on the other hand, the funky events coming together can sometimes crash the 'rules' and grind the whole thing to a halt. So, be aware that that's a possibility and plow ahead if you can remember that you're basically sitting over a toy with rules.

RATING: 6.5
I really wanted to like this game, and I've gotta say, for the most part, I did.  The scenarios where the traitor has monsters or whatever running around with him seem to be the best, but that's not to say the others are bad.  Really cool game, pretty quick to play compared to many of todays and dripping in atmosphere.  Only let down by some bad editing/proof-reading - WAY too many errors in this game.  Also, once you've played it a lot and learn what haunts are what, a lot of the 'wow' factor disappears...
